name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Friday, 23 October 2020.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, we began our last plenary meeting by paying tribute to Samuel Paty, a teacher who was killed because he believed in freedom of expression. It is with great sadness and emotion that we find ourselves opening our session with words of condolence, while our thoughts turn to the victims of the latest Islamic terrorist attacks in Europe, and our thoughts go out to their families and friends.  A fatal stabbing in Dresden, Germany, in early October: an infamous terrorist attack. On 29 October, three people were killed inside and near a church in Nice. Then again on 2 November four people were killed and several injured in central Vienna. Every victim is part of us and every attack, wherever it occurs, must feel like an attack on us, an attack on the fundamental values that we fight for, which we discuss: freedom of expression, freedom of religion, freedom of conscience. They are attacks on the open society that we want, attacks on the inclusive society in which we believe. It is therefore our common responsibility to combat all forms of extremism and to remain united in solidarity against violence and hatred. The European Parliament will continue to make a major contribution to our living together, in peace. Please join me for a minute's silence in memory of our victims. (Parliament, standing, observing a minute's silence) *** Look, honourable, as you know, to ensure equal treatment for Members who are both present in the Chamber and, many more, connected with us remotely, Parliament has decided in recent months, during its plenary sessions, not to accept points of order because that would be a way of not ensuring equal treatment. Any points of order, my dear colleague, can be tabled in writing and will be examined at a later date, as we have done in the last part-sessions. Mr Ferber, you do not have the floor. You don't have the floor.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The Minutes of the sittings of 19, 20, 21, 22 and 23 October and the texts adopted have been distributed. Are there any comments? (The Minutes of previous sittings were approved) But I would ask you all not to disturb this plenary.  (Off-microphone speeches by Mr Beazley) Ferber) You can do it in writing! That is what has been decided. I would ask you, as experienced Parliamentarians, to respect the rules we have set ourselves and the rules provide, in this case... Listen! Listen! The rules provide for a non-discriminatory attitude. You can do this in writing, as has been done. Then I will take your request to the Bureau of Parliament and we will decide, because there are bodies in this Parliament that decide, it is not just the President who decides! Mr Ferber, no, I will not allow you to say these things. You are so experienced that you know that there are bodies responsible! Let us move forward, please, sit down, because that is not possible, I will take your request to the Bureau of Parliament and we will decide. Moving on. The plenary is open, so that sign seems out of tune to me, sorry! The plenary session is open.  Look, Mr Mc8, I am very patient. I have already told you that I will take your requests to the relevant bodies of Parliament, discuss them and give you an answer. But now sit down and let's start the plenary, thank you. I don't want to call you to order.  I would ask you to sit down, Please sit down.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: We now come to the order of business. The final draft agenda approved by the Conference of Presidents on 22 October 2020, pursuant to Rule 157, has been distributed. Following consultations with the political groups, I would like to submit to the House the following proposal to amend the final draft agenda.  - On Wednesday, the Council and Commission statements on the multiannual financial framework (including own resources), the conditionality mechanism linked to respect for the rule of law and the European Recovery Fund are added as the first item this afternoon. Two statements by the Vice-President/High Representative for Foreign Affairs on: 1) the fight against impunity in crimes committed against journalists around the world; and 2) on the geopolitical implications of the Abraham Agreements in the Middle East region are postponed until the second november troika. The debate on the reports by Mr Mureşan and Mr Tang (A9-0198/2020) on the Investment Plan for a Sustainable Europe - How to finance the Green Deal is moved to Thursday, as the last point of the morning. The sitting will last until 10.30 p.m. - On Thursday, the reports by Mrs Bilbao Barandica (A9-0180/2020, A9-0182/2020) and Mr Roose (A9-0185/2020, A9-0184/2020) which were part of the joint debate on fisheries partnership agreements with Senegal and seychelles, are put to the vote directly. The reports by Mr Winkler (A9-0199/2020, A9-0202/2020), which were part of the joint debate on the agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China, are directly put to the vote. As a result, the time slot is cancelled from 15.00 to 16.30. In addition, the following dossiers are added directly to the votes: the report by Mr Fernandes and Mr Tinagli on the establishment of the InvestEU 2021-2027 programme (A9-0203/2020) and three objections under Article 112, two on genetically modified maize and one on genetically modified soybeans (B9-0346/2020, B9-0349/2020, B9-0347/2020). Finally, I would like to inform you that the votes are distributed over several shifts, taking into account the number of amendments tabled and the number of requests for split and distinct votes. Information on the distribution of votes in different shifts is available on Parliament's website in the "Priority Information and Documents" section. I would also remind you that this redistribution may be subject, as you will understand, to further changes and the relevant information will be available on the website.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We adopted my report on the adaptation of MiFID II in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and a large majority of political groups, which also represents a large majority of Members of this House, supported this report being put on the agenda of this plenary session. It was rejected by the Communists [removal]1. I find it interesting that, contrary to all custom, that majority decisions are accepted here, this item has not been put on the agenda, and so I would ask you to put this issue on the agenda of this mini-plenary session. ---------- 1 Text corrected at the request of the speaker in accordance with Article 5 of the Bureau's decision of 3 May 2004.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Mr Ferber, the problem is that we have a very tight timetable with regard to the way in which the plenary is conducted, and that is, of course, very difficult to insert. Could we do a round of consultations, or what? There are no spaces. At the moment there is no possibility of inserting another vote.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to point out that it was intended to put it on the agenda of the mini-plenary session, and then it was taken down again. Then, through the group, we tried to put it back on top of it. Now it's being taken down again. Other things that are much shorter in their decision-making processes – and you have just mentioned a number of points – have nevertheless been on the agenda. I really wonder: what are the criteria for deciding here? This is a legislative act that we urgently need to do because it has COVID relevance. In this respect, I would be pleased if we could succeed in getting the will that the group of PPE,Vp, S&D, Renew [delete]1 and, if I see it correctly, the ECR, in the group conference, that this item should also be put on the agenda. I do not think it is acceptable. There is no rule in the Rules of Procedure which says that there should be unanimity here, because there is no longer any possibility of debating here. Mr President, if you want to fulfil your task of being the chief representative of Members, then it is my urgent request that this responsibility be fulfilled. What you are doing here at the moment is not to assume that responsibility. You have privileges, you have a driver, we have to use public transport here. Is that the protection you give us? Of course, you get the daily allowances every day. We do not get it because you have decreed it without being able to rely on any paragraph. They hinder Parliament's work on the specific matter and in many other matters as well. I would ask that the report on the mini-review of MiFID II be put on the agenda. ---------- 1 Text corrected at the request of the speaker in accordance with Article 5 of the Bureau's decision of 3 May 2004.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Mr Ferber, Unfortunately I must disappoint you, because from a small examination your request has never been received as an official request by any political group. Maybe you missed this little detail. I have never received an official request to add to the agenda the proposal you made just now. The requests, as you know, must be made one hour before the beginning of the plenary session, on the basis of the Rules of Procedure. Mr Ferber, your request has never been officially submitted and has therefore never been discussed. With regard to the second point you made, I would remind you that the decision on the register of signatures was taken unanimously by the Bureau of Parliament. Of course it was taken for two reasons, and since there is a certain animation I want to explain them.  In recent weeks, hundreds of cases of contagion have occurred in Parliament, and so there was a need, in order to protect our institution and the functioning of Parliament, to take a decision so as not to crowd Parliament. Parliament's Bureau unanimously decided, for a few weeks, to suspend the register of signatures, which can of course be reinstated. But listen to me, otherwise it becomes a dialogue between the deaf! I'm explaining to you what the situation is like. This decision was made for a few weeks. At the next meeting of the Bureau this measure can be corrected.  However, it was important, for everyone's health and for parliament's efficiency, to allow the trilogues we had, the institutional commitments that we had, very importantly, not to close Parliament, because in recent weeks there have been hundreds – including Members, collaborators, Parliament staff – infected people. In the penultimate weekend alone, we had 171 positive cases.  A temporary measure was taken at that time, which I am well aware of is true in order to prevent the possibility of closing Parliament down at the moment. But, of course, we all hope that this measure will be suspended and that it will return to normal. (The order of business was thus established)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the multiannual financial framework (including own resources), the conditionality mechanism linked to respect for the rule of law and the European Recovery Fund (2020/2858(SDR)). I would remind honourable Members that for all the debates during this part-session there is no catch-the-eye procedure, nor will points of order or 'blue card' questions be accepted.  There will also be remote intervention from Parliament's Liaison Offices (our EPOS) in the various Member States.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I have to say that today it is with great honour and pride that I am able to address this plenary. Yesterday I think that we, all together, made history. The European Parliament, the Council and the Commission negotiating teams reached an unprecedented agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and Next Generation EU, and on own resources. We started this journey in 2018 with Brexit as the biggest challenge for the next EU budget. At that time, of course, nobody could have imagined that the COVID-19 pandemic would have sadly taken and threatened the lives of our citizens, and put a strain on our economies, businesses and the internal market. This new context has been very present in our MFF negotiations. We are demonstrating that Europe is up to the challenge, that the European institutions can live up to their responsibilities in the face of this unparalleled crisis. Unprecedented circumstances call for unprecedented responses. That is why, once adopted, the new long-term budget and Next Generation EU will represent the largest package ever financed by the EU budget, with a total of EUR 1.8 trillion. This package will help Member States, business, regions and citizens face the pandemic and rebuild a post-COVID-19 Europe. A new Europe, which will be greener, more digital, more resilient, and better fit for the current and forthcoming challenges. These negotiations have been lengthy and difficult. But yet, thanks to the constructive spirit of all institutions, including this Parliament, which I thank, we have managed to reach a good deal for our institutions, and most importantly for our citizens. May I say, on a personal note, I want in particular to thank the key representatives of Parliament in these negotiations. We all know it was not always easy to get an agreement, to find a common position, but at the end of the day you made it, we made it and I think this is something I would really like to honour, to salute and to acknowledge. It’s a good deal for the Parliament, I have to acknowledge, and I am grateful for this, because you have attained a number of achievements including the reinforcement of EUR 50 billion for specific programmes compared to the European Council agreement of 21 July. This includes flagship programmes of our Union and key priorities of this Parliament, such as Horizon Europe, InvestEU, Erasmus+, Creative Europe, Health for Europe... you name it. The increase is very substantial for programmes such as Rights and Values, and as I mentioned already, EU for Health, which will, respectively, double and triple compared to the level agreed by Member States in July. Moreover, 30% of EU funds will be used to fight climate change – the highest share ever and a key priority of this Parliament, while the Do No Harm principle applies to the whole of the EU budget. Let me just underline that we must also endeavour to translate this ambition into sectorial legislation. The agreed package also pays attention to biodiversity and gender mainstreaming. The agreement boosts the modernisation of our policies. Considerable funding will be allocated to research and innovation, fair climate and digital transition via the Just Transition Fund and the Digital Europe Programme; and to preparedness, recovery and resilience via the Recovery and Resilience Facility, rescEU and the new EU4Health programme. Parliament called several times for flexibility, and this budget will have increased mechanisms to guarantee it has the capacity to address unforeseen needs. The Flexibility Instrument has been increased further by EUR 1 billion. The overall functioning of special instruments is preserved even with a new set of special instruments, which followed the European Council agreement. The Commission has also committed in a declaration to present a review of the long-term budget by 1 January 2024 and, as appropriate, a proposal for revision. Another big achievement by Parliament and the Union as a whole, which I salute, is a clear roadmap towards new own resources to repay the borrowing for Next Generation EU. A reform of own resources has not been undertaken since the 1980s and we have also succeeded in this during these difficult times. Another collective achievement is our agreement on a rule of law mechanism giving us more power to protect European Union taxpayers’ money. This will be accompanied by an integrated and interoperable information and monitoring system to ensure the collection and comparability of information on the final beneficiaries, to avoid and counter conflicts of interest, irregularities, issues of double funding and criminal mis-use of funds. So I count on your support in translating these provisions into the sectorial legislation. With all this good news we must not forget one thing: we still have essential steps to take for the MFF and Next Generation EU to be in place as of 1 January 2021 as agreed, for the annual budget and completing the sectorial instruments. Time is extremely short and the COVID-19 conditions remain extremely challenging. Our citizens and businesses need the EU budget support. We are on the final sprint and once again I thank you for your strong commitment and dedication.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. We are almost at the end of a very long road which, as the Commissioner mentioned, started around 2018. It was a complicated road, because it was going in different situations.  Firstly, we had to react to the forthing Brexit. And remember, in Parliament at the time, our decisions indicated that, after the United Kingdom's exit, we wanted to keep the European Union at the same level and that we did not agree with the reduction of the Union's ambitions. And that's what we're sticking to. We believe that Brexit must not bring about a change in the union's actions.  Secondly, there was the problem of a pandemic, which completely changed the situation. Thirdly, there have been new developments which have led to an interest in the rule of law in the European Union or the maintenance of the entire democratic system in the Union.  These new situations, which have arisen recently, mean that the negotiations this year are quite different from in previous years. These are not mere negotiations, when we are trying to find a solution for each other, but a situation in which we have to take into account all the elements. That's why these conversations were so difficult. Please also note that we are considering preparing a conference on the future of Europe, and if we look at these negotiations, the way we talk about borrowing, the ratification of certain actions, the granting of credit and the creation of own revenues, we have in fact already started a discussion about the future of Europe. The European Parliament has already spoken for the first time about the future of Europe. We believe that europe's future lies stronger in Europe, which is why we have fought for certain solutions.  The first very important signal to citizens from the outcome of these negotiations is this: we believe that cuts in important European policies that concern the future of Europe are unacceptable, and we need to strengthen these policies. Not as we would like, of course, but as much as we can. Secondly, we believe that there are important issues for all citizens, such as safety, health, border protection, research. And that's why we put pressure on them. But for us, the future of the European budget also matters. How will it be constructed? How will it work after seven years? What will be the consequences of the financial perspective we are starting now? Hence our very clear emphasis on the design of the budget, on internal mechanisms.  Please note that we have not violated the political agreement reached in the European Council in July this year, but together with the Council and the European Commission, we have found solutions to strengthen policy without violating it. We can really say that everyone has actually benefited from this.  I therefore point out that one of the most important elements in our work was the unity of the European Parliament, which was very visible in our negotiating group. We acted together despite differences of opinion and views. I wanted to make this very clear, because this is an important lesson for Parliament: only acting together gives good results.  At this point, I would like to thank all my colleagues in the negotiating group very much. I have a lot of respect for them because it's hard, but very interesting work. I wanted to thank our colleagues, assistants, advisors. I would like to thank the European Commission and the Commissioner for their cooperation. These have been difficult discussions, but we seem to be getting out of them and the discussion on the future of Europe has just begun.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are living through very difficult times, but little by little we are seeing hopeful news. We started the week with the news on the vaccine and I hope that today too, the European Union can offer new hope to so many people who are having a hard time. We are asking people for great sacrifices to protect each other. Apart from death, illness and loneliness, thousands of people are losing their jobs, their savings, the business they had so hard to open. We see poverty increase and how there are large inequalities to work from home or care for the elderly and vulnerable. Therefore, no one would understand that here we did not agree to act as soon as possible, especially when the Plan is already on the table. No one can, outside these walls, understand that it is intended to block aid or that procedural issues remain outstanding. A European proposal needs to be addressed to start talking and responding to people's problems. That's what we're here for. The Union takes no action against anyone and is not taken by the link between the rule of law and the Community budget. The new mechanism has been a success of this Parliament and, therefore, of the whole European Union. Because in this chamber, where European popular sovereignty resides, we work to strengthen the democracy and the framework of coexistence that we have given ourselves. Because, without strong institutions, it is citizenship that loses. Please, let's get over the divisions, the blackmails, we're going to think about people. We are already immersed in the second wave of the pandemic and it is difficult to calculate the extent of economic and social damage. The contraction of 8% of GDP is expected this year. Even with a vaccine in the coming months, we would not resume previous growth until 2022. And that's why we need an effort over the next year to cushion the blow and lack of recovery. The Union was soon reacting on the first wave and that is why we now need to regain the initiative. Let's not go mess it all up now. Parliament was the first institution ⸺and I would like here to recall⸺ which urgently called for a Recovery Fund to include debt mutualisation, and the Council adopted it in July. It was a historic decision and I would like this Plan to be a historic success of the Union, of Europe. And it will be if we can implement the next financial framework as soon as possible and also if we get new sources of funding. We're on the right track. For the first time, Parliament has managed to raise the figure adopted by the Council: an additional EUR 16 billion which will enable us to strengthen public health systems, research, Erasmus, culture, development cooperation and, moreover, we have introduced the horizontal principle of equality into the budget between men and women. Moreover, a legally binding commitment to own resources. And we have done this, our negotiators have done it, to which we have to be very grateful because we have remained united and united. You will always be able to count on the loyalty of the Socialists and Democrats to move forward in Europe. For the sake of citizenship, I am confident that the other groups will also maintain Parliament's unity and I hope that no one is thinking right now of using other possibilities to reintroduce austerity or macroeconomic conditionality measures into the Recovery Plan. There is a clear position of this Parliament and that is what we have to defend. I ask you to focus now on ensuring good agreement on own resources, because that way we can finance the recovery. In my political family we are putting everything on our side to make sure we get out of this crisis without leaving anyone behind. They won't see us blackmail or torpedo agreements, or get last-minute tricks out of the joker to take advantage of this juncture. We're here to work for citizenship. I hope we all have the same intention.

name: Dacian CIOLOŞ
text: on behalf of the Renew group. – Mr President, today the European Union marks a historic achievement by reforming this budget. It is a historic achievement not only in the figures, by the amounts we put on the table to respond to this crisis, but also because this reform of the budget means a step forward, it means strengthening two essential and truly European pillars of this budget. I'm thinking here first of all about my own resources. This is the first time that the European Union has borrowed from external financial markets to finance a crisis, is making a decision very quickly, and here we are able, we are able to make a decision because these funds that the European Union assumes with a loan will be repaid from new own resources. It is an essential pillar of the future European budget, because these own resources will contribute not only to those who pollute, because we want a green economy, but also to those who have so far sought, large companies in the digital sector or in other fields, to avoid paying taxes to the European Union, even if they were taking advantage of the common market. And secondly, a second essential and strong pillar of this budget is respect for European values and principles translated into a mechanism to make funds a matter of law, to respect the rule of law. This is the first time that we have made a direct link between the European budget, between European taxpayers' money and respect for values and the rule of law, which is the foundation for the establishment of this European Union.  And here is that when the European institutions are working in the same direction, when the European Parliament really assumes the bargaining power and representation of its citizens, we can move very much forward in strengthening the European Union. Beyond that, and this time, the European Parliament has managed to obtain complementary amounts to what the European Council has proposed in order to strengthen truly European programmes. And I am thinking here not just of the European health programme, which, even though it was proposed with great enthusiasm, was left without funding or with very little funding by the Council. After Parliament's negotiation, this health programme comes out strengthened. We also have more money for research, which we see how important it is these days, we have more money for young people or for strengthening European borders, behold, more money for truly European projects. Beyond this, it is now important that we can also move forward on the negotiations on the instrument of recovery and resilience, where the European Parliament must have an important say at the same time. I conclude by saying that this time no one will be able to say that the European Union is a colossus with feet of clay, because the European Union and the European Parliament have shown strength, flexibility, dynamism and courage in these negotiations, and the European Parliament has managed to turn a crisis into an opportunity to strengthen the European Union. It is therefore a historic moment for the European Union and I hope it will be a new beginning for this Union.

name: Jean-Lin LACAPELLE
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as we prepare the European budget over the next five years and discuss the financing of the recovery plan, the European Commission, behind the announcements, is having guilty blind spots about the use of our money.  Have you learned the lessons of the first wave? Last March, in the face of total unpreparedness, in front of Europe deprived of masks and medicines, in the face of the economic collapse caused by the breakdown of supply chains dependent in particular on Asia and China, you seemed to react. We had heard the words "sovereignty," "strategy," "independence," which our current of thought had so far been the only one to bear. But do these words lead to realities? Will we fund, will relocations be encouraged? Mr. Thierry Breton claimed that they had begun. Do we have any figures, statistics, specific examples? We believe that part of the recovery should be played on recovery incentives for companies. Will these aids be conditional? Will there be quid pro quo? Will the vulnerability of our small and medium-sized businesses be taken into account? Finally, it is essential that the autonomy of European states can be developed. We must invest in localism, i.e. bring producers closer to places of consumption, shorten supply chains and regain industrial independence on our strategic activities. These objectives are essential and this recovery plan must devote all its efforts to achieving them. Let us invest for our security, our future, our peoples and our nations. Colleagues, the recovery plan, which must serve our jobs, our businesses, our production, our citizens, our peoples, is taxpayers' and citizens' money. But you are only a citizen of your country. The artificial citizenship of the European Union, the detestable citizenship of the world, fantasies of uprooted cosmopolitans, have and must have no political reality. However, the European Union seeks to take away the right to raise taxes in the name of a regal prerogative. Until now, the European Union's financial revenues have come from payments by The Member States of amounts set on a fraction of GDP or from certain national taxes - no doubt, in the eyes of this European Union, it was still too much room for States, even if this place was only that of the sheep being mowed. But here comes the European tax, this tax that will make all the French, all the Germans, the Italians, the Spaniards, the Belgians, all the citizens of European countries, the tax subjects to the euro-globalist super-state. It is this tax, hitherforthed, forked under cloak, that the health crisis gives the opportunity to establish. Finally, these new citizens of the European Republic will have the privilege of repaying the giant loans that the European Union will raise on the financial markets because the Union, nor the Member States, has the right to finance itself from its own Central Bank. Adopted in the midst of the crisis, in haste, these worrying changes, which change the political status of each of the 450 million inhabitants of the European territory, represent a danger to democracy. If we want to finance ourselves, there is no shortage of solutions: public subscriptions with treasury bill issues, increases in state payout rates or the repeal of scandalous rebates granted to northern states in exchange for the adoption of the stimulus package. According to its Constitution, France participates in the European Union, but it must not blend in with it. Colleagues, in line with the industrial dispossession allowed by European ultraliberalism and the fiscal dispossession provided for by the New European Union's own resources, here is finally the most detestable dispossession: political dispossession. The recovery plan provides for conditioning European aid, not on the relocation of companies or the maintenance of employment, but on respect for the rule of law, i.e. full submission to so-called liberal-libertarian progressivism. Our compatriots, by dint of hearing it everywhere, confuse the rule of law with the legal state - the legal state is the one that respects the right to act, the rule of law is something else: it is the state that obeys certain political principles that themselves dictate the law. But what principles? Who chooses them? Who decides them? Gianni Buquicchio, chairman of the Council of Europe's Venice Commission for the Rule of Law and Democracy, said on radio on 5 November that the rule of law did not impose anything on its own and depended on what politics put into it, that is, what democratic choice decides to put in it, nothing but the democratic choice. When the peoples of Poland and Hungary, freely and voluntarily, elect Euro-refractory governments, affirm their attachment to their traditions, to their history, they define the political doctrine that the rule of law must apply. They have a sovereign and legitimate right to do so. And their rule of law is beyond reproach. When foreign governments, even unelected technocrats, such as those of the European Commission, who support other political principles, come, through a despicable blackmail of big money, to summon Poland and Hungary to betray the decisions of their peoples, it is these governments and technocrats who violate the rule of law. Such a behaviour of moral authoritarianism, which seeks to impose hegemony on the conscience of Europeans, is unbearable. If the people choose, the state executes: the rule of law is guaranteed in Hungary and Poland. If you do not like the voice of the people, you are the one who has a problem with the rule of law, ladies and gentlemen.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I will not dwell on the merits of the agreement, but rather affirm my pride, my pride in two respects.  First of all, that of being part of a European Parliament which, this time, had the courage to defend its convictions. In the past, this same Parliament spoke loudly, rolled mechanics and then, in many cases, lowered its flag without even defending its values in the face of the Council. It was not the same this time.  Parliament wanted a more ambitious budget, wanted a budget aligned with the values of the European Union, starting with respect for the rule of law, and also wanted a more forward-looking budget, starting with the ecological and solidarity transition. And, on these three areas, it is undeniable that the agreement reached yesterday substantially improves the Agreement of July obtained by the Council.  Of course, it is never enough - I can already hear some colleagues say so. That is true, but in the political balance of power that the elections gave us, I think it was the best deal that was possible. The second topic I wanted to address is the fact that today we live in a political world where it seems that, to succeed, the recipe par excellence is to polarize our societies, to oppose the camp of good to the camp of evil. I think that logic is deadly for our societies.  On the contrary, it is the logic of dialogue, the logic of compromise, the logic of collective intelligence that has enabled us to give the European Union an instrument, not the only one, but a crucial instrument to address the social, environmental, democratic, economic and health challenges we face.  Well, I am proud that this logic of compromise prevailed, and I would like to say a greeting to our Conservative, Liberal and Socialist colleagues and salute their spirit of openness and compromise throughout the proceedings. Because the compromise we have reached is a compromise that goes beyond political families, but also a compromise that goes beyond institutional boundaries.  I think that this time the Council did not treat Parliament as a kind of accessory but respected us. And I'm proud of that.

name: Johan VAN OVERTVELDT
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, yesterday we concluded negotiations on the European Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). These negotiations have been intense, or intensive, because all those engaged were fully aware of what was at stake. First of all, I want to thank all the delegations involved, the Council and the Commission, but certainly also my colleagues in the negotiating team – most of them are present here today – for their efforts and their constructive cooperation during those weeks. It’s fair to say that we have been working hard and we needed to work hard because we were faced with a fait accompli. The July conditions of the Council conclusions were untouchable: that’s what we heard and that’s what we had to change because we thought there was a lot wrong in those conclusions. We fought for our priorities and there can be some satisfaction with what we reached or what we achieved. From the start of the negotiations, I emphasised very much that it is very important that we strengthen the future-oriented, innovation-oriented programmes like Horizon, InvestEU, Erasmus... and EU4Health, of course. When drawing up the budget for 2020 we already made an important change in that direction, and that has been strengthened now. Additional resources will be available for all those things that are crucial – for future jobs, future growth, future competitiveness and also, certainly for the fight against climate change. Compared to the European Council’s conclusion of July, we have EUR 15 billion extra for these flagship programmes. And let me especially draw your attention to the fact that for EU4Health, we have been able to triple the budget, and we also secured that adequate new resources are available, or will be available, to honour the considerable future burden of the EUR 750 billion for the Next Generation EU. With the conclusion of these negotiations, the Recovery and Resilience Facility (RRF) can finally be activated. This is absolutely important to get us over and beyond the crisis, and it’s up to the Council now. We’ve heard repeatedly in recent months and weeks that it is Parliament that is stalling, Parliament that is delaying, Parliament that is responsible for this or that. Well, the short answer to these allegations is no! Parliament has done what it is supposed to do – defend its priorities, act constructively and fight and try to find a compromise in a positive spirit. The train is on track. The Council should make sure that it can leave the station.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, the improvements achieved by the European Parliament in the Council's original proposal are a positive step but not enough to meet the challenges of the times and the demands and expectations of European citizens. The pandemic and the great recession it has caused have dangerously increased the already large disparities within the European Union and within the Member States. That is why we need a strong and ambitious multiannual budget to support public health, sustainable economic recovery, support for employment and social and regional cohesion. The European Parliament has succeeded in improving the Council's original proposal, but the agreement is far from our original objectives. Let's be realistic!  The increase we have achieved in the budget is EUR 16 billion, just 1.5% more than the Council's original proposal, and before us we have objectives: firstly, not to block the rule of law mechanism from being blocked by a veto by Mr Orbán and, secondly, the road map for own resources from 'indicative' to 'binding'. We took a positive step. We still have a long way to go and I hope that the Council will abide by the agreement it has signed and ensure — where necessary — the necessary unanimity.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this negotiation has been complex, but yes, it was certainly worth it. We have obtained AN EXTRA EUR 16 billion on the key programmes for the future of European citizens. , such as speculative finance and digital giants. A timetable that must be respected, but it is also necessary to speed up the response for European citizens, especially with regard to the RRF negotiations; In this respect, I welcome Parliament's proposal to bring forward from 10 to 20 % of the total, with the extension of another year for expenditure, which is also supported by the Italian Government. We need a fair, rapid and effective response in the interests of all, which means reforming even those policies that have not so far allowed full European integration, for example the Stability Pact, which must not simply be suspended but also deeply reformed and revised.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, Ladies and gentlemen, this is a historic moment!  We have a budget that strengthens the present and protects the future. It strengthens the health program (tripled it). Citizens are well aware of this importance. We need a vaccine: it strengthens the investigation. We need jobs: it also strengthens the InvestEU programme.  It also protects the future, protects citizens. For the first time, we are committed to the Council that the European Union's own resources, the sources of funding, are introduced in such a way that they are sufficient to pay off the debt created by the Recovery Fund. We have a basket of own resources, so there are no cuts in funds and programs. This is also a crucial point for the future.   It is that, at the moment, the costs of debt that are in the budget ceilings are only 0.01 % of the budget for seven years. That's €12.9 billion. But after 2027, the cost of debt will be €15 billion a year, it will be 10% of the budget and therefore it is crucial that we have new own resources to protect the budget in the future, so as not to burden citizens at the same time, to avoid cuts in programmes that are essential and also in their funds. That is why this agreement, which is binding, an interinstitutional agreement also has a timetable for the introduction of new own resources with a simple principle: those who do not pay must pay. And it's only fair that the digital giants pay. It is right that there should be a tax on financial transactions or a carbon adjustment mechanism at borders that will at the same time even help to give competitiveness to our small and medium-sized enterprises.  Then we have also strengthened the legitimacy of this Parliament. We will be involved in the Recovery Fund and we have also done something historic in Article 122 that has not been mentioned, an article that the Council has used not only for the Recovery Fund, but, for example, also for the European Stability Mechanism. From now on, Parliament, when the Council wishes to use Article 122, will be involved, with the aim of reaching a common understanding in joint meetings on the budgetary implications. We have therefore given hope to the citizens. We give the Member States the opportunity to make good use of the resources they have at their disposal. We have strengthened our own resources, we have also strengthened democracy. Congratulations!

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Hahn: financial framework, own resources, rule of law, recovery plan... what four topics for a debate! Every one more important. And the truth is that 2020 has been a very tough year and we needed good news and finally it seems that November is bringing them to us.  On the financial framework and own resources, I would also like to highlight the history of the agreement. What has been achieved is a radical change: for the extra 16 billion and also for the introduction of new own resources, because it was urgent to address this debate. We need better funding for budgets, we need it for the recovery plan, and we also need to end the shortcomings of a fragmented, unfair and insolidary system that many take advantage of.  And to historical agreement, which we also reached last week on the linkage of the European budget with the rule of law, which was not so long ago unthinkable. Finally, we have a clear and applicable mechanism on which this Parliament had been working for years.  In this agreement we have succeeded in improving the scope, linking it with the values defined in Article 2 of the Treaty. We have introduced the preventive nature, added a list of examples and on top of that we have included tax evasion and evasion among the objectives. And we have also established a system to provide guarantees to final beneficiaries—that is, students, universities, researchers, NGOs—so that they are not affected by the freezing of funds to their governments. And, also, we will evaluate the effectiveness of this mechanism in three years because it is a new mechanism.  And finally—and we keep making history—the recovery plan. Here we still have the final negotiation of the content with the Council and, for this, Parliament already has its position. I hope to find in the Council the same goodwill as in the previous dossiers.  The incredible welcome these two historic agreements have had shows that when we work together and with the aim of building a Europe that protects its citizens, things go well. So thank you very much and congratulations to all of you who have contributed to this agreement and to make us proud, once again, of this project.

name: Valérie HAYER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would hope that this morning all the pro-Europeans have raised their faces. Let us take time, let us be aware of what was achieved yesterday by MEPs in this House: EUR 16 billion. Sixteen billion! This is an unprecedented victory. In 2006, four billion euros. In 2013, zero billion euros of fresh money. We tripled the health budget, where Member States saw it as a national competence that should remain national, even in times of pandemic. We have corrected this nonsense. What happened yesterday is proof that Europe is not driven only by states, and only by states. By fully exercising our role, we MEPs have shown that we are the guardians of Community Europe, the guardians of the interests of Europeans, who demand more money for the mobility of students, who ask for more money for research, who demand more money for our borders, who demand more money for our cultural sector. Colleagues, we have done it! We were laughed at, we were told to go back down to earth, that we would only have bums... We did it. And on own resources, now, what should we say? Because the $16 billion is nothing in terms of volume compared to what we are going to get from these new own resources. We're finally going to have a carbon adjustment mechanism at the borders, we're finally going to have a tax on the digital giants, we're finally going to have a tax on financial transactions. And this tax on financial transactions, like the others, if we got it, it is because we negotiated, not by making trials of intent to those on the other side and around the table. Be aware: we have not created a real resource of our own since tariffs. That was 50 years ago. Let us therefore take stock: in April, we called in this House for the creation of a massive recovery plan. Today is 11 November, and we have a plan of 750 billion euros, but we also now have the assurance that this plan will not be reimbursed by European citizens, but that it will be reimbursed by the digital giants, by the financial institutions that speculate, or by the non-European companies that pollute. My friends, what a victory! What a victory! Even the Greens have told us that they will vote in favour of this budget. How long has this not happened, ladies and gentlemen? Since when? Ladies and gentlemen, I say congratulations to this European Parliament, I say congratulations to this European Parliament! We are the only ones able to reform Europe in the face of states entangled in their chronic unanimity. Let's continue our battles! Let us now launch the conference on the future of Europe. Let us not let go, and tomorrow the Union will finally be power.

name: Rasmus ANDRESEN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Those who suffer most from the COVID crisis should be those who benefit most from the EU budget. We are in a dramatic pandemic. Almost the whole of Europe, including parts of this Parliament, are in lockdown, and the lesson of COVID should be that together we invest more in our public health system. That is why we were shocked when, after the Council summit, we realised that the Heads of State or Government wanted to cut back on health. Instead of cutting back on health, we are now tripling the European health programme, and I believe that this is a very central success that we have achieved here together in the European Parliament.  The culture and the creative sector are also very much affected by the COVID crisis. We are all experiencing this in our countries, theatres and cinemas have to close, many tours are cancelled, artists are fighting for their existence. That is why it is more than just a signal that we have negotiated over EUR 600 million more for the Creative Europe programme.  But COVID is also a global crisis. Poorer countries outside the EU do not have the same opportunities to respond to the crisis as we have in common in the European Union. That is why it is right and proper that we have mobilised EUR 1.5 billion to help other countries, to contribute to global development. But COVID is above all also a crisis of democracy when we see what is happening in Poland, what is happening in Hungary, but also in many other countries. That is why it is absolutely right and sensible that we should now have an instrument that makes it more difficult for democracy destroyers such as Viktor Orban to carry on with their policies as before. And it is right and proper that we will double the Rights and Values programme to help NGOs – democracy—NGOs, LGBTI organisations, but also organisations fighting for equality – to fight this fight on the ground.  We must fight all crises, and the biggest crisis remains the climate crisis. And even if this budget decision, which we will take in a few weeks' time, will not solve everything, we have managed to make important instruments binding in the budgetary objective: the principle of damage prevention, a binding biodiversity quota, which will mean that biodiversity is not simply taken more into account in the budget, but that nature conservation becomes a separate budgetary objective. These successes are impressive, and for that I would like to thank my colleagues from the negotiating team and, above all, our staff, because without them none of this would have been possible.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: – Mr President, I would like to start by thanking this negotiating team, and particularly the chairman of this team, Johan Van Overtveldt, for the successful finalisation of negotiations with an extra EUR 16 billion for the MFF flagship programmes is a really important issue. I think we also have to evaluate the roadmap for own resources, but there are still very difficult issues ahead and we have to remember that Member States have to have their say on this very challenging new taxation, which is always the devil in the details.  We still have to decide here in Parliament about the very challenging issues once we receive the Council position – whether we will keep this package or maybe employ some different tactics – because the most important thing is to allow for MFF money to reach those Member States that have been waiting for a long time and have been hit very hard by the pandemic.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Mr President, there is always more merit to be done than it is to prevent. And I want to commend the role of Parliament's negotiators, who have worked hard to make progress, including linking the budget to a 'rule of law' mechanism. On a budgetary level, these improvements are indisputable in relation to the Council's position at a discount. But they are still insufficient compared to the original ambitions of the European Parliament. And farmers will be the first to suffer from this budget. On the question of own resources, which were, as you all know, a strong marker for the European Parliament, of course there are novations but these novations are very constrained. The tax on financial transactions is referred to the Greek calendars, with no guarantee of implementation. And the contribution on plastic, known as 'own resource', is actually a contribution paid by Member States and is not based on a tax. But the most worrying thing is elsewhere. This multi-year budget, backed by the stimulus fund, opens up the risk of a renationalisation of European policies. And we have to be very careful about that. Finally, Mr. Chairman, we wanted a budget of an afterthroir and we have the budget of a world before that does not respond... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Mr President, in July the heads of state and government negotiated for four days and four nights and adopted their position on the budget of the European Union for the next seven years. Immediately we, the European Parliament, recognised the good parts of that agreement and we also pointed at those areas where the agreement could still be improved. We recognised that the allocations which the 27 heads of state and government had negotiated amongst themselves for each country was something that the Parliament should not challenge. But we also said that, in the European programmes – in the future—oriented programmes, those programmes which should make Europe more digital, more modern, more competitive – the heads of state and government had made cuts and more money was needed. And our negotiators, after intense negotiations, have managed to achieve a very good result, and the number is EUR 16 billion more for the people of Europe as a result of the demands and the fight of the European Parliament. Is that a lot? Yes, it is an amount which makes a big difference to the budgetary lines it will go to. Let me just mention some figures: on the health programme, we are tripling the budget from EUR 1.7 billion to EUR 5 billion; the research programme, EUR 4.4 billion more – and just two days ago, we learned that the European company which received European support from EU money for research is in the lead with regards to discovering a vaccine; Erasmus, EUR 2.2 billion more, which means almost one million young Europeans will be able to have a scholarship in the next seven years because of the achievements of Parliament. And we are also reinforcing the Rights and Values Programme because, yes, we have an agreement on the rule of law mechanism, there is conditionality. Those who breach the rule of law should be sanctioned, but those NGOs who defend the rule of law, they should be supported. The rule of law mechanism also contains, as a demand of the Parliament, one very important prerogative: it says that the beneficiaries of EU funds should never suffer if a government attacks the rule of law. There are three pillars for the EU budget for the next seven years. The multiannual financial framework I just spoke about was a good result. The rule of law I just spoke about was also a good result. And there is also the Recovery and Resilience Facility, and here, Commissioner, I can report that the European Parliament is on track. This week we are giving the final mandate to our negotiating team, to the three co—rapporteurs, and one of them for the final negotiations with Parliament. What will we demand? We will support the allocation criteria and the amounts for each of the countries as negotiated in the Council, but we want to prolong the programme from three to four years because we now learn that Corona is a longer—term crisis, and we want to make sure that money gets where it’s needed. The more money you spend, the more you need to make sure that the control is good, that there is a strong goal for OLAF and for the European Public Prosecutor, and a strong goal for reform. Country—specific recommendations and the European Semester are very important because the title of the programme is ‘recovery and resilience’... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: Mr President, Commissioner, we have succeeded! This is a historic victory for the European Parliament.  For the first time, we were able to increase the budget of the European Union, which had been agreed by the Heads of State and Government. We have introduced the principle of financing the Union budget for new own resources, without asking for additional efforts from citizens. And this can be a starting point for changing the structure of funding for the European Union budget. The 7-in-7-year discussions of the famous 1 % that Member States pay and which verbalise, but never verbalise, the benefits of belonging to the European Union and the internal market. We have ensured that the costs of next generation EU will not be paid at the expense of European policies, Cohesion Policy or the CAP. We have strengthened the powers of the European Parliament in the Recovery Fund, thereby ensuring more transparency and democratic accountability. We have also managed to strengthen European policies by EUR 16 billion.  This budget protects citizens from the pandemic, triples the budget for the Health Programme, strengthens the Research Programme, mobilises additional resources for sectors particularly affected by the crisis: the culture sector or humanitarian aid, or the Rights and Values Programme, essential for democracy and the rule of law. It increases the Union's capacity to promote investment. It sets ambitions: climate, biodiversity, gender equality.  I end with thanks: to the Council, because it has taken a safe step in difficult circumstances; commission, which has put safe alternative solutions to solve problems on the table where necessary. A very special thanks to Commissioner Hahn and his entire team, the services of the European Parliament and the political groups in Negoteam, which was the unity of Parliament that allowed this agreement.

name: Moritz KÖRNER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I believe that we have clearly seen in these negotiations that only the European Parliament is really fighting for European priorities. 16 billion more for important European tasks, for Erasmus, for students, for young people in Europe, for research – and we are seeing in the last few days with the development of the vaccine how important research is – for digitisation, because it is precisely in this crisis that we realise how important this is and how much we are being left behind in relation to China and the United States.  What is clear is that the Member States – as we saw at the summit – are only fighting for their own interests. It's just about how much they pay in and how much they get out. If we really want to make Europe fit for the future, we need to focus more on what we need together for the future. And the European Parliament has achieved a great deal, achieved as much as possible. But we must also say that in the conference on the future of Europe, we must talk about how we can create even more for the future of Europe.  And we have successfully tackled a second issue, that is the rule of law. After all, it is not acceptable for EU funds to be taken, but for EU values to be trampled underfoot afterwards. And because a previous speaker from the French right has just said, well, there are actually no common values and the rule of law, because that is different in every country, and that would also depend on traditions and so on, I would like to make it quite clear here that there are clearly common European values in Europe, and every Member State has committed itself to them by joining the European Union. It is not the case that some people come from Europe and say that you have to stick to any values now. We have set them together in Article 2, and we will defend them here, and this Is what this European Parliament has fought for, ladies and gentlemen.  We must make it quite clear that we have achieved a great deal in this. We have finally ensured that the rule of law reappears in this regulation and that this was not just such a small addition, as the Council wanted, but rather that we also protect the independence of the judiciary again. We have linked it to the annual report on the rule of law, so that we can bring together the various instruments there. We have also ensured that the recipients of the money are protected, because in the end we do not want to punish ordinary citizens, but governments that do not abide by European values. We have achieved a great deal in this.  This mechanism is not what we dreamed of. But it is more than I dared to hope for in the meantime, for example, because the negotiations with this Council were really difficult. One had the feeling that Viktor Orban was sitting at the negotiating table. And to him, who is still threatening to stop this whole budget and everything because of the rule of law, I want to make one thing very clear here: if he does that, he will clearly show that he cares nothing about the European future, nothing about the future of his country and its citizens, but only about his corrupt friends. We will not allow that to happen.  And a final word to the Commission: we in the European Parliament will now be looking into whether the Commission is using this rule of law mechanism. We will press for it.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Mr President, overall, we have achieved a good deal. I can even see some historical components in it. Of course, in such a complex deal one can always find flaws and disappointments. But the question that we have to ask ourselves is: with this comprehensive budget deal, are we making the EU stronger or weaker? My answer to that is stronger. Especially when it comes to the post-pandemic Recovery Fund, the new own resources and the rule of law conditionality. These three instruments are a step forward towards more integration. They could have been more ambitious – true, but it’s also true that they could have not been there at all. The selfishness of Member States regarding an outdated understanding of national interest – all this could have made all the efforts derail, as so often happens, but this has not been the case so far. Concerning the content of the MFF (Multiannual Financial Framework), this is the least ambitious part of the deal. For instance, the research programme gets far less money than it should, while military spending appears too much in this budget. But it’s also true that the long-term budget has to be regarded together with the additional EUR 750 billion of the Recovery Fund. Let’s be honest, just a year ago a fund like this, with a borrowing mechanism like this, would have seemed impossible, but we had to make a virtue out of necessity, and we did it. Finally, it is worth mentioning the climate and biodiversity spending targets – we in my group are proud that we also succeeded on that.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent The world and the European Union are in economic crisis. The Multiannual Financial Framework and reconstruction plans can alleviate this crisis – the EKR knows this very well. Conservatives believe that europe can be strengthened through these instruments. The citizens of the European Union, however, are amazed at the fact that, at times, the European Parliament and the European Commission are unreliable in assessing the real risks. The Vice-President of the European Parliament says that some countries need to be starved and not given financial support. It's a bad language, it's not a Christian language. Ms Barley, it is not national governments that take money, money is taken by consumers, citizens of twenty-seven European Union countries. We all know that the rule of law is a value of the European Union, but today the real problem is the economic crisis, terrorism, insecurity. In France, a gunman kills a man, cuts his head, in Germany a gunman drives a car into a crowd of people. Today, of course, fraudsters who extort funds from the European Union are the problem. They are in every country and we have to eliminate them from the public market. The Multiannual Financial Framework and the Reconstruction Plan must not be directed against Christian governments, against right-wing governments. Of course, we are fighting the pandemic, let us fight it, let us help the companies that are swathing, let european solidarity unite us, and punishing anyone in the European Union can only put the European Union at risk of ridicule.

name: José GUSMÃO
text: – Mr President, the fund we are adopting today and its regulation are necessary, even if insufficient for the scale of the crisis we are facing. But the party that some political groups are doing with the adoption of this regulation serves to conceal two serious decisions for the future of Europe. The first is the non-consecration of an exclusion clause for fossil fuel financing, replaced by a very vague terminology which basically throws this matter at the Commission with unpredictable consequences.  The second is the introduction of a regime that does not appear in speeches, but enters into the regulation, a punitive regime on all states and all democratically elected governments that do not agree to implement the political agenda, never suffraged, of the European Commission. It is serious, it is a serious precedent, that governments and programmes that have been suffraged by the voters of national democracies are subject to penalties, on the basis of a discretionary assessment by the European Commission on these programmes, based on absolutely serious criteria. This is a precedent that should not have happened and should not continue.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: – Mr President, we, as the European Parliament, have certainly delivered in these Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) negotiations. We have delivered in own-resources. For the MFF, we have delivered on flagship programmes and, for me, most importantly, we have delivered on the rule of law. Last Thursday, we reached an agreement with the Council as regards the rule of law conditionality. I honestly call this a historic milestone for protecting European Union values, a milestone that we have waited for years to come true. For the first time, we have established a mechanism that enables the European Union to stop funding governments that disrespect our common values, such as the rule of law. Most importantly, we did not compromise on the values. We made sure that the rule of law is seen in the context of all the Union’s values enshrined in the Treaties, such as the independence of the judiciary. With this regulation, every breach of the rule of law – any breach of the rule of law – can be covered by the mechanism, from individual breaches to systemic or recurrent breaches for which no mechanism has existed so far. And more than that, we opened the scope. We have a separate list for breaches of the principles of the rule of law. We reduced the timeline from the Presidency’s proposal; we put back in the text the protection of the final beneficiaries.  I really want to thank my co-rapporteur Eider Gardiazabal Rubial and the whole European Parliament negotiation team. I believe we all agree that this mechanism may not be perfect, but it is a significant improvement compared to the proposal we received from the Presidency. In this connection, I would also like to thank the German Presidency for very, very constructive negotiations. Going back just a couple of years, there were not many who believed we could achieve this much, if anything. We, as the European Parliament, listened to the will of the citizens and pushed for a real rule of law conditionality mechanism that actually works. This is a huge achievement that we can be proud of.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, at an extraordinary moment like the one we are experiencing, in the face of a second wave of the current pandemic that is affecting all our countries, it is Once again Europe that is taking a beating, and it is doing so with the agreement on the Union's multiannual budget, which for the first time will see, thanks to the just battle of this Parliament , more resources than those initially provided for by the Heads of State or Government. Community programmes such as EU4Health for public health, Horizon Europe for research and training, creative Europe for culture, Erasmus for our young people will not be cut to repay interest on European public debt, because that will finally require the Union's own resources, which have been talked about for decades. No more taxes for citizens, as some would have us believe, but the possibility of finally putting our tax system back on track, with the web tax, with the tax on financial transactions, with the carbon border tax. The risk that, with Europe's extraordinary aid plan for the economic recovery from the pandemic, the important contribution of the States would be considered exhausted and that we would have to be satisfied with a budget even lower than the current one, that risk was high.  On the other hand, the message that starts from here is clear: we do not want to sacrifice the future in the face of the dramatic needs of the present that we are experiencing, but rather Europe is facing the present precisely by looking up to a future recovery that leaves no one behind and that does not pass on the costs to future generations, who have the right to live in a Europe that lives up to their expectations and that is cohesive around its values. Yes, its values: today we establish a fundamental principle, after years of unsuccessful attempts. Europe is not an ATM: those who do not respect the founding principles of this community cannot think that they have a credit card in their hands that dispenses money regardless. This is the solid and supportive Europe that is taking another step forward today.

name: Katalin CSEH
text: – Mr President, this budget deal is historic for so many reasons, because for the first time we have a rule of law mechanism. We have a tool to fight back against democracy backsliding and to make sure that EU support reaches those who need it the most, instead of disappearing into the pockets of corrupt oligarchs. But our work is not done yet. We need to continue to be the voice of our citizens who witnessed the abuse of EU funds up close day by day and who have spent years calling on Europe to finally do something about it. We need to make sure that Europe continues to listen to them.  This rule of law mechanism is not only a piece of legislation. It is a resounding commitment that Europe is ready to take action. Let me tell you, action could not be more urgent. I am sitting here in Budapest, where every day there is a new scandal breaking. Our country, this morning, woke up to the news that the government is about to amend the constitution to make it easier to funnel public funds to oligarchs. They should be protecting lives but instead they are protecting their own pockets. And, up until now, EU action has been disappointingly slow or even completely absent. But now, we have all European institutions, all major political groups, lined up behind this commitment. Now there are no ifs, no buts and no excuses. Let us remember, a few years ago such a rule of law mechanism or new own resources existed only in the visions that were outlined by my fellow MEPs, Guy Verhofstadt or Sophia in 't Veld, at the plenary of the Parliament. And I was one of those EU citizens who was inspired by them and who kept on enthusiastically hitting the like and share buttons on social media. And now, thanks to this Parliament, these visions are within our grasp and it is very humbling to be present when this first draft of history is being written. This budget shows the stark difference between those who bet against the European project and those who never stopped believing in it, because even a few months ago, it was unthinkable that we will have a budget of this size and this ambition. This was the bet of European populists – they have written the EU off. They believe that European democracy is losing and the future is creeping authoritarianism from Russia, China or even Donald Trump’s United States. But they were completely wrong.  The best thing about liberal institutions is their capacity to constantly renew and reinvent themselves and this is why Europe always rebounds. This is why those writing us off could not be more mistaken. We will keep on fighting and no amount of midnight legislative crackdowns will be able to stop us.

name: David CORMAND
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for this debate. Let me have a rather contrasting look at the package that is now being proposed to us. We have a formula in France that is often used and reused here: this agreement deserves neither excess of honour nor indignity. No indignity, because this is the first time that we have a recovery plan that allows us to have European solidarity and that is something that did not exist. No indignity, because we also won on the setting aside, a little bit, of the Semester, which forced us to austere policies - we see obviously that this is not the right thing to do today. No indignity, either, because there are first leads to own resources, but I will come back to that. No indignity, finally, because, it is true, for a very long time, this is the first time that we have a slightly - very slightly, but still - revalued multi-year budget, to the tune of EUR 16 billion. But no excess of honour either, because there have been missed opportunities in these negotiations. Now I want to go back to own resources. These own resources are fundamental, for two reasons. Firstly, they are the ones that guarantee us that we have European sovereignty where we are not under the constant blackmail of the Council to decide our budgetary fate. They are also very important because that is what makes it possible to have a fair tax system. And the Council's refusal of the financial transaction tax is an extremely serious political fault. During this period of crisis, the richest continued to enrich themselves through the financialization of the economy and speculation. This tax on financial transactions would have been a means of bringing tax justice to the level of the Union, and the Council refused to do so. A final word to say that I also regret that the Commission has not been at Parliament's side enough to carry our positions. Yet it is his responsibility to do so.

name: Derk Jan EPPINK
text: Mr President, the European budget is EUR 1 233 billion for seven years, plus 25%, if we think the British are thinking away. The compromise between the Council and the European Parliament amounts to a further EUR 16 billion. And now there is also a recovery fund of 750 billion euros: the sky is the limit. Who's going to pay for that? (Noise) (Address Mr Verhofstadt) I can't quite hear you with a mask on. The Americans? (Address to the Chairman) Mr President, can This interruption be deducted from my time by Mr Verhofstadt? Who's going to pay for that, Mr Verhofstadt? European citizens, through European taxes. A list of these taxes has already been made: plastic tax, emissions trading tax, digital taxation on financial transactions, etc. However, all of these will prove insufficient if we have to start paying back the EUR 750 billion in 2028. Do you know what will happen then, Mr Verhofstadt? Then new debts are created and we get a debt carousel. The European Union will become a debt union, thanks in part to you, Commissioner Hahn, this budget may be called NextGenerationEU, but DebtGenerationEU seems more appropriate to me. We are going to shower future generations with debt. I think that is irresponsible and therefore i am voting against it.

name: Sira REGO
text: – Mr President, we are approaching the final stretch of this budget, of this political instrument that will determine our lives in the coming years. And while it has positive aspects, such as the reversal of cuts in educational programmes or research, we are also concerned that it will continue to devote an immense amount of money to the militarisation of the EU, too much money to Frontex. Having said that this is not our ideal proposal, perhaps it is time to have the debate on how to manage it. In my view, it is clear: we must do everything we can to ensure democratic control; ensuring the strengthening of public services and employment so that no one is vulnerable either because of a pandemic or lack of work; make resources work to regain productive sovereignty with public control. If something has shown us pandemic, it is our weakness: in the EU not a single acetaminophen is manufactured. But above all, don't kid ourselves. If we let the austericidal rules sneak through the slits, as the right wants, and if we do not provide social conditionality and a fair distribution, those who from their seats spit out their project of hatred for Europe will win.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: Mr President, in the Lower House of the Dutch Parliament, Prime Minister Rutte has explicitly referred to the European Parliament as the institution which will hopefully improve a number of things with regard to the European Summit on the MFK. The Prime Minister has therefore called on the European Parliament to improve a number of things, because he did not achieve this at the European summit itself. Since the Dutch Prime Minister has been less positive about the European Parliament in the past, I would like to say: please do, Mark. The European Parliament has indeed made a number of important improvements. For example, in the area of the rule of law, where the rule of law mechanism has finally been established with a broader scope and with the provision that the Council cannot delay decisions forever. I would also like to mention a number of other things, including the additional resources for research. If we want to improve our economy structurally, we desperately need research and innovation. The increase in Horizon 2020 is therefore very welcome in this context. I would also like to raise the issue of the protection of external borders. I predict that the Member States that made huge cuts to the external borders budget at the summit will ask why Europe is not doing anything during the next migration crisis. So do parties such as Mr Eppink's. If you want Europe to act, you have to give Europe the means to act. Finally, I would like to draw attention to health, and in particular to the increase in the health budget, which was only logical in the midst of the current pandemic. I would therefore like to thank my colleagues who have done this.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – [Beginning of speech off-microphone] ... negotiators struck last week was not even dry, when the Minister of Justice of Hungary made her verdict public: she defined the rule of law conditionality as a political blackmailing tool. Indeed, the statement is in stark contrast to the open cheering of Prime Minister Orbán after the European Council in July. To me, this was a good sign that spoke volumes, and with a clear trademark on it. While this Parliament has no role in triggering the new mechanism, without this House there would be no strong conditionality between the EU budget and respect for the rule of law and fundamental rights. This was a red line for my group. Our negotiators fought to the end with the Council, and with success. The agreement reached last Thursday makes me proud to be a Member of this Parliament. Being determined and firm, we achieved something unique and something that is there to stay.
