We now have a real, effective and enforceable tool to stand up against autocratic leaders trying to take down our democracies and blackmailing our Union. We can finally put an end to leaders enriching themselves, their friends and their relatives with EU money. We created a smart mechanism to make sure the EU budget ends up in the hands of the people who it is meant for. As Parliament, we kept our promise. We did not give in on our core democratic principles, and the empty bluff of autocratic leaders in panic will no longer hold the EU hostage. We are ready to adopt the agreement and to get started on an ambitious EU budget we have agreed on for the next seven years. Now it is up to the Commission and the EU leaders to make use of this, too. This historic agreement is important for all those Europeans striving hard through crisis and the pandemic, making sacrifices every single day, and bad news for corrupt leaders trying to take advantage of it.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: – Mr President, the word ‘historic’ has been used, I think, 100 times here in this plenary but for once, I think, we are using it in the right way, because my impression is that exactly 20 years after the launch of the Convention, this is a real big step. Why is this a big step? Because we are in fact breaking three long-standing taboos in Europe. The first taboo was no eurobonds, no recovery bonds – that was impossible. That was the call of the Council and of everybody after the financial crisis. And what we will do now with this programme is launch nearly one trillion of these bonds on the market, and the first bond that has been launched is a huge success. The second new thing we are doing concerns own resources. I have heard for years ‘no, it’s impossible to have new own resources’ – for 10 years we have fought for that. It’s there and it’s not taxing the ordinary citizen, it’s taxing Google, Amazon, the big tech companies in America, imported products from China, which are in fact bad for our environment, and so on. So I don’t know what Mr Eppink has against taxing Google and Facebook and Amazon – who is against it? Not the citizens, anyway. And then there is the fact that there will no longer be money for authoritarians. But I want to give two short warnings. The first is to the Commission. Mr Hahn, tell your colleagues to use now the tools. I hear already in the corridors, ‘now we going to use this and we’re going to try to find out if Hungary and Poland are in accordance with the system’... but you have to do nothing at all, that has already been proved! You have now to use it and not wait two or three years before doing it. And my second warning is this: let’s not stop the reform of the European Union. There are other things to tackle: the lack of a European Defence Community, the unanimity rule, and the fact that we cannot elect our own leader. In America they can do it – not always easily – but we cannot do it.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Mr President, it is happening in the US, it is happening here in Europe, it is happening all around the globe. Authoritarian leaders are trying to destroy the basic principles and the very foundations of our democracies. Donald Trump does not want to accept the outcome of a democratic election. Viktor Orbán is threatening to veto the EU budget over the rule of law conditionality.  Some people might think, oh well, if we just back off a little bit, if we just try to see this from their perspective a little bit more, it might all turn out to be a big misunderstanding. Well, here’s the thing – it is not! This is not just a misunderstanding. These guys, they mean it. They are planning to undermine our democracy, our values, by spreading baseless conspiracy theories, by scapegoating minorities, by erasing all checks and balances we have built in hard-won battles over the centuries. This is on, and it is on now. That’s why we need to use every tool we have available in order to stand up to these attacks. The rule of law conditionality is not just a side note in these budgetary negotiations, it is a precondition. Without it, the European Parliament is not going to accept this budget. Lastly, you can threaten us, Mr Orbán. You can try to intimidate us. You can send your trolls after us. We in this Parliament are not going to be afraid of you. We have the backing of hundreds of millions of EU citizens with whom we stand side by side in the battle for rule of law, for democracy and for our rights. It is on and we are in it.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: Before we proceed with the discussions, I will begin today's voting period. We will vote on the dossiers as indicated on the agenda. The voting period will take place between 17:00 and 18:15. Voting is carried out according to the same procedure used during the last part-sessions. All votes will be held by roll-call vote and Members will be able to verify their votes and the results of the votes by consulting the document to be published on the plenary website. Written explanations of vote may be submitted. Exceptionally, only explanations of vote with a maximum of 400 words will be accepted. I declare the voting period open. You can vote by 6:15. The results of the votes will be communicated by 21h.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: We are now continuing the debate on the Multiannual Financial Framework (including own resources), the Rule of Law Conditionality Mechanism and the Recovery Fund for Europe [2020/2858(RSP)].

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Mr President, Europe is much more than the European economy. This agreement that we approve today is a good proof of this.  For Boris Johnson or Donald Trump, Europe was just a market to compete against. They were wrong. Europe is its values and principles, against which competition cannot be enjoyed. Without its values and principles, Europe is nothing. That is why today we put the rule of law before the market.  Today we create a mechanism on the rule of law that will enshrine in this continent that principles and values always lead to the market. It is born with the confidence not to be used, because what it seeks is not to punish anyone, but to protect us all. It is our alarm in the face of authoritarianism; it aims to protect us from present or future temptations of those who abuse power and pretends that those who order what to say and what to think, what is true and what is not, do not dare to do so because they find punishment.  Nationalpulism, like all viruses, does not discriminate by frontier, race or gender. Look, if not, what's going on in the United States of America, where the strongest, most stable and uninterrupted democracy in 250 years hasn't been able to stop its acting president from accepting an election result.  If what Donald Trump is doing was done by the president of another American country, the US Congress would already be talking about sanctions. That is what this mechanism is all about: putting democracy before the economy.  The rule of law is respect for the equality of men and women; it is respect for diversity, for religious, educational freedom; respect for freedom of expression, freedom of the press, independence from justice. All of that is more important than the market.  This rule of law mechanism is not born against anyone; born to defend us all. If any country contraviates it, even if it is mine, it must be sanctioned.

name: Elisabetta GUALMINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are celebrating the great success we have achieved in recent days in approving the multiannual budget, the reform of own resources and the European Recovery Fund, but above all we are celebrating the strength of the European Parliament, the role it has played with determination, a role that is not at last subordinate or small in relation to the Council. And the result was: 16 billion more, for a total of about 1 800 billion for this multiannual budget. But it is not just the figures and the quantity that count, there are two other aspects that I would like to highlight. The first is the system logic that has been used for the first time, I would say revolutionary: the multiannual framework has been approved together with the revision of own resources and we can finally ask for heavy contributions from the multinationals of the web, we can ask polluting companies not to do it again and to pay taxes, if by chance they do and do not help us in the fight against climate change. The review of own resources will enable us, in a package-specific way, to finance the NextGenerationEU. This had never happened, they are extraordinary answers to gigantic needs. In fact, we cannot be small when the demands are enormous, we cannot back down when colossal demands arrive. The second element is the relationship between the budget and democracy: the budget is the beating heart of democracies, it is the way in which we explain to our citizens what we do and how we do it. We need a healthy, clean and transparent EU budget to make it clear where we are going; we need an ambitious budget to prevent this devastating crisis from spreading. As Kamala Harris, the first female Vice President elected in the United States, put it: "dream with ambition, live with conviction". We will do so and we will do so on behalf of our citizens.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Mr President, let me start by congratulating the negotiating team of the European Parliament: you’ve done a fantastic job, and it cannot be said enough. I note that the Council is absent, which is strange because they are the other half of the agreement, but apparently they don’t care. And there is a contrast between the attitude of the Council and Parliament. Colleagues, do you remember the scenes of last summer, the balcony scenes, where they were fighting like cats and dogs over money, where there were political games, where there were vetoes, blackmail, and acrimony? It was the worst of the European Union, the image that they showed the citizens. Compare that to today. The European Parliament has a lot less drama than the Council, but we deliver, we deliver on change. We made a qualitative change. We deliver on the rule of law. We deliver on climate. We deliver on recovery from the COVID crisis. The European Parliament has done its job, as always. We take responsibility. On the rule of law conditionality, I’m very happy that we have the mechanism, but now we also expect the European Commission to act on it. And we need to remember that this is about conditionality, it’s not a sanctions mechanism. That means that every single penny that will be spent has to be checked against compliance with the rule of law standards. Every single penny! So don’t come here and say ‘oh, we first have to investigate and see if everybody complies’ – we know what the situation is, so act. Finally, I think the situation with Mr Orbán shows that we desperately need to change the system. It cannot be that a single autocrat is holding the entire European Union hostage. It is taxpayers’ money that we are talking about, and this should not be for Mr Orbán to determine. This is for the democratically elected representatives of the European people.

name: Daniel FREUND
text: – Mr President, you might have noticed that two governments – Hungary and Poland – are fuming since last Thursday, since we struck this historic deal on the rule of law conditionality. The Polish minister has been speaking of political, cultural and economic colonisation, and Hungary goes a step further, as always, and speaks of the execution of the Soros plan. What a bizarre fantasy land these people live in. Hungary and Poland are among the biggest recipients of EU funds. They have profited to the tune of EUR 180 billion of European solidarity since they acceded to the European Union and now, at this moment, where millions of citizens, where thousands of businesses need a lifeline from us and are expecting European solidarity, this is the moment that they threaten to block the whole package, because Kaczyński wants to continue to throw out judges that he doesn’t like and because Orbán wants to keep lining his own pockets. I think one thing is pretty obvious: that those that are screaming the loudest now about this are the ones that have to fear the most from this new conditionality. Just last night, the Hungarian minister, as some colleagues have referred to, has put forward new constitutional changes that would make it impossible for the opposition to run in a coordinated fashion. In Poland, we have an ECJ ruling that this so—called disciplinary chamber should cease to exist, but it continues to operate and to put judges out of work. For years we have seen how the situation is deteriorating. Commissioner Hahn, I was recently in Hungary. I visited Klub Radio, which is about to lose its frequency – the last independent radio station in Hungary. There are thousands of people in Poland on the street because they lost the independence of the judiciary. These citizens do not have the time to wait. They don’t have the time to wait for another rule of law report, another dialogue, we need to act. When this enters into force on 1 January, we don’t have a minute to lose, it’s time to act.

name: Jessica STEGRUD
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr It is good that Parliament and the other Swedish parties, as well as we, want to raise the requirements for the rule of law in order to receive EU subsidies. The strange thing is that they do not at the same time demand economic reform, budgetary discipline and corruption measures; that you want to give money so casually and undemandingly to states that have mismanaged their economies in good times; that you are now prepared to introduce new taxes and put in debt future generations; that you want to spend thousands of billions on ill-conceived climate action, which the Commission itself admits will not be enough or have any decisive impact on the global climate. You talk warmly about trade, the internal market, environmental cooperation and security. At the same time, you are spending money on completely different things and taking the opportunity to move even more power to Brussels, ever further and further away from the individual citizens. Europe is talking about a Coperian revolution, and it certainly is, but not a revolution that liberates anyone, not one that builds something for the future or solves any problems.

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: – Mr President. The Recovery and Resilience Fund can greatly help the European economy. If we spend money well and invest in projects that will move us the most out of all available alternatives, this will be a unique opportunity to increase economic growth in Europe in a leap. However, the Recovery and Resilience Fund also carries significant risks. There is a risk of pushing the private sector and a more efficient part of the economy to the margins, the so-called Dutch disease, and there is a risk of increased corruption. Instead of discussing how much of the expenditure of the Recovery and Resilience Fund is allocated to the individual sectors that are currently in vogue, we should go back to what we talked about at the beginning. Flexible conditions for Member States to invest in repayable reforms aimed at economic growth.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. We are discussing a very broad package here today, including the building fund. This week, on Monday, in the Committee on Budgets and in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, we have finalised the votes on this issue and are now ready to negotiate this package with the Council.  I am pleased that we have managed to reach a common broad approach here in the European Parliament. I do not want to hide the fact that there are, of course, a few downsides in this dossier. Of course, it was our task to bring into this programme what the Heads of State or Government did not do, namely to create European added value. However, while the Heads of State or Government have said that this must also be conditional, there was a large group here, namely the Social Democrats, which said: no, there must be no conditions. Not even the conditions that we now have in the Structural Funds regulation, not even the conditions that we have for other support programmes, the only one is the rule of law, but I will come back to that in a while. That is why, ladies and gentlemen, anyone who sees this aid fund only as a money-saving bank, where it is easy to withdraw but does not have to meet conditions – this is not our world, and I hope that this can still be corrected in the negotiations with the Council.  Ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about the rule of law and we are pleased that we have adopted a mechanism in a plenary that violates its own Rules of Procedure, that violates its own legal bases, that violates the Statute of Members, which violates the law on Members' privileges, to name only a few points. We should start applying Rule of Law again in our own house. Then we can also point the finger at other parliaments.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Today is a good day for the European Union and it is a very successful day for the European Parliament. After all, after many citizens were sceptical at the beginning of the pandemic that the EU had been doing too little too slowly, we are now proving that there is a cross-border, a European, powerful response to this pandemic – in the interests of the citizens. I am sure that this will increase confidence in the EU.  But another point, or one that is included in it, is even more existential for confidence in the European Union. For the EU's acceptance has long suffered from the fact that there are governments in Member States that have distanced themselves from the soil of common values. Here, too, we are sending a powerful signal with the conditionality of the rule of law. The most important signal is that all Member States are equally committed to the values of Article 2. No Member State can claim to have its own interpretation of these values. We know the situation, some governments are probably confusing rule of law with rule by law. They believe that because they have a majority, they can do and leave what they want, make the judiciary dependent on themselves, subjugate the media, curtail the rights of the opposition, thus making any democratic control impossible. It is good that the EU is sending out a signal.  I am particularly grateful that the full scope of Article 2 is covered, that the Copenhagen criteria are also mentioned and that the preventive nature of the mechanism is emphasised. United in diversity – yes, we can all shape our systems differently, but we are all on the ground under Article 2, and at the end of the day we decide what the rule of law means, and that is the European Court of Justice. And what was particularly important to social democracy is that in the end it is not the recipients of the grant, the recipients, not the towns and municipalities, the companies, the cultural workers, the students, the research institutions, but the governments that are sanctioned. The money must reach the beneficiaries, and the Commission must ensure that. It hasn't become what we wanted, it's not ideal. There is still much to criticise, but overall it is a great success, a good day for the European Union and a successful day for Parliament.

name: Sandro GOZI
text: Mr President, we have not given up, and we have been right. Congratulations to the European Parliament negotiators. Some in the capitals said that Parliament should go backwards, be silent and quickly accept the Council's agreement, as early as July. They were wrong. Today, some, such as Mr Orbon, are again threatening to block this agreement. They are wrong, and we know it is a bluff. We have an economic recovery budget, of course, but also a more citizen budget: for our youth with Erasmus, for our health with EU for Health. A more credible commitment, with a clear timetable for new own resources. A fairer union that ultimately gives itself the means to prevent and punish violations of the rule of law. Let us repeat it and proudly advocate it: no European funds to those who violate European values. As has been said, the clearest way to show what the rule of law means to us is to remember what happened when there was no rule of law in Europe. In Europe, we can no longer tolerate this. The union was born to guarantee our freedoms. You cannot be European when it comes to receiving billions of euros, and find yourself a nationalist when it comes to respecting the fundamental rights of Article 2 of the Treaty. For us, we have to succeed. This is an obligation of result for the Commission and for the Council. You must follow through on all your commitments and we will remind you of them until the last day of this Parliament. And there is still a priority, Mr President, for which we are waiting for the Council. Keep your commitment. Let's start the conference on the future of Europe. It is a question of credibility. The citizens are waiting for us.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Mr President, the truth is that the Council intended for months and weeks to bring it to the side of the European Parliament. You can't touch anything in the July agreement. Well, today we have made substantial changes, and they are to be thankful and, above all, citizens will thank them: EUR 3.5 billion more for health programmes; EUR 4 billion more for research , although insufficient, is an important step forward; 35% more funding for culture. These are all issues that citizens will note thanks to the action of the European Parliament, and that is good news.  And a clear timetable for own resources. Valérie Hayer has said this before: we don't have a new self-appeal since customs duties more than fifty years ago. Let's introduce the tax on financial transactions. Let's introduce the digital tax. All with a clear calendar. We would have liked a more ambitious, closer timetable, but it is certainly a step forward. And a mechanism of linkage with the rule of law, which is an essential mechanism for those who use and receive European funds to not be able to break fundamental rules. This, of course, is not the agreement we wanted as a whole, but it is a very important step forward given what was on the Council table and what Parliament has achieved. Secondly, this Parliament, this week too, is going to give its go-ahead to the position on the Recovery Fund for Europe, and it is very important what Parliament will say and say this week. We don't want economic macro-conditionality. We do not want European Semester reforms to be imposed that have nothing to do with the mechanism. We want ambitious climate targets that do not spend money on polluting activities. Parliament will say this and I hope and wish the Council to listen to us in the negotiations we will begin.  We are at a very important time for the European Union. We will double the amount of resources available by the European institutions. We will leave behind the era of austerity to move to a more investment-focused time. We have moved forward and broken taboos, such as the Eurobonds. I believe that this is a package that, seen in historical perspective, is a big step forward.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, I don't know if you can hear me, I hope you can hear me. I would like to make a note to the Presidency - this way of functioning of the European Parliament is, to put it mildly, inappropriate. But I would like to point out that once again we are discussing the multiannual financial framework, with which we are very much likeable, Chairman, to the plethenums of the old Soviet Union.  The biggest, undeniably, is the lack of any economic logic in this conversation we are having. The European Commission and, by the way, the left majority in the chamber, it is quite Bolshevik, support economic suicide, called the Green Deal. At this point, we should be thinking about how to save our economies, not relying on ueds, on green ingests, President. I know you're smiling, I see you're smiling, but it's a utopia, and you'il understand sooner or later. The same can be said of the so-called "next generation". Dear President, colleagues, we will either wake up and look at things as they are, or we will crash like the Soviet Union. I see you have white hair, you probably remember the Soviet Union, you'il see what happens. Thank you.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I am very grateful to colleagues who have negotiated hard over the last few weeks. On many issues with European added value for our citizens, we have created additional opportunities: the Horizon Europe research programme will receive EUR 4 billion more, the Erasmus exchange programme EUR 2 billion more, the EU4Health health programme EUR 3 billion more, for better protection of the common external border, for the rule of law and European values, for arts and culture around EUR 1 billion more – just to name a few examples.  I hope that the European Commission, the Member States and, above all, the citizens, have the strength and the ideas to use this money wisely. But have we really received sufficient funding from the Member States to ensure that the European Union is sufficiently future-proof in terms of the common foreign and security policy, in external border protection, in research and development and in the fight against human content in climate change? I have my doubts about that.  We also have specific demands for the building fund to ensure that the money from the Member States does not go to the maintenance of old structures, but can actually be invested in the common future of our European continent. Please allow me to make one more comment, which several members have asked me to make: all the national parliaments in Europe are meeting, and the Belgian Parliament even just a few days ago here in our Chamber. And we Members of the European Parliament should stay at home! We all know that parliamentarianism is much more than reading out opinions, it is much more than electronic participation in meetings, and it is much more than participation in votes and elections. The request is therefore: please ensure, with the highest possible hygiene measures, that Members who wish to and can come to Brussels can also attend all meetings in accordance with the usual rules. And please comply with the rules of procedure, for example here in plenary today, please ensure that those present today can, as usual, also document their presence under Rule 156, thereby creating legal certainty.

name: Eero HEINÄLUOMA
text: – Mr President, the agreement reached last night is historic in nature. It gives cause for satisfaction and it is easy to support the solution that has now emerged. The agreement on a seven-year European Union budget, as agreed now, will take forward the really necessary good things. Universities and research will receive more money, young people's exchange programmes will also be safeguarded, and more resources will also be put into monitoring the Borders of the European Union. It is also important that we now have an agreement on the EU's own resources. It will safeguard the EU budget for the next few years and will also allow us to finance a large recovery fund. And the most important thing is that this money comes in a way that is fairness in taxation and does not mean interfering in the taxes of the Member States. For example, the EU's carbon border tariff is something that will certainly receive broad support.  But what is particularly historic about this solution is the agreement on the rule of law. For the first time, we have reached an agreement that the use of EU funds will be conditional on the inviolability of the budget and the rule of law. It is therefore significant that, in future, the condition for access to the EU's own resources will be respect for fundamental principles of the rule of law. It means a judiciary and a free press. I will support this solution and I believe that this will receive very broad approval in Finland.

name: Ramona STRUGARIU
text: – Mr President, the first word that I have in mind about this agreement is gratitude – gratitude to the representatives of the Council, to the Commission, to my colleagues, to our teams, to every one of you who made this possible under extremely difficult circumstances. Now this truly means delivering to the people for their safer and better future, and I would like to thank you for that. My second thought goes to the role the European Parliament and my Group – Renew Europe – had in defending the rule of law and European values along this process, and we will continue to defend it and keep an eye on the Commission and on the Council to fulfil their commitments as well, because we are defending the mere essence of the European project, the mere essence of democracy. This is the reason that we are stepping into this House every day, doing our work and we are defending the hope of millions of people along with it. I’m so proud to be part of the political family who is writing history in such a way. My third thought goes to those political leaders who are not so happy with this agreement, who actually stated out loud that they are preparing to veto it, like Mr Orbán. It is a proven fact that those marching against history written by visionary people usually end up in a very cold, unfriendly and insignificant quarter of such a history, and I would like you to think very, very well whether you want to end up like this or not, because the European project and the world moves forward, with or without you. We are pushing it forward, with or without you. Long live Europe!

name: Alexandra GEESE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the This budget package represents a living European solidarity with the countries most affected by COVID, but also of solidarity between generations, because we are investing a large part of this package in climate protection, but finally also solidarity with the people most affected by the crisis, namely women. Parliament's position on the Building Fund calls for clear equality checks, which show the impact of the individual measures and projects on women and men.  I call on all governments to stand up for women in the Council and to support this demand. I also very much welcome the fact that, for the first time, the Commission will now develop a methodology for a gender-sensitive EU budget, which we will have from 2023. Finally, the rule of law mechanism: I hope that this important instrument can support the women who have been most committed to fundamental rights in Europe in recent weeks, that is, women in Poland. Women of Europe, women of Poland, we have your back!

name: Patryk JAKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The only treaty procedure for the rule of law is Article 7. And you know that very well. The problem is that you have not been able to find a majority to trigger Article 7, so you have come up with a non-treaty procedure, thus breaking the law, as even your own legal opinions and those of the European Court of Auditors have confirmed. Secondly, the sphere of education and culture, the redistribution of resources and the organisation of the judiciary under the Treaty falls within the exclusive competence of the Member State and the Poles. You are also trying to appropriate this competence, that is, in fact, when you talk about the rule of law, you are breaking the rule of law yourself. And it is already symbolic that the German Presidency is attacking Poland m.in on the Independence Day of the Polish State. It is really a huge shame, especially since the politicisation of the courts is being talked about by The Germans, who have the most politicised process of selecting judges throughout the European Union.

name: Kris PEETERS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the fact that yesterday we reached an agreement on the multiannual budget and the recovery plan is not only good news in these difficult times, but is indeed even historic. The agreement should enable us to rebuild Europe after the COVID–19 crisis and make the EU even better to better secure the future of our citizens and businesses. In short, the agreement means more money for research and development, more money for European health challenges and better protection of the rule of law. Research and development funding will be significantly increased by EUR 4 billion. This is good for Europe and for the Member States, including Belgium and in particular for the Belgian land of Flanders. The funds are distributed according to the principle of excellence and Flemish research institutes and companies usually participate in these project calls with great success: about 2.6% of European research and development funds flow to Flanders. In addition, the European budget for health challenges is tripled. It will serve for reserve supplies of medical supplies and for cross-border teams of health workers. The current crisis has shown that European solidarity can actually save lives. However, the principle of 'what, what is' applies: Member States wishing to use European resources in the future will have to demonstrate that they are a rule of law with freedom of the press and independent courts. This is how we protect Europe's democratic values. My congratulations to everyone who made this agreement possible.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, for forty years, this European Parliament has been the only directly elective institution of the Union's architecture. And in 2019—his last election—for the first time, during all this time, voter turnout, rather than declining, bounced back strongly, increasing, even not knowing that we were aaphing in the worst crisis in history: the pandemic and its economic and social havoc.  Well, to all those who went to the polls even with skepticism and doubt, the message this afternoon is very clear. Here is proof that the European Parliament matters. With a historic achievement, for the first time it has managed to double the firepower of the multiannual financial framework, the Recovery Fund and all the instruments to ensure the necessary funding for education, innovation, culture. But the Council's proposal has also increased the Council's proposal by EUR 16 billion. It has achieved a binding proposal for own resources, with new tax figures to finance the Europe we need, and the conditionality of the rule of law, which obliges Member States to comply with democracy, the rule of law and the separation of powers if they want access to European funds. And they can't procrastinate, because they have to make a decision. At the same time, the beneficiaries of these decisions and those European funds are protected.  This Parliament has therefore made a historic achievement by fulfilling it as a budgetary authority and as an engine of democratic legitimacy of the Union. 440 million citizens can feel represented in this European Parliament and, above all, in the hope of the response they need as soon as possible.  Thank you to the negotiators who have made this possible, because this Parliament has made this answer possible so that it can reach them immediately, as soon as possible.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Mr President, two recent events give us hope. And among them, first, the European Union's response to the dramatic economic and financial consequences of the current health crisis.  Our three institutions involved in the legislative process have just demonstrated that we can leave behind the obstacles that once made it impossible to make the progress that we will soon approve. The second factor of change is the new U.S. administration that will be put in place, with a return to correct reports: is it not going to change anything? For the optimist that I am, it will change everything: international cooperation, multilateralism - badly damaged, alas - and the fight against climate change are once again becoming real perspectives.  Good news for us, good news because the gravediggers of our fundamental values, the enemies of a free press, as well as the friends of a justice at the boot of the ruling party, have just lost a major ally in the fight against European integration. The decision to introduce a compliance clause is timely. Recipients of European funds will now have to comply with the commitments to which they themselves have signed up. Good start for the new decade, good start for the Commission which will have to apply this clause with great skill, a lot of talent and a lot of perseverance. So it all depends on our institutions, and on the front line of our Commission, to make this achievement sustainable. "I hope it lasts," Napoleon's mother said, and I hope this time she'll be right.

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Almost three years ago, the Article 7 procedure was triggered for the first time, and this is Polish. Since then, we have had many debates on the link between the rule of law and the budget, we have adopted many resolutions, and there have been further violations in Poland and Hungary. The principles of judicial independence and media freedom were violated, women's rights, LGBT plus rights were violated, civil society was destroyed, natural areas were destroyed. The Polish and Hungary will block this mechanism because violations of the rule of law are part of their political DNA. Now it is important not to end up with words. The Union must protect citizens and citizens, not governments.  Today in Poland we celebrate Independence Day. I dream that yesterday's agreement will become a symbol of the European Union's struggle for the independence of the citizens of the Union and their protection from governments that are violating the rule of law.

name: Niclas HERBST
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Ladies and gentlemen, you have the advantage of speaking so late that everything has already been said and you can be brief. I suspect, however, that the ladies and gentlemen who were directly involved in the negotiations are mentally stable in such a way that you too can tolerate some praise from me. So a heartfelt thank you to all those who were directly involved! However, I would like to take this opportunity to point out that we are not there yet – on the home straight, yes, but there is still much to be done. It has already been mentioned several times that in the next few days we will see the issue of rule of law again from the outside, that we have to show what we have shown as a Parliament and why we have been so successful, namely unity and self-confidence. We will have to be united and self-confident in order to fend off these attacks, and that will continue to be the case for the next few years. I will just mention the issue of own resources. The issue is not through, but it will continue into the next parliamentary term for us to pursue this issue. Here, too, we must be self-confident and united.  And let's not fool ourselves, we're at a real fork in the road. We, as the European Union, are taking on debt for the first time, and that has what it takes to change the European Union as a whole. This needs discussion, not from a few, but from the whole of Parliament. That is why I also expect the President to have this debate in this important situation that we are in right now and to reconsider this restrictive approach. We must now be able to work here in Parliament – and I expect this from the President – namely, united and self-confident. We must also conduct this public discourse, because there is no point in patting each other on the back. We have achieved this success not for ourselves, but for the citizens of Europe. And we need to make that much clearer.

name: Leszek MILLER
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would like to express my satisfaction with the agreement on the Union budget, which, among other things, provides EUR 15 billion more for science, health and education. I am equally positive about the compromise proposal for a regulation linking EU funds to the rule of law, which means strengthening the values on which our Union is built.  The conditionality mechanism is not an attack on the sovereignty of any Member State. The possibility of suspending funds is only a temporary measure which can be quickly restored if the State concerned returns to the path of respect for the law and principles on which the Union is founded. This mechanism is not aimed at the interests of the citizens of the Member States, but at the policies of governments that act against their own citizens. Therefore, tools that, if necessary, will enable the financing of projects by citizens, local governments and NGOs directly from the European Commission through the central government.  I hope that in the way we continue to work, all governments will retain responsibility, become adults and make an understanding of the compromise arrangements. This also applies to the Polish Government.

name: Marie TOUSSAINT
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the ecological crisis does not stop with the health crisis. On the contrary, all crises are linked. They come from an unfair and destructive economic and development model. In the face of the pandemic, mobilizing funds for recovery was essential. But the urgency must not condemn the future. Our investments are shaping the future, we need to reorient our economy to ensure both social justice and the protection of our planet. If we want to save the climate and achieve carbon neutrality, as we have pledged, not a public euro should be allocated to fossil fuels. It is simple, it is clear, and that is the position we are defending. But being an environmental parliamentarian often means having to deal with political majorities trapped in the short term. So once again, we have fought the battle to clearly exclude fossil fuels from this recovery facility and we have only got gas not listed as a transitional energy. It is time to go further and take the radical decisions that are needed, otherwise the climate crisis will produce words far worse than those we face today.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for the work he has First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks to all those who have taken part in these really successful negotiations. I believe that it is an important step for the European Union in this crisis, and we could only achieve this step – as Mr Herbst has just said – because we were united and self-confident.  And today's debate shows that, of course, we will need this unity and self-confidence in the coming weeks, too, in the coming weeks, so that we can keep the Member States – 27 in number – all in line, whether on the subject of the rule of law, whether on the issue of own resources or on the issue of increasing the EU budget. But this unity and self-confidence, Mr President, wins an assembly like this – we have learned this several times in history – as a democracy from the demos. We do not live in a video cracy, and that is why it is important that we retain the opportunity to meet here, under special security regulations and to a lesser extent, even in the crisis. That is why the debate today is important.  When Mr Aguilar of the Socialists points out here that we represent forty-four million people, he is of course also doing so in order to make it clear that if we stick together, if we stand together and confidently, we will achieve precisely this objective: to give the citizens of Europe an understanding that we want to show solidarity and that the budget is an expression of this solidarity.  Mr President, I would like to add, however, that the European Parliament has always seen itself as a supporter of the Commission, particularly in the budgetary field, in this crisis, but we have never had the impression that we are there to finance the Member States. That is why, on the one hand, when monitoring the EUR 750 billion in the Recovery and Resilience Instrument, we are asking for real control that these funds are also spent at European level and do not serve as a kind of money-saving account for Member States' budgets. Secondly, in the budgetary field too, our core principle remains that we defend the fundamental values of the European Union and do not make ourselves willing helpers of the Member States.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Mr President, this second wave of the pandemic has made it clear that the consequences for our economy and our well-being are far more serious than expected, and that is why this agreement is so important. The word 'historic' has been dropped several times today and we have indeed taken historic steps. For more than 30 years, we have been fighting for the European Union's own income. We have ensured that more resources are allocated to research and development and that 30% is spent on climate and 10% on biodiversity to secure our sustainable future. The rule of law mechanism also ensures that money can only be spent in the Union if European values are also respected. There is a view on a vaccine and that offers perspective. The same applies to these investments. We should not put profit first when investing, but well-being. If we have learned anything from this pandemic, it is not that profit increases well-being, but that welfare is a huge gain for European citizens and businesses.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Dear Chairman, I congratulate first and foremost all those who contributed to the agreement on the new budget yesterday and the rule of law control mechanism last week. I commend the excellent cooperation of pro-European groups. This strengthened our position, despite political pressure at the end of the negotiations. I expect unanimous support from the Council to make the funds available as soon as possible.  Parliament has finally been respected as a co-legislature. With a direct mandate from citizens, our proposals allow transparent use of funds. This will allow for the sustainable recovery and development of the Union. Thanks to proposals from the Socialists and Democrats, this budget is more sustainable and greener and more socially just. Research and education envelopes have been increased. A total of nine programmes will receive more money than agreed by the Council. Nevertheless, I particularly want to highlight the rule of law as a control mechanism. As important as the amount of money available to citizens through funds is, it is even more important that this money is used in line with citizens' expectations. Our values and the rights of our citizens have no price, and governments that threaten them must also be held financially accountable.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Ladies and gentlemen, what we are witnessing at the moment is nothing less than a turning point, a turning point for more solidarity, for more mutual help and for more sustainability. And that's a good thing. The decisions of the last few days are a milestone along this road. Yes, we have what it takes in the European Union. We have the resources to emerge stronger from this terrible crisis. However, ladies and gentlemen, please allow me to look at the places in the world that we are far too rarely looking at. Let us not just remain in a Eurocentric view. Europe is only so strong, as much as we manage to get on our feet in Latin America, In Africa, in Asia. And I am grateful to the negotiating team for the fact that the funds for humanitarian aid and development policy have not been underthe radar here, but have even been increased. I appeal to you, that must be the spirit in this House, even in the coming months and years: we must look to our partner countries, and we ourselves must ensure that we are able to act globally. That is our task, including in the European Parliament.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Mr President, the European Parliament has reached a historic agreement on the future European budget: EUR 1.8 trillion for the priorities of European citizens.  Our political group has called for and achieved a tripling of the budget for the health programme, an increase in funding for education and youth by EUR 2.2 billion, an increase in the research budget by EUR 4 billion and similar increases for programmes in the field of culture, digitalisation, infrastructure, agriculture and entrepreneurship.  Our political family will continue to fight for a sustainable economic recovery and an effective response to the new challenges posed by the pandemic and technological developments.  It is central to getting these financial resources to beneficiaries as soon as possible and to start programmes as soon as possible in all Member States. In Romania, European resources are the solution for economic recovery, in the context of governance unable to properly manage this crisis.  To do this, we must avoid delays and ensure that European money is spent transparently, following consultations with the social partners and civil society in each Member State.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the agreement reached yesterday on the budget is a very important result, a real test of maturity on the part of the European institutions, which have been able to react decisively to the serious threat of the pandemic and its disastrous effects on our society. Reaching an agreement was by no means a foregone conclusion, given the tight deadlines, difficulties and political knots that had to be broken up, especially on the rule of law and own resources. Now, however, between the budget and the recovery plan, we are putting in place almost EUR 2 000 billion of resources, which must be used well and with the right speed. The binding timetable introducing new Union own resources opens a new chapter in the process of European integration, because it will make Europe progressively less and less dependent on the individual contributions of the States. Taxing web giants, speculative financial transactions and major polluters are necessary steps to achieve our objectives, as well as ensuring that in the face of flagrant violations of the rule of law, the disbursement of funds can be blocked. Orbán's negative reaction tells us that we are in the right direction, let me tell you. It is therefore time to give Europe the means to grow up, the time is now and we are there!

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Firstly, as a Hungarian Citizen of Europe, I would like to thank everyone in this House for finally working together to make the payment of EU funds subject to rule of law conditions in the future. For years, Hungarians in Europe have watched their own prime minister's circle steal and steal EU subsidies for Hungarians. Therefore, for us, this new decision, this new rule, is huge, even historical. Secondly, I would like to confirm europe that we made the right decision when we decided to do so. Here is the proof: from yesterday, the Orban government has today submitted, under the cover of night, a constitutional amendment that will make it very much easier to steal public funds in Hungary, while at the same time starting a unilateral one-party overhaul and revision of electoral law. Orban showed everyone in Europe in one night that we made the right decision when we introduced the rule of law condition, because this will be much more necessary in the future than ever before.  We must finally make the Hungarian Prime Minister understand together that he cannot do anything to the Hungarian and European people.

name: Marc ANGEL
text: – [Inaudible] While negotiating the multiannual financial framework and the recovery fund this Parliament stayed strong and didn’t allow itself to be blackmailed by some autocratic governments or by some of the so-called frugal governments. This shows how crucial it is that the European Parliament has its say on the MFF. The concrete roadmap on new own-resources is the merit of this House, and this will allow us and our budget not to rely too heavily on contributions from Member States which would continue to divide our Union into net payers and net receivers. As a member of the S&D Group, I’m especially pleased that own resources like a financial transaction tax and corporate tax base ensure that everybody pays their fair share. Moreover, it was again the European Parliament that insisted on linking European funds to respect for the rule of law and fundamental rights. Still, personally I think this is not enough in its current form, but it is for sure a very good first step to ensure conditionality that after all 70% of all citizens consider to be crucial. This MFF and recovery fund will prevent the European Union from going back to business as usual: on the contrary, it will help the Union to become more resilient, sustainable, gender-balanced and inclusive.

name: Petar VITANOV
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate everyone involved in the negotiations, because yesterday a step towards a more social and solidarity-based Europe was taken. Yes, when compromises are reached, many people make concessions, but yesterday's historic deal ensures that European funds will reach citizens, businesses and regions on time in their fight against the severe consequences of the crown crisis. I also welcome the agreements reached on new own resources and the roadmap for their implementation, because through them the European Union can conduct an independent fiscal policy and not become a hostage to domestic political arithmetic by individual governments. Last but not least, I would like to draw attention to the linking of the rule of law with the financial resources of the European Union. European Union money is citizens' money, it does not serve to replicate a corruption-ridden political class. Finally, I thank all my colleagues in the European Parliament who have stood up for the institution's position in the negotiations. Thank you.

name: Petar VITANOV
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, believe me, today I really appreciated and enjoyed this debate, because it has shown a very broad not only understanding, but in particular support and commitment concerning the next MFF and everything that is related to it. This is extremely helpful in backing our work because we are not yet there. We have found a political agreement which was important, but now it’s about taking the necessary approvals and then of course it’s about implementation, and this was highlighted by several speakers. I think we have really to focus on implementation throughout the seven years, but in particular at the beginning of those seven years, because this is also related to the response to the COVID crisis, where people need our support, where businesses need our support in order to survive and to protect jobs, for instance, which is equally important and therefore I am very grateful for this strong support. By the way, we have also protected and safeguarded the political priorities which we have discussed for many months, if not to say years here in this House, the Green Deal but also digitalisation, and to work together here. I am confident that we can also achieve in due time all the necessary approvals in order really to start working, and to implement what we have discussed, what we have decided and what we have envisaged. I once again thank you and I ask for your further support. I have no doubts. I didn’t have any doubts, and after this discussion have even fewer doubts that we will get the right backing from this Parliament for these very ambitious goals for the next couple of years. Plus, as was said by almost every speaker, it’s about Europe, our citizens and it’s about helping people to overcome this crisis, and to be even stronger afterwards, and this should be our goal. But we should, by the way, not forget our responsibility in the world. This was also highlighted by several speakers. Europe can only be successful, finally, if we are part of a more peaceful, a more cooperative world, and in that respect I think also the recent developments in the United States should give some hope. But on the other hand, we should not overestimate everything, but in general, I think this was and is – it is only Wednesday – a good week for Europe, the world and in particular the citizens.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: The debate, which is so important for the future of the European project and a good example of interinstitutional dialogue, is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – The agreement reached this week with the Council for the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-27, after months of negotiations, is a historic success: for the first time since the Multiannual Financial Framework exists, the European Parliament has managed to increase the amount of money initially agreed by the Council. We have reached an ambitious, progressive and people-centered multiannual budget. We have defended the 15 key EU programmes, and we have ensured that none of its beneficiaries fall outside the new financial framework. In addition, we have achieved funding for the Green Pact and for a fair ecological transition; we have defended people and put the socialist seal on this long-term budget, which is now greener, fairer and more social. In addition, the agreement reached establishes a roadmap for the introduction of new own resources for the European Union, which on the one hand will allow us to finance our programmes, and on the other hand have a fairer taxation, which requires us to pay taxes in Europe on large technology and large multinationals, for the most polluting companies, and those who make financial transactions only for speculation.

name: Adam BIELAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The current Multiannual Financial Framework, also known as the EU's long-term budget, expires in December. The proposals for the Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027 m.in reform of the own resources system to ensure its financing. The Multiannual Financial Framework and the Recovery Plan can allay the effects of the Covid-19 pandemic crisis. The new reconstruction package will provide an investment boost to transform our economies and strengthen their resilience through a combination of strategic investments supporting the small and medium-sized enterprises sector. It should also increase employment opportunities in order to mitigate the impact of the crisis on workers and consumers.  The European Parliament has advocated an increase in the budget for innovative and future-oriented programmes such as Horizon, InvestEU, Erasmus and EU4Health. Budget flexibility has also been increased to allow for an easier EU response to unforeseen needs, and the role of the European Parliament in the area of new sources of revenue for the EU budget has been strengthened. Unfortunately, the success of these negotiations is being tinged by the adoption of so-called conditionality solutions for budget expenditure by proposing non-treaty rules on linking funds to the rule of law. These solutions exceed the protection of the EU's financial interests, becoming an instrument of political, financial and ideological pressure on member state governments that do not follow the eu's mainstream policies. In a context of deep recession in the economies of all EU countries caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, we should not place the political interests of some countries above the economic and social interests of all EU citizens.

name: Sara CERDAS
text: in writing. – After months of negotiations, we finally reached an agreement on the European Union budget, the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for 2021-2027, and the European recovery package "Next Generation EU". The SD group played a key role in these negotiations in pressuring the Council to adopt a people-facing budget. This MFF should ensure that people are a priority. We are living in an unprecedented crisis caused by an unmatched pandemic, so an effective and rapid response is urgently urgent. It is essential that there should be a safeguard in the interests of the different Member States and regions, in particular the outermost regions, given their specificities, but at the same time we must ensure a progressive, ambitious budget focused on the needs of EU citizens. I particularly welcome the increase in the EU4HEALTH health programme budget by 3.4 billion compared to the Council's proposal of EUR 1.7 billion. Health is an investment. For every euro that is invested in public health interventions, there is a return of 14 euros. This is the investment in health that will allow us to achieve greater gains for the health of populations in the long term.

name: Estrella DURÁ FERRANDIS
text: in writing. – The agreement reached this week with the Council for the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-27, after months of negotiations, is a historic success: for the first time since the Multiannual Financial Framework exists, the European Parliament has managed to increase the amount of money initially agreed by the Council. We have reached an ambitious, progressive and people-centered multiannual budget. We have defended the 15 key EU programmes, and we have ensured that none of its beneficiaries fall outside the new financial framework. In addition, we have achieved funding for the Green Pact and for a fair ecological transition; we have defended people and put the socialist seal on this long-term budget, which is now greener, fairer and more social. In addition, the agreement reached establishes a roadmap for the introduction of new own resources for the European Union, which on the one hand will allow us to finance our programmes, and on the other hand have a fairer taxation, which requires us to pay taxes in Europe on large technology and large multinationals, for the most polluting companies, and those who make financial transactions only for speculation.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: Writing. – Following the European Parliament's many years of requests, the EU will finally establish a mechanism to protect European money. We no longer want to support, directly or indirectly, the governments of countries that systematically and ly systematically demolish and politically subo thing social systems, disencompe the rule of law and democracy. We will no longer devote European taxpayers' money to the Member States that are doing this. The agreement between the EU institutions is also extremely important for Slovenia and for restoring citizens' trust in the Union and its institutions. Indeed, 80 per cent of Europeans said in a recent survey that countries that violate common values cannot be eligible for EU funding. The Union is so clear that it does not allow itself to blackmail authoritarian leaders. European values are no longer on sale. An important part of the deal is that EU citizens will not be punished for violations of their ruling countries. The final beneficiaries of funds that depend on EU support - for example students, farmers or NGOs - will be entitled directly to the funds by the Commission, as we have always requested in the European Parliament.

In addition, the agreement reached establishes a roadmap for the introduction of new own resources for the European Union, which on the one hand will allow us to finance our programmes, and on the other hand have a fairer taxation, which requires us to pay taxes in Europe on large technology and large multinationals, for the most polluting companies, and those who make financial transactions only for speculation.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The agreement on the future Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027 is undoubtedly a historic moment that will slowly build a stronger, citizen-oriented, green and competitive Europe on global markets. The European Union has responded to the extraordinary difficulties that Europeans now face in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, and in order to continue their existing policies and objectives, with the largest financial package ever adopted, amounting to EUR 1.8 trillion. With these measures, we will be able to support the maintenance of the present and the creation of new jobs, ensure future economic growth or fight climate change, and also more money for health and education, among other things. There is no doubt that this is particularly important now for all Member States, including the Polish, which can benefit from this extremely. However, in order to achieve this, these budgets need to be approved by the European Parliament and a unanimous vote in the Council and in the case of the Reconstruction Fund, ratifications in national parliaments. We therefore still have historical decisions before us on which the future of not only the European Union and individual Member States depends, including, in particular, my close Polish, but also individual European families. I hope that the particular interests of the ruling parties in some Member States will not prevent this extremely important agreement from being finalised for our common future.

name: Alicia HOMS GINEL
text: in writing. – The agreement reached this week with the Council for the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-27, after months of negotiations, is a historic success: for the first time since the Multiannual Financial Framework exists, the European Parliament has managed to increase the amount of money initially agreed by the Council. We have reached an ambitious, progressive and people-centered multiannual budget. We have defended the 15 key EU programmes, and we have ensured that none of its beneficiaries fall outside the new financial framework. In addition, we have achieved funding for the Green Pact and for a fair ecological transition; we have defended people and put the socialist seal on this long-term budget, which is now greener, fairer and more social. In addition, the agreement reached establishes a roadmap for the introduction of new own resources for the European Union, which on the one hand will allow us to finance our programmes, and on the other hand have a fairer taxation, which requires us to pay taxes in Europe on large technology and large multinationals, for the most polluting companies, and those who make financial transactions only for speculation.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Speaking in the debate on the multiannual EU budget 2021-2027, on behalf of the Polish delegation, I would like to express my joy at the conclusion of the negotiations between the EP, the Commission and the German Presidency. As a result of this agreement, funding for health, research and youth programmes has been increased by €16 billion, budget flexibility has been increased to allow for an easier EU response to unforeseen needs, and the ROLE of the EP in the area of new sources of revenue for the EU budget has been strengthened.  Unfortunately, the success of these negotiations is deeply overshadowed by the departure from the compromise conclusions of the Council of 21 July this year and the adoption of solutions on the so-called conditionality of budget expenditure, far exceeding the protection of the EU's financial interests. The solution, which was initially adopted on 5 November in the trilogue, is nothing more than the creation of an ideological baton that the Commission wants in the future to put in place right-wing governments that are disliked in Brussels, and some negotiators have made no secret of the fact that this was their aim.  Going into a confrontation with the Council threatens to block both the multiannual budget and the recovery plan, which, in the context of the deep recession of the economies of all EU countries caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, shows that negotiators have put the political interests of some EU countries above the economic and social interests of 450 million EU citizens.

name: Beata MAZUREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Mr President. The main challenge facing Member States today in times of a raging pandemic, rising unemployment, the collapse of many businesses, is the efficiency of an effective and rapid response to the crisis. A crisis that we all see. Not only economic but also social. Today, Europe should be a strong force for its countries of the community, not a force for incomprehensible decisions taken in the privacy of European cabinets. Such a path leads nowhere and undermines already eisting public confidence in the European institutions. I would like to remind you that the Multiannual Financial Framework is a measure that is enshrined in the Treaties, which cannot be amended by the Regulation. The regulation of linking the disbursement of money to the so-called rule of law mechanism is contrary not only to the content of the Treaties but also to the findings of the European Council of July this year. We cannot accept any discretionary mechanisms that are based on criteria that are mainly politically motivated. These illegal and dangerous actions can serve as a tool to blackmail and fight democratically elected governments seeking to preserve their sovereignty to which they are entitled. We need to come up with rules that are acceptable to all and allow for an agreement. All residents of the community are waiting for such actions.

name: Rovana PLUMB
text: in writing. – I welcome the historic agreement reached on MFF of EUR 1.8 trillion. More, the increases secured by Parliament for the key EU programmes in areas including health, research, mainstreaming gender and young people represent a big success of the negotiations held since 2018. The total amount of these top-ups is EUR 15 billion, and another EUR 1 billion will be put aside if unexpected future crises need to be addressed. The pandemic has given us new responsibilities and duties: the responsibility to make choices and the duty to do so in the interests of our European citizens. If we make a summary, it becomes obvious where we should invest: in the green economy, fighting against adverse effects of climate change, restore biodiversity, health, education, and in digital, democratic and social rights. We have managed to secure financing for the Green Deal and for a just transition and to stand up for a budget that is now greener, fairer and more socially just. We have to stay united, working hard for the well-being of the European citizens.

name: Marcos ROS SEMPERE
text: in writing. – The agreement reached this week with the Council for the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-27, after months of negotiations, is a historic success: for the first time since the Multiannual Financial Framework exists, the European Parliament has managed to increase the amount of money initially agreed by the Council. In addition, we have achieved funding for the Green Pact and for a fair ecological transition; we have defended people and put the socialist seal on this long-term budget, which is now greener, fairer and more social. In addition, the agreement reached establishes a roadmap for the introduction of new own resources for the European Union, which on the one hand will allow us to finance our programmes, and on the other hand have a fairer taxation, which requires us to pay taxes in Europe on large technology and large multinationals, for the most polluting companies, and those who make financial transactions only for speculation.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the agreement reached this week with the Council for the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-27, because it is a historic success: for the first time the European Parliament has managed to increase the amount of investment initially agreed by the Council, and it has been more than EUR 15 billion. This agreement is an achievement of the S&D group in which the EU's ability to invest beyond the recovery plan is preserved. We have increased the funding of strategic programmes (Horizon, EU4Health, Erasmus+, Creative Europe, Rights and Values, Humanitarian Aid,...) and secured funding for a fair ecological transition. In addition, this agreement establishes a roadmap for the introduction of new EU own resources (un recycled plastic tax and border carbon in 2021, digital rate in 2023, TTF and harmonised corporation tax in 2026) that together with the issuance of federal public debt to finance the recovery plan, make possible the temporary financial union to become a permanent union in the future , this being one of the keys to making full political union possible.

name: Nacho SÁNCHEZ AMOR
text: in writing. – The agreement reached this week with the Council for the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-27, after months of negotiations, is a historic success: for the first time since the Multiannual Financial Framework exists, the European Parliament has managed to increase the amount of money initially agreed by the Council. We have reached an ambitious, progressive and people-centered multiannual budget. We have defended the 15 key EU programmes, and we have ensured that none of its beneficiaries fall outside the new financial framework. In addition, we have achieved funding for the Green Pact and for a fair ecological transition; we have defended people and put the socialist seal on this long-term budget, which is now greener, fairer and more social. In addition, the agreement reached establishes a roadmap for the introduction of new own resources for the European Union, which on the one hand will allow us to finance our programmes, and on the other hand have a fairer taxation, which requires us to pay taxes in Europe on large technology and large multinationals, for the most polluting companies, and those who make financial transactions only for speculation.

name: Alfred SANT
text: bil-miktub. – The results obtained by the European Parliament negotiators seem impressive. The increased allocations for very crucial funding programmes such as education and research are highly commendable. Also very essential, especially in this current moment, is the tripling of funding dedicated to the incoming EU4Health funding programme. However, the main problematic issue here naturally remains the one of revenues. A major added source of revenue from this week’s agreement is that EU fines will automatically become a source of EU budget revenue. EU colleagues working on competition are suspicious of this new solution, as they fear it to become a new argument by defendants undergoing antitrust procedures. More controversial for some Member States is perhaps the agreement on the introduction of new own resources, over what has already been agreed in Council few months ago. For countries like mine, the introduction of own resources through a Financial Transaction Tax and a Common Corporate Tax Base will not be taken lightly. And here is a stumbling block that one cannot ignore. Such new own resources need approval by Member States in accordance with their respective constitutional requirements. This means that in most cases, each single new proposal needs to be approved by national parliaments: that will not be so plain sailing.

name: Riho TERRAS
text: Writing. – The European Parliament's determination to negotiate the next MULTIANNUAL BUDGETARY FRAMEWORK is very welcome, and I would like to sincerely thank parliament's negotiators. The agreement reached during the negotiations will bring significant additional funding to those areas whose development is critical for Europe's future. Increasing r&D and education opportunities through European Union funding is an investment in the future. Europe's competitiveness, the improvement of which is the day-to-day work and commitment of all of us, depends very much on how much resources are invested in raising it. This is both at national level and across Europe, not to mention the private sector, where it is a question of survival. Today and in the near future, of course, sufficient investment in our health care capacity is needed. The European Union must be a better partner for its citizens on health care issues. The ongoing crisis is a testament to this. However, in addition to positive developments, it must be noted that there are areas on which the European Union has a habit of hiding its head in the sand like an ostrich and ignoring reality. I am talking, above all, about the defence sector, whose funding has been severely cut compared to the original plans. All this was done in a situation where experts do not keep the words of caution – the security environment surrounding Europe is certainly not such as to allow sober decision-makers to further reduce the already limited amounts. The European Union has signed up to its greater ambition to contribute to defence. Ambition must always be guaranteed with a real financial cover, otherwise it will not be credible.

name: Monika VANA
text: Writing. Without a green EU budget, there is no Green Deal for a sustainable Europe! Ultimately, it is thanks to the European Parliament that this insight prevailed and that, after difficult negotiations, we were able to agree with the Council on the multiannual EU financial framework. The European Parliament's demands for future investments have gone much further, but have been held back by member states' attitude towards cuts. Nevertheless, we were able to push through some important budgetary decisions. 1. The Rule of Law Mechanism creates an important tool for consistently defending fundamental rights and democracy against autocratic backlash. 2. We Greens have negotiated award criteria for climate protection and biodiversity into the multiannual financial framework. For the first time, the MFF also provides funding to actively combat species extinction. 3. The legally binding roadmap for the establishment and development of the EU own resources system is another milestone. With a plastic tax next year, a digital tax and CO2 tax mechanisms in 2023, as well as a financial transaction tax and common corporate taxes in 2026, the roadmap is less ambitious than we Greens are calling for, but it finally puts a long-standing Green demand on the railways.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. – Mr President, I am pleased that Parliament and the Council have reached an agreement on the financial framework and the stimulus package. Compared with the European Council's july proposal, the package improved. In July, I criticised the fact that member states cut major EU programmes, recorded a loose position on the rule of law mechanism and left the debt payment open. Now, in the further negotiations, changes have been made to these points. The most significant improvement was the linking of funding to the rule of law. There was a strict limit to the record of conditionality. In addition to cases of misappropriation of EU funds, the mechanism also applies more broadly in the face of the union's fundamental values being jeopardised. The risk of breaches of the rule of law is sufficient to apply the law. This is an important step in safeguarding the EU's fundamental values.
