If this had not been successful now, the next opportunity to turn off the money taps on member states that trampled on fundamental values would have had to wait a long time. Another important improvement was the additional FUNDING of EUR 16 billion for flagship EU-added programmes such asEU4Health, Erasmus+, Creative Europe and Horizon Europe. However, as far as the horizon is concerned, we still cannot be satisfied with the outcome. Funding will remain at just under EUR 85 billion, which will rise slightly from last season. A transition to a climate-resilient and digital economy would require much greater research efforts. Europe's low level of INVESTMENT in THE CZECH Union is a big disappointment, which the Member States now also have to correct through the e-plate package. When debt is received for recovery funding against the EU budget, it is also up to us to agree on the repayment of the debt. I therefore welcome the fact that new own resources, such as the plastic waste levy, can contribute to the costs of the recovery package. Next, I hope that Parliament and the Council will swiftly adopt the package. This will not jeopardise the continuum of EU programmes and allow recovery funding to be targeted at sustainable growth.

name: Bettina VOLLATH
text: Writing. – The EU budget for the next seven years is worth a total of EUR 1.1 trillion. This includes: EUR 750 billion in EU Corona aid. That's a lot of money. Money that should not be watered away lightly, but should be used in the best possible way in line with European values. I am very pleased that we, as the European Parliament, have been able to enforce the rule of law. Our steadfastness has paid off. For the first time in EU history, EU funds will be bound - at our pressure - to respect the rule of law. Although we as a Parliament have not achieved everything, it must be said that this is a great and historic step. This will ensure that European funds can no longer be used in future to undermine or even dismantle the rule of law.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I support all measures to protect the Union budget. However, they must be lawful. They must not be intended to circumvent existing treaty mechanisms. The European Council called on the Commission to prepare a regime to protect the budget from breaches. However, this was not a breach of the rule of law, as this procedure is included in Article 7 of the Treaty on Union. A mechanism to link the budget to breaches in the area of the rule of law would mirror the mechanism under Article 7, further over-strengthening the Commission while marginalising the role of Member States in the process of assessing breaches of the rule of law. I support this part of the proposed regulation, which relates to the implementation of the budget and the effective prevention of fraud. However, I cannot support proposals that lead to discrimination against certain Member States. I absolutely do not agree with giving the mechanism a preventive character, by being able to trigger it not only in the event of a direct breach of the budget, but also when there is a risk itself. The European Council stressed in its Conclusions in July the need to defend the Union budget in accordance with Treaty principles and values. It stressed the importance of the rule of law. It is not only the Responsibility of the Member States, but also the institutions to comply with it. Secondary law cannot replace the Treaty.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. – The enthusiasm and optimism shown by the majority forces for the supposed compromise reached between the Council and Parliament on the MFF and the Recovery Fund are, as is often the case, excessive and, unfortunately for European citizens, unjustified. A draft agreement was reached after long weeks of negotiations, the latter influenced by the utopian demands of the majority of the Eurochamber. In the midst of a very serious crisis such as the current one, valuable time is still being wasted in Brussels by planning to introduce new own resources, that is to say, additional European taxes that would increase the tax burden on a country such as Italy, which is already a net contributor. On the Recovery Fund, the EU's desire to impose a mechanism for the protection of the rule of law translates into a ruse designed to punish some "non-aligned" countries, in order to establish a kind of parameter for the entrustment or denial of the resources provided for in the package. In view of the EU's bureaucratic slowness, which is putting the fate of an entire continent at risk, we will continue even more strongly to support the need for immediate action.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The agreements between the European Parliament and the Council on the Recovery Plan for Europe, the Multiannual Financing Framework 2021/2027 (MFF), own resources and the Conditionality Mechanism on the application of rule of law rules are a historic moment and a robust step, both for the European response to the needs of citizens and for the affirmation of a new paradigm of interinstitutional cooperation and solidarity.  The European Parliament has achieved substantive negotiating gains, which dignify its role as a direct representative of the peoples of Europe. A total of €16 billion in strengthening the MFF, including substantive strengthening of the Research and Development, Mobility (Erasmus), health, investment, innovation and humanitarian aid programmes, were substantially strengthened.  The guaranteed articulation, under parliament's supervision, between the MFF and the Recovery Programme for Europe is essential. 40% of this plan will have to be implemented in the Green Deal and 20% in the Digital Agenda.  Finally, I would like to take the steps taken in my own resources. The timetableism is less ambitious than they should be, but they allow the solidarity coverage of the Recovery Fund to be guaranteed.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: The next item is the debate on the results of the US presidential election. I would like to inform you that in this debate a round of speakers from the political groups is envisaged and that, in all the debates in this part-session, there will be no catch the eye procedure or blue card questions. Interventions are made from the Liaison Offices of the European Parliament in the Member States.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, dear Members, dear colleagues of the European Parliament, thank you for organising a very quick debate, an exchange of views on the results of the US elections. I’m glad to see that you give this event all the importance it has and have a look at the future of our partnership with the US – it’s an important thing, a priority of our future engagement and our future foreign policy.  Unfortunately, we will not have a lot of time today to discuss this, but I’m sure that we will have other opportunities to come back to this issue soon and to examine our transatlantic relationship in depth.  Indeed, last week the whole world was following, with a lot of attention and suspense, the elections in the US. And I want to congratulate the American people for the largest participation in US electoral history, which shows clearly that the American citizens were very much aware of the importance of these elections. Americans demonstrated the importance and capacity of democratic institutions and civic engagement and I want to congratulate warmly President-elect Joe Biden and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris for their historic victory.  We are now looking at the opportunities to advance our strategic partnership. This morning at the college, the Commission took a first look at this opportunity and how we are going to manage this new era of our relationship with the US. All the Commissioners participated in this debate and I am happy that the Parliament also wants to advance a first approach to this issue.  I don’t have to explain that we have had a very significant bilateral relationship globally. We have a common history, shared values and we adhere to democratic principles. This partnership reflects how cross all economic fields underpinned by broad cooperation.  It’s not a secret either that in the past four years things have become complicated in our relations. I am looking forward to getting back to a frank dialogue. Well, the dialogue has always been frank and wherever possible we have formulated joint strategies and put in the necessary resources to make them possible.  First of all, I think that we have to welcome the clear commitment of President-elect Biden to restore unity and respect for democratic norms and institutions and work with allies based on true partnership. We are a partner and a capable and strategic approach to the European Union-United States relationship has to build on this idea of partnership.  For this reason, we have to proceed with our work to enhance what we call Europe’s strategic autonomy, a word that will be very much in use, I hope, in the near future, because this means our ability to act and to defend ourselves effectively and at the same time work together with the US in many frameworks, including defence frameworks and others.  Let me take a quick look at the wider spectrum of global challenges that will be at the heart of our transatlantic agenda. I think that there are some priorities that they want to highlight: to re-energise cooperation for multilateral fora, in particular the United Nations; we are continuing to work towards promoting respect for human rights; to address the difficulties of the World Trade Organization, especially the dispute settlement mechanism; to cooperate in fighting COVID-19, including strengthening the workings of the World Health Organization and the capacity of the global health systems, starting with preparedness and response to emergencies; to accelerate ambitious global climate action and to invest in harnessing that in a logical transformation; to look at China and Iran and our neighbourhood, and we will try to reach a common approach with the US. We already started with the previous administration over the last few weeks but for sure it should now be easier. We also need to become a stronger global player for a stronger transatlantic partnership that benefits NATO. It’s a busy agenda and our capacity for developing digital strategy partnerships will be more effective if both partners are strong and committed, and of course here in Europe we speak with one voice when we engage with the new President, the new administration and the new Congress.  We need to invest at all levels and talk to our American friends across the aisle. For sure the Parliament will also have an important role to play through the transatlantic legislators’ dialogue and other contexts.  From our end we will also step up people-to-people programmes – a priority that was supported by this Parliament as well and one I hope will continue. All in all, the European Union and the United States are, and will remain, key strategic partners of first resort in critically difficult moments, such as the one that we are currently experiencing. A strong transatlantic partnership is of key importance and you can rest assured that we are ready to engage quickly with the new administration, although for that we still have to wait until 20 January, because as you very well know there is quite a long transition ahead. Let’s hope it’s not going to be a bumpy transition.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which On the part of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I congratulate Joe Biden and Kamala Harris on their election. As a group that has always been important in the transatlantic partnership, we are pleased that we can return to good relations, in a political framework based on reason, decency, trust, predictability and value-based partnership.  We congratulate the institutions, the countless election workers, who have carried out their work unimpressed by politically stoked doubts and insinuations about the integrity of the election. Our European observers have also confirmed that there have been no systematic falsifications or irregularities. After all, the OSCE was also represented there with its colleagues in the Parliamentary Assembly, and the European Parliament, unfortunately, was not.  We also congratulate the newly and re-elected colleagues in the House and Senate. We look forward to a broad dialogue with both houses and both parties on all issues that affect us together. First of all, we wish the new administration to get a grip on the COVID-19 pandemic and to reconcile the politically divided nation. As part of the democratic world, we want the US to recommit and take responsibility, where the multilateral rules-based world order needs to be strengthened. We Europeans are therefore pleased with the President-elect's announcement that he will rejoin the Paris climate agreement. We also welcome the intended return to the World Health Organisation. Together, we must make the WTO fully operational again. China's behaviour in the WTO is one of the reasons for today's problems. We are therefore not equidistant between the United States and China. Together with the United States, we want to achieve a well-coordinated approach to this systemic rival. We know that the new administration is still cautious about free trade. However, I am convinced that the West can only successfully meet the Chinese challenge in the long term if the EU, the US and other allies such as Canada and Japan jointly organise free trade and set global standards.  I would like to thank the United States for also taking care of vulnerable partners such as Taiwan in terms of security policy. We should supplement this with our own contribution, for example through a bilateral investment agreement with this important trading partner. We support the important American ideas to rejoin the Iran nuclear agreement. Nobody in the world wants an Iranian bomb. Therefore, all the parties must be behind it, and Iran must comply with the agreement again. Then we can also talk about what else is complaining to us about the country, but that is a separate matter.  For Europe's security, the US remains an indispensable nation. However, we will only keep them anchored in Europe if we make burden-sharing fair. I want to make it clear to our European doubters that the 2% target for defence spending has not been imposed on us by Mr Trump, it was a decision taken by the NATO summit in Wales in 2014 in the face of Russian aggression against Ukraine.  I know that there are also political currents here that do not want to advocate strong defence or even compliment the Americans out of Europe. "Be careful what you wish for" is a beautiful English saying that I would like to give you here.  It is important for us Europeans that arms control and disarmament agreements are guaranteed. We know that the new START agreement will soon expire, I hope that the United States will agree to the one-year extension there, and that time must then be used for negotiations. There are other agreements that we would like to see, as Europeans in particular. For this, a predictable US administration is a better partner, including for Russia. Finally, we are pleased that Joe Biden is a friend of Europe, but also of Ireland in particular, and has made it clear to him how important it is to him to preserve the Good Friday Agreement. We trust that the US, under his leadership, will not support an agreement that threatens peace and well-being on the island of Ireland. So far on this subject. Ceterum censeo: I'm sitting here in 156th place. This is a coincidence, but Rule 156 of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure says: 'In each sitting, a attendance list is interpreted for signature by Members'. This is not a provision of can' be made, it is not at the discretion. Mr President, please ensure that the Rules of Procedure are observed here too on this issue.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, ‘while I may be the first woman in this office, I won’t be the last’. These were the words spoken by the new Vice President-elect Kamala Harris in her victory speech. To every little girl watching she said: ‘dream with ambition and lead with conviction’. Joe Biden and his Vice President spoke about the people rather than about themselves, about their plans rather than their egos, and they spoke to inspire, not to divide. The past four years have been tough for our American friends, tough for transatlantic relations and tough for the multilateral global order. Five years ago, we watched in horror as this chapter in American history began on the golden elevator in Trump Tower. On Saturday, we saw it coming crashing down in the parking lot of Four Seasons Total Landscaping. While this year will go down in history as the year of a global pandemic, economic decline and authoritarian power grabs, the US election result is a clear symbol of hope for all of us. Our American friends have demonstrated that yes, democrats can defeat autocrats, yes, facts can defeat disinformation, and hope can defeat fear. The long nightmare is over. Well, almost over. It is, of course, worrisome to see that McConnell and other prominent Republicans are doing everything in their power to cast doubt on the fairness of this election, and I believe it’s time to face reality. Some of Trump’s friends in Europe also had to swallow: they hoped for four more years of support for their repressive illiberalism, and they are left empty handed. Mr Trump has been fired by a majority of the American voters, but he hasn’t conceded. The next 70 days will certainly be bumpy, but they won’t change the facts. I’m hopeful that in the end the democratic institutions will halt the power grab of President Trump. On behalf of the entire S&D Group, let me congratulate President-elect Biden and Vice President-elect Harris on winning the most important US elections of our generation. We are happy and relieved, while we also know that Trumpism is not gone. We know that things have changed in the last four years, and that the EU also needs to take up its own responsibility as a global player. However, it’s good to have an ally in the White House again. And it’s a joy for millions of girls around the world, especially girls of colour, who in Kamala Harris have the brightest demonstration that there’s nothing they cannot achieve. Mr President, let’s make it very clear that we are stronger if we work together, that the damage done is reversible. And therefore let’s do so by inviting President Biden to deliver his first foreign address in the European Parliament, because there’s no better place to start – to restart – a new transatlantic partnership than at the heart of European democracy.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, after the elections, we all felt relief: relief from the endless stream of fake news and – let’s be honest – the racism of Mr Trump. But relief is not a strategy; relief doesn’t tell us what to do next. Millions of Europeans have been watching the American elections, waiting for the verdict of the American people. But the Americans will not solve our problems. We shouldn’t live our lives to the rhythm of American democracy. We should live our lives to the beat of our own drum, to the rhythm of European democracy. So, let’s welcome and congratulate President—elect Joe Biden and Vice—President—elect Kamala Harris with open arms. But let’s do so by building from our own strength. This Commission promised to be a geopolitical Commission. We have the perfect opportunity now to show the Americans we mean business by going forward with the European Defence Union, by creating a real European migration policy, by building a European intelligence capacity that is able to combat terrorism on the same level as American agencies. Mr Biden is a friend of Europe, but he is also an important architect of America’s China strategy. He might – and let’s hope – he might tweet less than his predecessor, and more politely, but he is also more focused on Asia than on Europe. It’s high time that Europe stood on its own feet. Instead of always hiding behind the Americans, we need to stand next to the USA. That will be in the interests of both sides of the Atlantic.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the United States is and will always be the polar star for democracy and freedom in the world. To date, the results of the AMERICAN elections would indicate as the new President Joe Biden, to whom, if the data are made official, we wish him well in his work. The new American administration, of whatever political colour it may be, democratic or republican, will always find in us in the League a serious and reliable ally, firmly aligned with the Atlantic alliance in defence of the values and interests of the free West. Our pro-Atlantic position, which is even super-Atlantic on some particularly sensitive issues, such as 5G and the defence of human rights, has never been called into question. The same cannot be said, in Italy and In Europe, of so many parties or political subjects who say they are democratic, such as the PD and the 5 Stars, but who in reality defend the positions of communist dictatorships, such as China and Venezuela, or criminal regimes such as Iran. We do not accept lessons from false Democrats, Italian and European, who in recent years have waged an absurd war against the Trump administration and therefore against the United States. We all know our sympathy and appreciation for Trump and his administration. The trump administration's successes in economic and foreign policy are in everyone's eyes, and only the blind persist in not seeing them. Trump was the first leader to put the great danger posed by Communist China in the spotlight of world public opinion. To paraphrase a great American President like Ronald Reagan, Trump has the great merit of making the West understand that communist China is the empire of evil of the third millennium, potentially much stronger and more dangerous than Soviet communism, because it is a danger that affects the daily life of each of us. But Trump's foreign policy is not just China: think of the iron fist against Maduro's dictatorship in Venezuela; think of the fight against Islamic terrorism, with the destruction of Isis and the targeted killing of Soleimani, the military leader of a rogue country like Iran who would like to destroy Israel with the nuclear bomb. Or think about Trump's decisive role in the historic peace agreements between Israel and the United Arab Emirates. And let us always remember that President Trump did not start any new war during his term of office, unlike his predecessor, who has combined many wars and damage around the world. We need only think of the chaos created in the Mediterranean area with the Arab Spring and the unholy war in Libya, which has had very serious consequences that Italy and Europe are still paying for, especially those linked to the emergence of illegal immigration. I mean, Democrat Obama should take away the Nobel Peace Prize and give it to Trump. Now the question everyone is asking is what Biden will do in foreign policy: Will he follow Trump's bold and successful path, or will he go back down Obama's chaotic, warmongering path? What will Biden do about the hottest dossiers, China and 5G, the Middle East and Iran? Will he have the strength and foresight of Trump to continue the tug-of-war with China? Will it have the strength to combat the beijing regime's strategy of penetration and infiltration into our society, our economy and even our institutions? We hope that Biden will continue the right battle against china's Communist dictatorship, which is the greatest threat to our freedom and democracy. And we hope that Europe will finally also abandon the double games, the ambiguities, the blood-stained business done with Beijing.  We are at a crossroads in history: on the one hand, the free world of Western democracies, on the other the world of dictatorship, tyranny and repression. "Do not be afraid", said Pope John Paul II. Well, we are not afraid to stand shoulder to shoulder with the United States of America in this battle of civilisation, so that good may win over evil and freedom may triumph over dictatorship.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, these US elections have brought some good news. Trump is out, even if he himself doesn’t yet want to believe it. I’m sure he will see soon. Joe Biden and his promise of politics based on respect for each other, for facts, and for science has won. Kamala Harris, Vice President-elect, achieved something truly historic. A first woman, a woman of colour: Harris smashed many glass ceilings, and while a lot remains to be done on gender equality, this breakthrough will have a long-lasting impact.  But, while Trump is voted out of the White House, Trumpism – or whatever you want to call this disastrous mix of nationalism, racism, and narcissism – got a lot of support. And it also has a lot of support in Europe and even among some EU governments, as we have seen. Democracy, equality and rule of law are not a given on either side of the Atlantic. It is something we have to strive for every day and never take for granted. Movements like Black Lives Matter, like Me Too, and journalists, democracy activists and many more fought back and defended democracy in the US for the past four years. They are the ones that should be celebrated in these elections.  Transatlantic relations have taken a hard hit over the past four years, and while we all hope and we can be sure that they will become better now, the lesson learned for Europe is that it needs to stand more on its own two feet. In order to be able to do that, we need to also stand stronger together and more firmly. For that, we need to have a common understanding of fundamental values because if we don’t know on what grounds we stand as a Union then we cannot grow. And equally, we cannot shy away from the responsibilities of our actions in the external world. That goes for the climate crisis, for weapons exports, for conflict parties or for shady energy projects with even more shady partners such as Nord Stream. If we want Europe to be taken seriously by the world, we have to take ourselves seriously first, and that means taking responsibility for our actions and their impact in the world, no matter who rules the White House.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, thank you for your word. Dear Colleagues, first of all it would be right and normal to wait for the final results of the elections. Elections are not decided by the media, no matter how biased they are, but are decided by the legitimate institutions of each country. So wait for the media, do not rush to rejoice, dear colleagues. I'm saying about the colleague who, before me, was so pleased and biased with one of the two candidates. What is important to us as citizens of Member States of the European Union is to continue to maintain our transatlantic relationship with the United States of America. No matter who the president is, we must continue Black Sea cooperation, we must continue cooperation in the field of defense, security. We must continue to maintain the restoration of the capabilities of our armed forces so that we can be adequate to the challenges that are all around us.  What we need is to respond to the challenges from China, from Turkey, from Russia, they are hostile to us. I say this about the Communists, the Bolsheviks and the colleague who spoke before me. She also sympathizes with these ideas. And to know that these countries around here are not our friends. The US is our strategic partner and we must work with them thoroughly, wisely, meaningfully and in the interests of all our citizens. Thanks for the attention.

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Democracy has triumphed. Short, but after four years of Trumpian contempt for democracy, after attacks on the press and minorities, after open cooperation with the far right, and even racist armed militias, voters in the United States have said: Stop getting out of the White House with this autocrat.  Because this election in the United States was not a normal choice between two candidates from different parties. It was the choice between democracy on the one hand and authoritarianism on the other. And after four years of Trumpism, voters have opted for democracy and against authoritarianism. And this result, ladies and gentlemen, came about through an alliance of left ists to liberal forces. And it will hurt demagogues, autocrats, and dictators and their friends all over the world, and also in the European Union, and strengthen all the forces that stand up to such guys as Trump.  It is against this background that I have also spoken and spoken in the run-up to the elections, and I have also asked your boss, Mr Borrell – unfortunately you are no longer here – to do so. For a clear statement from the European Union – not for either of the two candidates, but for respect for democratic values and basic standards – would have been a sign of foreign policy strength. Their silence was not. Because when democracy is under threat, democrats must not remain silent.  Donald Trump still can't concede defeat and defiantly barricades himself like a little kid in the White House. It must recognise the outcome of the election and guarantee a peaceful transfer of power. The fact that the result is nevertheless so close should give us all something to think about. We must address the causes of the emergence of such anti-democratic politicians, that is, to overcome the social divisions in our societies and resolve the issues of the future, such as digitalisation and climate protection, socially justly.  I want to congratulate Joe Biden and Kamala Harris on their convincing win. This victory also belongs to the young people and the marginalized communities who have fought so hard. But the dangers of Trumpism remain. The narrative that demands like Medicare for All, or movements like Black Lives Matter, pose a threat to progressive electoral victories is completely wrong. The evidence shows the opposite is true: it would be a fatal mistake now to sideline the new generation of leftist leaders who contributed to this victory. The repair of US society requires strong, principled leadership that boldly tackles both inequality and climate change. Mr President-elect, you succeeded because of the unity of progressive forces: their hopes lie on you. Do not let them down or Trumpism will be back.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the great exercise in democracy that has seen some 160 million Americans – the highest turnout since 1900 – engaged in the elections of their new President now leaves room for a transitional phase that is in danger of being among the most complex ever, with the daily cases of COVID-19 churning out 100 000 and an outgoing President who does not seem prepared for a painless handover. Yet something has changed, and it is no coincidence that the whole world has held its breath and spent sleepless nights in the exhausting expectation of a verdict, which has never been expected as in this case. A new and delicate phase is opening up: for the United States, which in these elections has been painted as a country still divided and in search of a new normal, and for the whole world, which in recent years has undoubtedly suffered the lack of a clear direction expressed by Washington, of a reference on which we had perhaps, blessly , all too well set in past decades. Let me make it quite clear: I expect a great deal from this American Presidency. I expect the fight against climate change and the rise of inequalities, the biggest systemic crises of this generation, to be back on the US and global agendas. I expect an end to a senseless and perpetual trade war that we have seen in recent years; coordination and not confrontation. I still expect the EU to find its American partner in global governance and for the US to regain its place in the international multilateral system, reconsidering some critical decisions taken by the Trump administration, such as participation in the Iran nuclear deal. I expect that once again the indissoluble transatlantic link, a link based on our common values, on the staunch defence of democracy, the rule of law and freedom, which has never been discussed but which has certainly been put to the test, indeed extremely tested, in recent years, will be reconfirmed, and that this will also be done in the light of the renewed process of integration and the search for strategic autonomy of the EU. I know, Mr Biden, I expect a lot and we expect a lot. We're ready. I wish you good work and we look forward to seeing you soon in Brussels.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: The debate on the results of the US presidential election is over. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The eagerness of the European Union to welcome Joe Biden's victory, to the point that the President of the Commission saw fit to discuss a new partnership even before the inauguration of the person concerned, contrasts with the caution of some heads of state, from China to Russia, via Mexico.  Thus, it is unusual that Brussels, yet always quick to distribute patents of democratic virtue to the four corners of the world, ignores the heavy uncertainties that still weigh on this disputed election. I would like to remind you that U.S. Attorney General William Barr on Monday authorized investigations into possible fraud.  Unfortunately, this is only the least of the scandals that have marred this extraordinary election. In particular, the media outburst has reached rarely matched lows against a president whose only wrong is to have made himself the herald of flyover country - an American echo of peripheral France, forgotten of globalization.  Certainly, this haro against a candidate reviled by the establishment does not bode well for upcoming elections in the Western world, at a time when civil liberties are declining dramatically.

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: Writing. – The result of the US presidential elections promises the return of this superpower to international relations, which will be more inclined to respect international law and strengthen international institutions, i.e. multilateralism, which can potentially restore confidence in the strength of the Euro-Atlantic Strategic Partnership. The latter is undoubtedly a prerequisite for a safe and stable world, based on rules and norms, for the benefit of both the US and the rest of the (larger and smaller) members of the international community, and especially the people who are affected by political decisions at the highest level in their daily lives. I consider that the efforts of the outgoing administration have gone in a different direction, and I would like to point out that a great lot of effort will be needed at all levels to eliminate this legacy. In this light, I would like to see concrete steps to be taken as soon as possible to re-strengthen the us-Europe ties. I also want to work on closer cooperation based on trust, respect for agreements and predictability, and not on the basis of unannounced unilateral actions, as we have seen in the nuclear agreement with Iran, or acts to the detriment of the Middle East peace process. For a successful partnership, however, equal conditions of cooperation are certainly key. The EU must therefore strengthen strategic autonomy by leading the most coherent common foreign policy to both the US and other key players, such as Russia and China.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – I welcome the victory of Mr. Joe Biden in the U.S. presidential election and I particularly salute his commitment to re-join the Paris climate agreement, in line with the EU’s Green Deal ambition. The EU and U.S. share common history and values of democracy, human rights, freedom and open economy. I find this moment a good opportunity to reenergize EU’s Transatlantic Partnership with our long-time allies and friends and to jointly address increasing and pressing global challenges, such as: climate change, digital transformation, security, defence and the rules-based multilateral system. In the same time, engagement to NATO remains a pillar of security and economic prosperity on both sides of the Atlantic In my capacities as chair of ITRE Committee and rapporteur for EU program for health, I highlight just a recent outcome of good EU-US collaboration, where a joint project between a European and an American company succeed to develop a strongly effective vaccine against COVID-19, bringing back hope to people all over the world. Together, the EU and U.S. represent over a half of the global GDP. This one more reason to be confident that together we can lead the global agenda towards a liberal and rules-based international system.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – The new US presidential administration is accompanied by the hope that this will lead to an improvement in Relations between Europe and the US to the level they were before the previous presidential elections. This is also very important for Estonia. Both from the point of view of security and the economic environment. Our focus should first and foremost be that relations between Europe and the US return to very good substantive cooperation, as it has been in the past. In a situation where pressure from China, Russia and other authoritarian powers is intensifying, comprehensive open cooperation between Europe and the US is essential to our value- space.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. – Congratulations to the winner of the election, Joe Biden, with the highest number of votes in the election. On the other hand, I see a deeply fragmented American society. However, I consider it essential, from a European point of view, which direction the development of transatlantic relations will take. From the removal of trade barriers, to attitudes to environmental challenges, to the promotion of democracy at home and around the world. Closer cooperation between democracies is essential, because the democratic world needs much more cooperation between them.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Written. – The election of Joe Biden and Kamala Harris is encouraging. After years of political disarray, fake news and polarization, the American people are once again offering the prospect of a binding presidency that faces major economic, social, social, and climate challenges. And for the EU, too, a change of guard in the White House is good news. If the US takes its place at the table again internationally, a renewed partnership with the European Union will provide opportunities to form a strong voice for democracy and human rights. We'll be stronger when we work together. This is also the case in the global fight against climate change and the transition to a carbon neutral economy. With the Green Deal, the European Union has taken the leading role in achieving the objectives of the Paris climate agreement. Here too, we hope to find a partner for ambitious climate policy in the new President. Finally, ladies and gentlemen, we are looking forward to the new role of the United States in the field of international trade. We hope to find a partner there to re-strengthen multilateral cooperation, reform the WTO and build a new partnership with Asia and Africa.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: The next item is the debate on the statements by the Council and the Commission on the fight against terrorism and the right to freedom of expression and education [2020/2841(RSP)]. I would remind you that in this debate a round of speakers from the political groups is envisaged and that there will be no catch-the-eye procedure or blue card questions. Interventions are made from the Liaison Offices of the European Parliament in the Member States.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I think we are all still in shock because of the recent terrorist attacks in Austria and France. My thoughts are with the victims, their families and friends. My thoughts are with the French and Austrian people and I know yours are as well. Let’s be clear: these were attacks on our European values, on fundamental rights and freedoms. Samuel Paty taught history, geography and civics. His brutal murder was a direct attack on our values, rights and freedoms – the freedom of expression and information, the right to education, the freedom of thought, conscience and religion. We need to unite and show strong solidarity as a Union. No Member State can or should face this threat alone. We need to unite as a society. We need to show that our values are unbreakable and that we cannot be divided on this, and we need to do more to protect our citizens, our societies and our values. The Vienna attack shows the need to stop illegal firearms. Member States must urgently implement the Firearms Directive. Before the summer, we launched an action plan against firearms trafficking. We are working closely with Western Balkans partners to fight the smuggling of illegal guns. And we need to register all known foreign terrorist fighters in the Schengen Information System so that we can detect them when they try to cross EU borders. The Vienna attacker tried to buy ammunition in Slovakia. There were contacts in Germany and Switzerland. We need to better share information and to share better information across borders. The Schengen Information System is central here, but so are PNR – passenger name records. They are essential to deter and detect terrorist suspects. Member States should implement the PNR Directive. I am planning to update the Prüm Decision to make it easier for law enforcement to exchange DNA, fingerprints and number plates, and, in future, possibly also photos and police records. I want us, together in the European Union, to move away from ad hoc police cooperation towards systematic police partnership. The Commission has started work on an EU police cooperation code. Better information-sharing also means making sure that IT systems can talk to each other. Member States need to work hard to achieve full interoperability by 2023. Europol is the backbone of European police cooperation and Europol is providing concrete and invaluable support to the French and Austrian authorities as we speak. Already this year, I will propose a reinforced mandate for Europol so it can do an even better job at fighting crime and terror. The recent attackers struck in a church in Nice and in the streets and cafés of Vienna. The Commission is supporting Member States to increase the protection of public spaces. Small actions can make a difference, sometimes between life and death. Last year, a far-right terrorist attacked a synagogue in Halle in Germany. A reinforced door and the security cameras helped to save thousands of lives. The Commission made EUR 12 million available to improve security in places of worship. I’m looking into possibilities to increase this amount. Samuel Paty’s murderer used the internet to identify his horrible crime and afterwards posted pictures of his victim online. The Vienna attacker posted a picture with an AK-47. In one month, in July this year, Europol’s Internet Referral Unit took down 2 000 links to terrorist content, including tutorials on how to carry out an attack. Europol will continue to work with platforms who want to help, but voluntary cooperation is not enough. Member States need to be able to order the removal of terrorist content from any hosting service provider, irrespective of its place of establishment, with EU-wide effects in one hour. I call on this House, this Parliament, for an agreement on the proposed regulation to prevent the dissemination of terrorist content online as soon as possible. Besides police intervention, the European Union also invests in the prevention of radicalisation. Prevention is better than cure. It’s difficult to measure terrorist attacks that are prevented, but our police forces, with the help of Europol, work hard every day to do justice. The Radicalisation Awareness Network connects teachers, social workers and community police officers. When they successfully lead someone away from violence, there are seldom big headlines, but the results are spectacular. There are former neo-Nazis, former violent Islamists who now reject violence and help others to do the same. Without the Radicalisation Awareness Network and their job, these people would perhaps still be a danger to society. In a few weeks, on 9 December, I will present our new counter-terrorism agenda. The objective will be to identify and close security gaps in law enforcement cooperation, in the use of technology and information-sharing, to prevent radicalisation, to protect public spaces and to work with Member States, regions, cities and towns and also with key third-country partners. But we also need to look beyond counter-terrorism. Terrorists seek to divide us: to draw a line between ‘them and us’. We can only counter this by offering an inclusive, cohesive society in which everyone has a stake, where there is no ‘them and us’. Later this month I will launch an action plan on integration and inclusion, based on opportunities and obligations. Everyone who has a legal right to be in Europe should have the opportunity to take part in society, a society where everyone is protected by European values and fundamental rights, and where everyone must respect those same values and rights, that includes the freedom of speech and the freedom of expression. Fundamental rights, the EU will defend – that includes also the freedom of religion, but we will never accept violence in the name of religion. Education, culture and sport also have a key role to play in this. Mr President, today is Armistice Day. Europe commemorates the end of the First World War 102 years ago: a war that started with a violent attack – the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand in 1914. New attacks have such cataclysmic consequences. But this is what we mean by ‘terrorist offence’: international acts which, given their nature or context, may seriously damage a country or an international organisation. This reminds us that our struggle is not a new one. When I grew up, there was the RAF, the Red Brigades, the IRA, ETA. The terrorists change, their causes change and their methods change. What doesn’t change is the fear, the death and the suffering that they bring. What we must do is to be united as a Union and as a society and to do everything we can to oppose them, to fight them, to defeat them.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. The terrorist attacks in Paris, Nice and Vienna are shaking Europe. And attacks are attacks on the whole of Europe, on our values, on our ideas, on our democracy, on our way of life.  The focus is first on the victims. We also mourn with the relatives. In Paris, a 47-year-old teacher with a son, in Nice, killed three people, including a 44-year-old nurse who simply left work. In Vienna, four dead, a 44-year-old woman on her way home from work, a 39-year-old owner of a Chinese restaurant and a 22-year-old art student from Germany. People were murdered indiscriminately. Much suffering from the relatives, and these thoughts are first in our hearts.  I would also like to thank the authorities, the police, the emergency services, the emergency services, the medics who helped. They, too, have done an excellent job, and they deserve our thanks. Grief alone is not enough. In the last twenty-two months, 119 terrorist attacks have taken place in Europe. Almost every country in Europe, almost every city in Europe, already has victims and knows the threat, knows the fear and knows the grief.  It must now be said that enough is enough. We do not allow ourselves to be forced to their knees by the perpetrators of violence. Combating radical Islamism and Islamists is the task we must tackle now. They are fighting our way, and that is why we must now take the most out-of-the-way action against these Islamist perpetrators.  Terrorists do not kill alone. They are following propaganda. They are recruited and supported by structures in the background. All these radical Islamists are fighting our democracy and are enemies of our freedom – including religious freedom. That is why we must now dismantle the networks and structures.  What concrete action should be done? The first important point is that there are many people who, unfortunately, grow out of our societies and become radical. That is why we have to ask ourselves the question: what will go wrong if people who have enjoyed education with us, who grew up with us, become radicals and individual perpetrators?  We need to convey more ambition and invest in our values of tolerance and freedom. And we must ensure that recruitment on the web, on social networks, can no longer be done so effectively. That is why the EU-Commission's directive on the eradication of online content, which calls for terror and glorifies terror, is so extremely important. I would now ask the colleagues of Renew and the Social Democrats to put an end to their blockade of this legislation. We have already lost too much time. Legislation has been on the table for years and, unfortunately, is not making progress. It is now time to complete this legislation.  The second is that we need the full implementation of the Arms Directive, as the Commissioner has said. I also call on the Commissioner to put pressure on fellow ministers of the Interior to ensure that the existing laws on regulating and preventing access to arms are uniformly implemented on this continent.  Another major issue for us as the PPE-DE is a key threat file. Unfortunately, the Schengen Information System is based only on voluntary action. We need it to be mandatory. All the dangers that we have on this continent, which are monitored by the national authorities, must be entered in the common databases in a compulsory and binding manner, so that all police forces have the same level of information.  Terrorism is cross-border, and Europe must also respond to it across borders. That is why we are also in favour of extending Europol's powers so that it not only acts as a consultant, not only supportive, but also builds up independent investigative capacities in the fight against Islamist terrorist cells. We also want to strengthen Europol in this context.  Last but not least, the border protection, which has now been discussed at the mini-summit in Paris. Yes, border management needs to be improved. Yes, Schengen needs to be revised. There must be no entry without a passport, as is already the legal situation in Europe today. And we need a binding, mandatory networking of files, so that it is possible to check at the external border whether there is data against certain dangerous persons. And the biggest problem is enforcement, which must be tackled accordingly.  Mr President, Commissioner, there is much to be done. We must now tackle this together. The question of terrorism is back on the political agenda, and the most important thing we have to say is that we must not allow the radical forces to split between them in the fight against terror. religions. Religions enjoy freedom on this continent. This is not a battle between religions. It is a fight against terror that we are waging. Let us approach it with courage.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, unfortunately, we need to talk again about terrorism in this house, terrorism that seeks to undermine the foundations of our liberal and democratic societies. The recent terrorist attacks in France and Austria fill us with sadness, but they will not bend us. On the contrary, we will pursue fans without giving up our principles. I would like to reiterate my condolences to the victims and their families, all our solidarity.  We cannot give up freedom of expression and freedom of education. Europe would not exist without them and are fundamental principles of our Union. Also in cases where I do not agree with the content, I always support freedom, because it is the basis of a democratic and pluralistic society. We must educate on freedom of conscience and critical thinking. That is why I would also like to pay tribute to Professor Samuel Paty. His legacy will not be forgotten. But we must also not allow the violent to divide us, because that's what they want. We must distinguish between Islam as a religion and radical Islamism as a political ideology that does not accept freedom and pluralism. Let us respond to the terrorist threat from unity in diversity. And we must do so with the instruments of the rule of law. Every time barbarism strikes us, we repeat the same thing: the need to strengthen the exchange of information between Member States. What does the Council expect to create a true European intelligence agency? We must also ensure that terrorist groups do not take advantage of any legal rifts to fund their death campaign. And, at the same time, we must invest in social inclusion, to give a future to young people who, perhaps disillusioned and marginalized, are dragged away by fanatics. That's why it's critical to tackle terrorist content circulating on social media. These have become a powerful tool for radicalization and recruitment. We will continue to legislate to end misinformation and hate speech. In this regard, Parliament will adopt new rules for online platforms to remove any content that promotes terrorism. I heard Mr Weber today in his speech and some Members of the European People's Group these days. Make no mistake, gentlemen of the European People's Party. Do not intend to place guilt and responsibility on those of us who are working on this issue with the same commitment as you. We need to find a balance that guarantees security but also freedom of expression. We don't want to give up any of them. I would also like to refer to the Schengen debate. Some voices deflight the focus and propose border controls in the Schengen area, linking migration and terrorism. But, as Europol reminds us, there is no conclusive data to link the two phenomena. Schengen is a great achievement of the Union and we must not weaken it by short-term interests. It's always a complicated balance, but we can't sacrifice our freedoms and our open societies for the sake of security. Because then, the violent will have won the battle.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, democracy in the European Union is everyone's business and terrorism tests us. Emotion in the face of the pain of the innocent must become the engine for our action as politicians, because we are co-responsible for the response against atrocity.  On behalf of my group, I stress zero tolerance against intolerants, and that means using the force of the law, of the whole law, but nothing outside the law; means assessing changes in the threat so as not to leave any blind spots that the killers can escape through.  Terrorists are great moral manipulators: they are identified as victims—they, the murderers—and they want to impose their obsessions on us. And no, we are not responsible for their heinous acts, but they can poison many; and, therefore, we need to innovate in the prevention of violent radicalization, especially at local levels; and that is why the work of the school and public opinion against the frameworks of intolerance and in favor of freedom of expression is as important as Samuel Paty knew.  The European Parliament has been very useful in the previous mandate after the Paris attacks, following the attacks in Brussels, Germany, Manchester, Barcelona, Stockholm, Liege, and it must also be so now, after the bombings in Hanau, Paris, Nice, Vienna. Society and victims need answers, recognition and solutions.  In the previous term, Commissioner King or Gilles de Kerchove were really important and so was this Parliament, and now it has to be important again. Great consensus was generated to improve coordination between countries against the financing, against impunity, for the rights of victims; we strengthen Europol.  We intend to develop recommendations from the Special Commission on Terrorism. Terrorism can only succeed in places where institutions are degraded, with incapable rulers, with politicians who discuss what they do not have to discuss, with poorly guided public servants, in broken societies. This is not our case, but it is also true that terrorism is not defeated without effort and commitment.  And we are effectively negotiating with the Council the Regulation on the removal of terrorist content online. It must be effective, it must have the safeguards of rights and freedoms. And we know that those who have the most power have greater responsibility and, therefore, I hope that it will be possible to reach consensus very soon. Of course, my group will not stop fighting without fainting until we get it.  Commissioner, those who are radicalizing must know - and the whole of Europe must know - that we are not going to leave any room or resquicious for their anti-democratic strategy, and our work, when well founded, deactivates them, discourages them.  The novelist Amos Oz once wrote that the essence of fanaticism lies in the desire to force others to change: terrorists have pretended it from cruelty. The Renew Group wants to make it clear that we have reason and reasons to defend freedoms and coexistence. That is our strength, that is our tribute to every innocent victim and his loved ones: not to forget them, to remain effective and to remain free.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr. President, what was attacked in Vienna? What was attacked in Nice and Madrid, Amsterdam, London, Milan, Stockholm, Toulouse, Brussels, Copenhagen, Paris, Berlin, St. Petersburg? Just a few hours ago, the Consul General of France was again targeted in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, while presiding over a ceremony on 11 November. Almost all of our countries are affected and all are threatened. Too many to mention, no victims should be forgotten: 450 people have been killed by Islamist terrorism in Europe, from the vile attack in Madrid in 2004 to the one 10 days ago in Austria. What is under attack is our civilization. You wanted to build the European Union and its treaties by forgetting our Christian roots. You wanted to build a super-state on abstract universal values. You wanted to deny our common past to make a supermarket without identity.  But today, it is our deep being that is being targeted. The Islamists come to remind us. It is not secularism, not colonialism, not even our freedom of expression that they vomit: it is above all what we are. They attack us for who we are, not for what we do. We will not be able to fight this battle if we refuse to designate the enemy. We cannot win it if we refuse to assert and defend our identity. Today, in the Chamber, to deal with this fundamental subject, you are planning only a short debate and a single round of speakers. The title itself carefully avoids the term "Islamism." As our civilization is under attack and besieged, what do you propose to us? Emmanuel Macron, the French president, claims to fight Islamism by strengthening communitarianism, by generalizing the learning of Arabic in schools and taking over the training of imams by the state - a ludicrous idea that Charles Michel, for that matter, immediately took up. So we would have imams trained by the European Union? Will it soon be necessary to have a European Commissioner for Islam? Recently, Mr. Borrel, the High Representative for Foreign Affairs, said it was up to the refugees to decide for themselves whether or not they wanted to return to Syria. And as recently as yesterday, Mrs Johansson, you said, in a mixture of naivety and total irresponsibility, that, I quote, 'migration is not a danger'. Wouldn't migration be a danger, Mrs Johansson? The last three attacks in France were carried out by migrants. He's a Pakistani who attacked journalists in Paris. He's a Chechen who slit the throat of a teacher in Conflans. A Tunisian man who arrived via Lampedusa murdered three people in a church in Nice. Taking advantage of your procrastination and cowardice, Erdogan is also moving forward. Because the European Union does not dare to act, it is waged war on Armenia and Libya, deploying jihadists from the ranks of Daesh. It threatens our continent with migratory submersion. He converted St. Sophia's Basilica into a mosque. Turkey, and with it the Islamists of the world, are part of the longest memory, unlike you. You want to train imams, we want to expel hate preachers. You want Frontex to secure the crossing of migrants, we want Frontex to take them home. You are watering subsidies and customs facilities from Islamist countries like Pakistan or Turkey, we want to punish them. You regard free movement as an untouchable dogma, we consider that the security of Europeans is an inalienable right. You are funding Islamist organizations, we want to dissolve them. Yes, I weigh my words, you finance Islamist organizations. Here in this Parliament, Islamist organizations, such as The Femyso, have been able to participate in official events. When you don't give them a voice, you give them money: 51,000 euros for the CCIF, 584,000 euros for the Islamic Human Rights Watch, which called Charlie Hebdo Islamophobic, 5.6 million euros for the networks of the Muslim Brotherhood. In total, over the last five years, the European Union has paid EUR 36.5 million directly to Islamists or the projects they were associated with - I have sent a written question to the Commission on this subject so that this can finally stop, and I am still waiting for the answer. You want to turn illegal immigration into legal immigration, we want to put an end to illegal migration, family reunification and settlement immigration, because mass immigration is obviously the breeding ground for Islamism. We must stop the arrivals and consider that the welcome and generosity of our countries are not definitive. The installation of foreigners on our soil should not be considered irreversible. If we show weakness, then they will dominate us. If we show cowardice, they will submit us. If we are able, on the contrary, to proudly affirm who we are, we will resist. If we are able to fight forcefully for our values of civilization, we will prevail. Aeschylus already said of the Greeks and, through them, of all Europeans, that they "believe that they are not slaves or subjects of anyone". The time for compromises, of which you are unfortunately often customary, must stop. We must not give in to the injunctions of the Islamists. We will not submit, and all those who want to impose it on us, all those who prefer Sharia law to our laws and our way of life, all those who want to weaken our civilization and replace it with theirs will have to leave. Our freedom is at that price. History has shown that European nations are capable of startling, able to fight together against a common enemy, only in this way will we win this war.

name: Salima YENBOU
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, the brutal murder of Samuel Paty, Nice, Vienna, Kabul: all these innocent victims have in common the desire for freedom. Voltaire said, "I don't agree with what you're saying, but I will fight for you to have the right to say it." But how?  The fight against terrorism is part of the long time, in analysis, in understanding and in action.  The fight against terrorism is above all to promote freedom of expression and education, it is to come out of a binary vision of good and evil, a world that confronts each other, it is to promote fraternity, tolerance. To preserve our rights, duties and values is to transmit them, to educate, to dialogue, to exchange, to cultivate.  The fight against terrorism means promoting an inclusive, egalitarian society on a daily basis, in which no discrimination has a place because terrorism feeds on hatred and divisions of those who suffer the exclusion, oppression, disrespect, and distance of sources of information and education. The fight against schooling, illiteracy, misinformation, for literacy, are constant struggles to be fought among our young people, rich in their diversity. The fight against terrorism is also a fight against ourselves, against our prejudices, our oppressions, against individual and systemic racism. The true doctrine of a fight against terrorism is a doctrine in favour of the citizen of the world, with its culture or its cultures, its history or its his stories, without prioritization, without domination. And these times of crisis are all too often reclaimed by short-termist populist discourses that divide and fuel terrorism, far more than they advance the fight against barbarism. The rights and freedoms that the state must protect risk being restricted by actions that are supposed to defend them. In a security environment, some discriminatory actions gradually become acceptable in response to attacks. Finally, if we renounce respect for human rights, equality and the protection of the rule of law in order to fight terrorism, we risk playing into the game of those who attack us under these values.

name: Nicola PROCACCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I must point out that it is a serious mistake that the adjective 'Islamic' is not being used as the title of this debate, as mrs Johansson has just said. The fear of associating religious motivation with the terrorist attacks that have bloodied Europe in recent days, as in the last twenty years, prevents us from preventing them, as well as combating them. The fear of naming Islam is the most striking demonstration of the effectiveness of the terrorist fight, which not only wants to reap victims among the infidels but above all wants to change the way we think, live and express ourselves. The fear of naming Islam prevents us from bringing out a thought of secularisation among Islamists, of giving courage to those Muslims who want to live in peace in Europe, legitimately professing their religion. The fear of giving things their name leads us to hide the cultural roots of our rights of freedom, which are religious: they are Christian roots, do not pretend not to know! Where do you think we have learned to give Caesar what is Caesar's and God what is God's? Who told us to give the other cheek if I offended? Who taught us to respect women, considering them like men, and who commanded us to defend the oppressed? The fear of making the right choices, even in the fight against illegal immigration, not only discovers the side of our cities and schools to terrorist violence, but at the same time prevents us from identifying upstream those who need humanitarian protection, those who really want to share our system of values, possibly without being forced to put themselves in the hands of the smugglers or risking losing their lives at sea , as has happened again today. We have to govern departures so we don't have to handle arrivals. We don't know how to tell you anymore! I conclude with a warning from a great Italian writer, Cesare Pavese: "always remember that monsters do not die, what dies is the fear that inspires you". Come on, Europe!

name: Manon AUBRY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, in Conflans, in Nice, in Vienna, three times in less than a month, terrorism has struck us in our flesh. On behalf of our group on the European left, I first of all want to join in the messages of emotion and solidarity for the victims of these heinous murders and for their loved ones. While our societies are weakened by the health crisis, the climate catastrophe and the explosion of poverty, this series of abject attacks has a clear political objective: to weaken us by dividing us. And today I issue the warning with seriousness: let us not let them win. The European public debate, by repeating the increasingly hateful rhetoric of the far right, takes a disturbing turn by venturing into the dangerous slope of assumed authoritarianism and uninhibited racism. In France, a witch-hunt was initiated by the government, which sometimes accused opposition parties, university professors, of complicity with terrorists, which implied the existence of a link between the halal shelves of supermarkets and the rise of religious extremism. Politicians across Europe are calling for the creation of new emergency laws to free the fight against terrorism from the most basic rules of law, as if taking back the enemy's methods would protect us from doing so. This is a fundamental fault. On the contrary, in the face of terrorists, the rule of law is not a weakness, it is our most powerful shield. Any questioning of our fundamental freedoms is a defeat in the face of their ambition to bring down our democracies. Any stigmatization of Muslims as scapegoats is a gift for those seeking to revive the wars of religion. These drifts are as dangerous as they are ineffective.  On the contrary, the terrorist threat must be approached firmly and seriously, around an absolute imperative: the maintenance of our cohesion. Of course, we must actively fight against jihadist networks, by providing sufficient resources to our justice and intelligence services, by attacking tax havens and banks that launder the dirty money of terrorists, by profoundly changing our commercial and military alliances with the states that subsidize them. But we must also tackle the breeding ground that allows jihadists to recruit and fundamentalism to thrive. Discrimination, racism, ghettoization, the disappearance of local public services, precariousness, are allies of terrorists. Our duty is to actively combat the systematic relegation of part of our populations. Investment in the education system must finally be our compass. It is our teachers, like Samuel Paty, who teach young people freedom of conscience and expression, the right to caricature, respect for the opinion of others. It is at school that the citizens of tomorrow are formed. Our teachers are the best weapon against obscurantism. So let's not let the terrorists dictate their political agenda and impose the terms of the debate. Let us not fall straight into the trap they set at us and oppose our unfailing unity.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the escalation of terrorist violence in France and Austria reminds us of the serious threat to the Member States of the European Union. Terrorism generates fear, reinforces political extremism, polarises societies, creates tensions between social and religious groups, fuels discrimination, hatred, xenophobia and Islamophobia. It is not only security and public order that are under threat, but also individual rights, peace and social cohesion. We have been fighting for years a varied and complex phenomenon, which acts with evolving operational, communicative and financing methods, which escape in part the efforts of cooperation, monitoring and contrast, especially when the fight moves into the online and digital world, which can offer content and tools used for propaganda, training, recruitment and radicalization. In this context, on issues such as surveillance, detection and removal of online content, if the impact of anti-terrorism legislation on fundamental rights is not assessed in a balanced way, there is a risk of giving certain authorities dangerous tools to combat arbitrariness and abuse, to the detriment of freedom of expression and access to information. The balance between the need for security and fundamental rights is essential for democracy and the rule of law. , affecting the causes. We cannot accept having generations of young people with European citizenship who have a sense of alienation and resentment towards the society in which they live, to the point of embracing jihadist violence as a response to the search for identity, belonging and respect. Integration policies, the aim of each education and education path, must play a leading role in the fight against the processes of extremism and violent radicalisation, promoting tolerance, intercultural dialogue, personal development, full social inclusion and participation in political, social and working life.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you to the Members for a very good debate. Let me first say to Mr Weber that I fully agree that it should be mandatory for all Member States to insert terrorist alerts in the Schengen Information System. As a matter of fact, it is already mandatory, but we have to make sure that everybody also complies. We need to share information better, we need to share better information and we need to remove terrorist content online immediately. To Ms García Pérez, I would say I fully agree that we need to defend the right of free speech, even when we totally disagree with the message, but we will also firmly fight those that seriously threaten these freedoms and these rights. I would say to Mr Bay, migration is not a threat. Today, we have 22 million people in the European Union who are third—country nationals. They have come here to marry a European citizen, they have come here to work here, they have come to do research, to study, they have come here because they need international protection. They are part of our society. Let me tell you about Osama Joda, a 23—year—old Palestinian immigrant in Vienna. He was just five metres away when a police officer got hit in this terrorist attack. He pulled the police officer to safety, he took off his own shirt, he tied it around the officer’s leg to stop the bleeding. You know what? He risked his life despite suffering appalling racism. He was bullied at his job for having the same first name as Osama bin Laden. A mayor also tried to block his family from buying a house because they were Muslims. The aim of the terrorist is to divide our society, is to destroy our unity, is to abolish our values and rights. We will never let them win.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. – Unfortunately, terrorism is once again one of the most important problems that we must fight decisively. Two beheading attacks carried out with blood-curdling cruelty in France and the Vienna shootings that claimed four innocent lives shocked Europe. These events are alarm bells that Europe must wake up and use radical means to counter the threat posed by illegal migration against the people of Europe and the European way of life. European left-wingers are still unable to admit that the wave of terror has something to do with immigration. Until they do, the threat of terrorism will continue to increase and we will witness more attacks. Anti-Semitism, racism and various forms of religious intolerance and discrimination not only threaten the security of individual persons, but can also contribute to creating a climate that is toxic to communities, which is favourable to the rise of terrorism and crime. Education plays a key role in addressing all these conflicts, biased views and prejudices. Teachers thus have a great responsibility, as they can help young people become tolerant citizens who respect others. Hate speech based on prejudice can lead to violence, hate crimes and the emergence of societies in fear. It is therefore important to curb uncontrolled immigration into the EU so that European values and principles can be maintained.

name: Ioan-Rareş BOGDAN
text: in writing. – The terrorist attacks in Paris, Nice, Vienna have severely shaken Europe. The attacks are in fact a direct attack on the fundamental values and principles of the European Union, on our democracies and freedoms. There needs to be a better and more effective exchange of information between Member States and there is a need to increase the protection of public spaces in order to stop such tragic events. Last but not least, the internet is a means by which terrorists incite hatred and gain followers through social media and websites crammed with dedicated messages. I am pleased that the President of the EPP Group in the European Parliament, Manfred Weber, has taken a trenchant position and called for the unblocking of the initiative authorising the elimination within an hour of the content of online platforms promoting such misfortunes. The security of Europeans is non-negotiable. We must show all those who want to induce fear and insecurity that we will not kneel before any attack and that we will fight terrorism by all possible means and that we will at the same time protect the right to freedom of expression and education. With courage and determination we must stop such manifestations and act firmly to combat any kind of terrorism.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. – A professor of history and geography beheaded in Paris for holding a course on freedom of expression, a brutal attack on Notre-Dame Cathedral in Nice where 3 people lost their lives, another in Vienna, where 4 people died and many more were injured. Terrorism continues to bloody Europe, it attacks the freedoms, the fundamental values that underseat our European construction. A strong common response is therefore needed. The initiatives taken at EU level - information exchange, investigative and judicial coordination and the fight against property - must be strengthened in the fight against terrorism and organised crime which, through its trade, especially in drugs and weapons, also provides support and resources to terrorist groups. Together with the Commission's new agenda for combating terrorism, the Union must equip itself with stronger instruments, such as extending the powers of the European Public Prosecutor's Office to include terrorist offences and related financial crimes, providing it with the necessary resources and resources, and also through the strengthening of Europol, in order to create a genuine European intelligence agency. In the face of terrorism, we must respond with determination and firmness, in defence of the citizens of Europe and of our shared values of freedom and peace.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Terrorism is one of the greatest threats of our time, and terrorists are ruthless criminals with no values or moral boundaries. In their attacks with unprecedented cruelty use new techniques and technologies, increasingly geared to media notoriety.
