The recent attacks in France and Austria on a religious and cultural basis only prove how much we still have to do to ensure a high level of security for our citizens. In their activities of incitement, recruitment to terrorist activities and the organisation of acts, terrorists increasingly use information tools, including the internet, while reaching for information dispersion in order to provoke psychosis, chaos and uncontrolled reactions.  It is therefore increasingly difficult in practice to define the line between freedom of expression and human rights violations. By definition, freedom of expression is the right of every individual, but how to set its limits in the face of an imminent threat? That is why we have an extremely difficult task ahead of us. We must remember that security and freedom are complementary and human rights should be at the heart of the counter-terrorism strategy.  The new initiatives and methods we are proposals and methods to prevent and combat terrorism must at the same time ensure that security, human rights and law enforcement are not mutually exclusive, but complementary.

name: Elżbieta KRUK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In view of the level of terrorist threat in western EU countries, the fight against terrorism must not be limited to military and legal-criminal activities. Information and education activities also remain relevant. The private sector and NGOs need to be involved. In this case, however, fundamental civil rights must not be forgotten. Civil liberties cannot be put at risk. Under the Regulation on preventing the dissemination of terrorist content on the Internet, hosting service providers operating within the EU will be required to remove terrorist content. This is right, but be careful not to use the records to block or remove content that is not terrorist propaganda. The implementation of such preventive mechanisms must not restrict the activity of Internet users. The more active role of platforms in combating terrorist content must not lead to censorship, freedom of expression and privacy violations. Therefore, additional safeguards and safeguards are needed to protect the right to freedom of expression. Judicial review of the decision to remove content from the Internet should be ensured. Above all, however, the sources of terrorism in Europe must be combated at the root. The eu's flawed foreign and migration policies have led to a situation where the security of citizens and even the existence of our civilisation are at stake

name: Julie LECHANTEUX
text: In writing. The murder of Professor Samuel Paty, a victim of Islamist barbarism, highlighted the climate of intolerance and hatred that prevails today in some French schools, where freedoms of opinion and expression are the target of unprecedented attacks by an Islamist movement whose model remains that of Sharia, which is incompatible with democracy and the very principles of the republican school , such as secularism and gender equality.  To impose it, some Islamists are ready for the worst atrocities. This murder, like that of the three Christians of the Basilica of Our Lady in Nice, follows a global campaign of hatred against "blasphemous France", orchestrated in particular by the Muslim Brotherhood, Turkey, Qatar and Pakistan. A hate propaganda, relayed in France by the supporters and propagators of this deadly ideology: a galaxy of Islamist associations, some of which have taken to the streets in many European countries.  In the face of this attack on democracy, our European values, we must react. We must denounce and banish, once and for all, the organizations, preachers and foreign nationals who spearhead Islamist ideology and its armed arm in France: terrorism.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Writing. – Europe has once again been confronted with armed bloody attacks by terrorists, motivated by extreme perceptions of religious fanaticism and hate speech, which have cost the lives of many of our fellow human beings and which are only intended to sow terror and damage our principles and values. The attacks in France and Austria show that a difficult new period is beginning for Europe's relations with the extreme Islamist regimes, which must find us all united and in solidarity. We have taken many steps in the fight against terrorism, but we still have a long and difficult road to go. Enhanced cooperation between EU countries and the exchange of information should continue, as they have helped to prevent attacks or limit their attacks. In the last 22 months, 119 terrorist attacks have been prevented on European soil. However, the radicalisation of young Islamists, trained to hate Europe, our democracy and institutions, as well as Islamist propaganda on the internet, which promotes terrorism, must be addressed immediately and targeted. The threats we face are common and common must also be our approach, without discounting our values, freedoms, way of life or the safety of European citizens.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The S&D Group has informed the Chairman of a decision to amend the appointments to delegations. This decision will be included in the minutes of today's sitting and will enter into force on the date of this announcement. I would also like to inform you that we will have to suspend the sitting briefly in order to allow interpreters to change their shifts and to disinfect the booths. The sitting will resume at 7.55 p.m. (The sitting was suspended at 7.25 p.m.)

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Pierre Larrouturou and Olivier Chastel on the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2021 – all sections (2020/1998(BUD)) (A9-0206/2020).  I would like to inform you, as always, that all the debates in this part-session do not accept spontaneous speeches, blue cards or points of order. It also provides for any online requests to speak from Parliament's liaison offices in the Member States.

name: Pierre LARROUTUROU
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, EUR 600 billion, the report we are going to vote on this week to say how climate and social chaos can be avoided, says that an additional 600 billion investments are needed every year.  Faced with governments that did not want to give up a euro, the team that negotiated for the European Parliament got 2 billion more. Thanks to Margarida and has the whole team. Well done, that's really good. But, in conscience, we all know that this budget is not up to scratch.  Mr European Commissioner for the Budget, dear Johannes, Madam Secretary of State, dear Bettina, ladies and gentlemen, I am truly convinced that, in the coming weeks, it is still possible to complete this budget - I mean to complete, not renegotiate it, to complete this budget in order to be up to the task, to give more resources to health, climate and employment.  If we were in a period of stability, if all went well, I would say congratulations, thank you, and I would stop my hunger strike. But we all know that we are facing three historic crises, three crises on a scale never seen before.  To deal with the health crisis, we need immediately more resources for hospitals, we need more resources for research, to find new vaccines, to prevent future pandemics. To deal with the social crisis 18 months ago, Ursula von der Leyen said: we are heading for a new economic crisis and to avoid a surge in unemployment, all Member States will have to be allowed to develop the Kurzarbeit. Ursula von der Leyen said: Europe must help every country protect jobs. The Kurzarbeit system is very simple: if a company is facing an economic shock, instead of laying off a third of employees, it lowers working time, wages are lowered, aid is maintained by 95% of income. Ursula von der Leyen said: we are heading for an economic shock, we must avoid a surge in unemployment, Europe must help the Member States. Why is there not a line or a billion for these employment protections today? To cope with the ecological crisis, some believe that, with the economic crisis, the evolution of CO2 has calmed down. Alas, that is not true. Wildfires in 2020 have reached an all-time high. Australia's wildfires: 440 dead - 440 dead in Australia in wildfires! Forest fires in Siberia, America, make 2020 the worst year for CO2 developments. Of course, CO2 is directly linked to slowed economic activity, but overall it's going to be one of the worst years, so we can't wait to act on climate.  We must act forcefully. Humanity no longer has time for the policies of small steps. Humanity wants us to stop the rubbish, it is time to propose a new deal for Europe. As we all know, my friends, Europe is at a crossroads. We are all aware that the mix of the social crisis, the climate crisis and the health crisis can lead us to collapse. It was said the other day in the Committee on Budgets, with the crisis of 1929, Europe has sunk into barbarism, and we all know that the current crisis is worse than the crisis of 29. And we are not, collectively, up to the task. But with the rule of unanimity, I think it was impossible to do better, our negotiating team did the maximum. The rule of unanimity is impossible to continue like this. With unanimity, it is the stupidest, the most selfish, the most blind to the dangers of the medium term, which can block any negotiation. No human group operates with unanimity - neither a football club, nor a choir, nor a company, nor a democratic parliament. Unanimity is paralysis.  That is why, in the report we are going to adopt this week on the financing of the Green Pact, we say that we must get out of unanimity and relaunch with closer cooperation, without delay, the negotiation on the financial transaction tax, with 10 or 15 countries. We cannot, in the name of unanimity, block means for health or climate. In this report, we call for the speeding up of this enhanced cooperation on a financial transaction tax that would bring in $57 billion, as is marked in the report. Parliament wants the real tax on financial transactions, not the very small one. Yes my friends, it's time to invent something new! If we want to avoid chaos in the next 10 or 15 years, it is time to propose a new deal for Europe. New deal: this is the name of my party in France, in reference to Roosevelt's New Deal. And when Mrs. von der Leyen talks about a Green New Deal, it's obviously a reference to Roosevelt's New Deal. But for Roosevelt, it wasn't just beautiful speeches.  Roosevelt has given himself the means to create millions of jobs, he has tripled the federal budget. He tripled the federal budget and wanted a balanced budget. That's why he creates a tax on millionaires, that he introduces a tax on corporate profits. The bankers are furious and say that Roosevelt is a communist who will kill America. But Roosevelt stands firm, he did not kill America. On the contrary, as Europe was moving towards barbarism, Roosevelt saved social cohesion and saved democracy, and the United States was able to help Europe afterwards. So, yes, when you have a real ambition, you have a real budget.  What is our ambition today, what are the means we give ourselves? I would like here, together with Bettina Hagedorn - you represent the Council of Heads of State and Government - I would like to address Mrs Merkel and Mr Macron.  Mrs Merkel and Mr Macron, by your statement of 18 May, you really had a catalysis effect, a catalytic effect. You have proposed a very courageous plan: 500 billion common debts for a stimulus package. Obviously, at the beginning, there were four countries that said no, no, never. But two months later, the momentum was so strong that everyone agreed to a plan of almost 400 billion investments. It was impossible, but you did, and Parliament thanks you for that. Similarly, if we want to find ways to get more money for hospitals, for climate, for research, for employment, it is still possible to find new resources. It is possible to launch very quickly - we have been talking about it for nine years, the directive has been on the table for nine years, it has been nine years since we did the impact study which shows that it is possible - it is possible to create a tax very quickly on financial transactions with the countries that want it. Show, Mrs Merkel and Mr Macron, that your commitment is serious.  Mrs Merkel, you absolutely want a climate agreement, an ambitious agreement on 10 and 11 December, and you are absolutely right. You have been interested in climate for 25 years - you were the one who hosted the first climate summit in Berlin 25 years ago. But the only way to get a real ambitious agreement on 10 and 11 December is to unlock funding, otherwise many countries will block the climate agreement, and that is dramatic. In the coming month, the European Parliament is proposing a lot of its own resources, but the only one that is technically ready, I repeat (1,200 pages of impact study), the only one that Parliament supports and which more and more countries support - Poland, Belgium were hostile five years ago and now agree - is the financial transaction tax. My friends, humanity no longer has time for small-step policies. Climate scientists tell us that 2020 is much worse than they thought. Climate change is collapsing and the social crisis can lead us to a democratic crisis. We do not know which countries will still be democratic in five or ten years if we continue like this. It is time to take strong initiatives. In May 1950, Adenauer and Schuman, to avoid war, took a historic initiative. Schuman says: "World peace cannot be preserved without creative efforts, to the extent of the dangers that threaten it." This is why Germany and France are offering their neighbours a limited but decisive initiative. A limited but decisive initiative is to combine coal and steel. We had been at war for decades, and in just two weeks, in two weeks, Schuman and Adenauer decided to combine coal and steel. Adenauer said, "It was the happiest day of my life, I saw the sky open before me." My friends, I think we have done a lot of work to negotiate the current budget and that it is urgent to supplement it, to have new resources for climate, health, employment. Mrs Merkel, you are a great European, it is time to take a limited but decisive initiative: Europe was born with coal and steel, it can be reborn with a climate, health and employment project financed by a tax on speculation.

name: Olivier CHASTEL
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, at first glance, I would like to first of all, of course, welcome the political agreement reached in the multi-year financial framework and on the recovery plan, as well as the exceptional work of our negotiating team. The European Parliament has been able to move the Lines of the Council: this is a first, it is a real victory and we must congratulate ourselves on it.  By voting on our budget proposal for 2021, we are responding concretely to the concerns of European citizens who are facing an unprecedented long-term health and economic crisis every day, with the economy contracting by more than 7% this year. We cannot disappoint them with European programmes that have been planned when they have not yet recovered from the first wave of this crisis and are already facing the second. When Member States make decisions on major research health policies, the transfer of these powers must go hand in hand with adequate financial and human resources. That is why the European Parliament has been a tireless advocate for an ambitious budget for months. We are asking for a substantial additional budget for the 2021 budget to finance the European Union's flagship programmes: Erasmus, EU4health, Horizon Europe and InvestEU. We want to be able to make people understand that European solidarity is not limited to slogans, that European values are not empty words, that only real solidarity from 2021 will ensure the financing of structural reforms and the effectiveness of the Union's policies. Our budget, which is the first year of the multi-year fiscal framework, must be able to support a facility for a sustainable and resilient 4-year recovery. The Council has chosen an arithmetic approach to the amounts proposed by the Commission for 2021 for several programmes, based on the position of the European Council and without identifying any real political priorities. Cuts to the Union's flagship programmes, clearly forward-looking, such as climate and digital transition, health, research and youth and culture, are already undermining the very foundations of this recovery. In these particularly difficult times for entrepreneurship, youth, the hospital environment, or civil society, Europe proposes an exit from the crisis, bringing collective and solidarity projects. Only a common political will has enabled us to conclude an ambitious, fair and balanced political agreement on the next multi-year financial framework. The principle of just return is outdated. The conciliation that will open on 17 November is crucial and it is equally crucial to make full use of it: 21 days of conciliation in a constructive and open spirit so that, through frank and honest exchanges, we meet the legitimate expectations of European citizens from 2021. We must learn from this major crisis and build the foundations of European sovereignty in terms of health, digital, industrial and even security, in order to be able to deal with current and future challenges by freeing up European decisions that bring about sustainable investments and human cooperation at the service of all European citizens. Ladies and gentlemen, the 2021 budget is also the budget of our institution, the European Parliament, and indeed of the other institutions. It is clear that policies that will lead to the future cannot be built without operational, efficient, modern, environmentally friendly and interactive institutions that are therefore capable of functioning, even in the event of a force majeure.  That is why, together with my colleagues from the five main political groups, we have decided to restore the Council's cuts, at the request of the institutions, when they were justified, because here too, the Council has made proposals for horizontal and systematic cuts, without taking into account the specifics of the institutions. Adopting such an approach would have hindered their functioning and would have reduced the vital contribution they make to the proper functioning of the Union, in the same state of mind.  And on the basis of this same approach, we have restored the staffing table. Finally, with regard to the Commission's proposals for cuts, we considered in a limited number of cases that it was necessary to restore the estimates of these institutions. And I will conclude, Madam President, by pointing out that a euro spent in the European budget saves much more than one euro in our various capitals, on the basis of the principle of budgetary subsidiarity. Member States should consider payments to the European Union, not as spending, but as investments in a globalised world, where Europe must be able to deal on an equal footing with China, Russia and the United States, thanks to European autonomy essential to defend the interests of our citizens and future generations.

name: Olivier CHASTEL
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I’m really grateful for the opportunity to address you even under these very difficult circumstances and I’m also happy to see that Mr Larrouturou is with us and still quite well and I hope it stays like this. Let me first congratulate all of you on the political agreement concerning the Multiannual Financial Framework, which we all could reach just yesterday. Indeed, it required serious compromises on both sides, but it came just in time, and it shows that the Union is ready to act. This unprecedented agreement is historic both in size and magnitude. At times, when the epidemiological situation is worsening, and economic forecasting is predicting challenging times for our companies, citizens and regions. This demonstrates the Union’s ability to act. As you know, the MFF is a pre-condition for having the annual budget and all the programmes adopted. Ultimately, the envelopes for Union programmes depend on the final agreed MFF ceilings.  The Commission will therefore work tirelessly to introduce the budgetary impact of the MFF agreement in the annual budget procedure as quickly as possible.  We were just about to conclude our work on the amending letter but now we are happy to finalise it taking the MFF agreement into account.  I hope that this will enable us to swiftly come to an agreement on the 2021 budget in the conciliation. I think we can all agree that recent agreements should not directly be re-opened, especially considering the sweat and tears that went into this MFF agreement.  Concerning the budget nomenclature, we have, at the technical level, worked proactively with the Parliament and the Council to find the right balance between flexibility and transparency. The amending letter will provide proposals, which should meet the main concerns. On the substance of the Council and the Parliament position, I would like to address one issue also raised by State Secretary Hagedorn last time when we met in this Chamber few weeks ago. This concerns the proposal to reduce 162 posts in the Commission’s establishment plan of which 140 posts relate to staff increases in the Union’s decentralised agencies.  While we fully share the objective to ensuring the efficiency of our administration, I simply cannot accept the rationale in offsetting increases in posts for decentralised agencies by cutting Commission posts. The decentralised agencies work in areas where Member States agree that resources are better pooled for activities that would otherwise have to be performed by national administrations: border control or food safety are just two examples. The Commission doesn’t perform these tasks and the pooling of national activities in the decentralised agencies has no impact on the workload within the Commission. Therefore, I urge the Council and the Parliament to reconsider their position on this.  Let me just remind you of the next steps in the annual budgetary procedure. Firstly, we will present the aforementioned amending letter by the end of this week. Secondly, we will also present the executability letter in the coming days. It’s one of the Commission’s inputs for the conciliation. The executability letter provides the assessment of the implementability of the amendments proposed by the Parliament and the Council.  I am now fully confident that, after reaching the difficult and important MFF compromise, we will also be able to agree on how to translate it into the 2021 budget.  There’s no margin for failure in the draft budget 2021 calendar. The conciliation, which starts this coming Tuesday, 17 November, is our one and only shot to find an agreement on the next annual budget. Now, the negotiating teams will, with their political agreement on the MFF, pave the way to an agreement on the 2021 budget as well.  We have only these 21 days until December 7 to reach an agreement. So I trust we all understand the heavy responsibility that this places on everyone, because what is an MFF without an annual budget?  Let’s make every single day count and work together proactively and constructively. This is critical if we want the Union’s response to the crisis to continue at full force next year.  I have to say my services and I are available at all times to help this process because, once again, we cannot lose any time and it’s our one and only last shot, if you like, and this is something which has to be fixed in due time in order to really to enable us, starting on 1 January next year to implement what is necessary in the interest of our citizens.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. Madam President, next year's budget is very important, as it is the first with the new multiannual financial framework and will be a model for those who follow. We need to support neighbouring countries in the challenges they face; As the Committee on Foreign Affairs we have decided to follow a more detailed record of how European money is distributed. We cannot accept the European Commission's proposal for general budget lines that deprive the European Parliament of political control over which countries and actions are financed by us. We stop funding the governments of Turkey, Azerbaijan and Belarus, because a prerequisite for receiving European funding is to respect human rights, the rule of law and international law. It is unacceptable for the Union to fund those who systematically violate our principles and values. Money in these countries will only go to civil society. Finally, the latest events in Ngorno-Karabakh make it all the more timely and imperative for the Council to accept our proposal.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development. Allow me, Madam President, to begin my speech with two quotations. The first: "Money is not everything, but nothing is nothing without money." I do not know who is the author, but the second quote I can attribute to Woody Allen, who said, "Money is important, if only for financial reasons."  I think he is absolutely right and, for us, the agent is important, for financial and political reasons. We have just adopted our multi-year financial framework and I want to congratulate all our teams, who have done some hard work, who have managed to move the lines and deserve our respect. The next seven years at least will be marked by the fruit of their efforts. We have succeeded in making it clear to policy makers that there is no question of letting Italy down, that there is no question of letting down Spain, Portugal, France, the countries of the South, the countries of the East. There was a Franco-German initiative , and the rapporteur referred to it a few moments ago - which gave the necessary political scope to the initiative of the European Parliament, which had already decided before on a very ambitious recovery plan. Perhaps the only small complaint that could be made about this stimulus package is that it might, with the second wave of COVID, not be enough.  But with the political prowess that we have been able to do, I think there, too, we will find an answer. I hope that the needs will not be too great, but in any case the political reflexes of the Union are starting to work. As my friend and colleague Valérie Hayer said this morning, for the first time in 50 years, we are creating new resources of our own. This is a real success and, even if that money does not go directly into the budget, it will help us pay off the debts incurred in the months that follow.  2021 may be a healthy year, it will be the first year of the budget cycle, it will also be the first year that will be a test of resistance for the new clause respecting fundamental rights. This stress test should not be postponed until 2022. No, it is now, because it is now that we must fight against violations. They have taken place, they are still taking place and, when I hear the political speeches of some Member States, they are not disappearing, these violations, so we are going to have to be very vigilant.  Finally, as co-reporter on the NDICI, I would like to say that 2021 may also be the first year that the European Parliament will be able to benefit from new political prerogatives in terms of programming. I believe that our Parliament has a say, and will have to have a say in the budgetary programming of the next round in the context of our external relations.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. – Madam President, Commissioner, today we are debating the safer 2021 budget. We have known since yesterday the European Union budget for the next seven years.  The latest economic forecasts point to a fall in GDP in the euro area above 7%. 2021 will continue to be a very uncertain year, with consequences not yet measurable.  This week, two news stories gave hope to a better 2021 and better prosperity: a vaccine on a short horizon, after the success of tests announced; a political agreement on an enhanced financial framework for the July European Council conclusions and higher than the current 2014-2020 framework. An agreement providing for new own resources aligned with the Political Priorities of the European Union.  We have to invest in retirement, investment and job creation. A recovery that must protect and innovate: protecting those who have been most affected by these uncertainties (women, young people, children, precarious workers); innovate in the economy. This time, we didn't make the mistakes of the last crisis. A more unequal society is a society with less confidence, more unstable, insecure and subject to radicalism that we reject.  We must invest in the future, the new generations and ensure the climate and digital transition. Europe is showing vision. Financial markets recognize; citizens renew confidence. This 2021 budget is the gateway to the European Union's contribution to economic and social recovery, but it has a fundamental challenge: the entry into force of the Multiannual Financial Framework and, consequently, the European programmes on 1 January, and to do so there is still a long timetable to be met, in particular, in the negotiation of programme regulations.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – Madam President, (start of speech off mic) ... in the negotiations setting up the budget for the next seven years.  The outcome is particularly important as it increases Horizon Europe by EUR 4 billion; Horizon Europe being key in enabling innovation horizontally in all sectors, and ultimately delivering on the Union remaining competitive worldwide.  I would also like to take this opportunity to emphasise the major increase dedicated to EU4Health. The 2021 budget should be using the entire available margin to strengthen those EU programmes that contribute to the digital and green transformation.  As the rapporteur for the Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) opinion and chair of ITRE Committee, I would like to recall the important role of the EU agencies and the role they are playing in helping to achieve policy objectives set by the legislator. Therefore, I would like to highlight the need to strengthen the agencies under the ITRE remit with sufficient funding and staffing, in line with their tasks and responsibilities. Particularly important in supporting the energy transition expected in the coming years is the Agency for Cooperation of Energy Regulators, which needs substantial reinforcement.

name: Leszek MILLER
text: IMCO rapporteur. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The coronavirus pandemic crisis has seriously affected almost all sectors of the European economy. We are now facing a recurrence of this pandemic, which will only exacerbate existing socio-economic problems.  In this context, the need for urgent and efficient funding for small and medium-sized enterprises is a prerequisite for economic recovery. Although work on the new financial framework has not yet been finalised, I believe that the new budget should be a strong funding centre for sustainable development, innovation, strategic infrastructure and digital transformation. This will make the single market stronger and more resilient.  There is a particular need to create synergies between the Single Market Programme and the Reconstruction Fund in order to mobilise the necessary investments.  The COVID-19 crisis has highlighted the single market's dependence on global supply chains and producers, as well as the dangers of product insecurity. It is therefore crucial to develop a robust consumer policy that ensures an appropriate level of protection for consumers.  Restoring the confidence of Union citizens in the market is key to boosting demand and economic recovery. We believe that the draft budget for 2021 creates such opportunities.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has We all have big plans together when it comes to transport policy: digitisation, automation, reduction of emissions. But it also needs money. Our problem today is that the demands are large and the purse is small. Bringing that together a little bit was our interest. Let us take one example, alternative infrastructure: there are now 125 hydrogen filling stations throughout the European Union – 125! There are a bit more than 20,000 fast charging stations. The Commission itself has said that we need one million fast charging stations by 2025 – we currently have just over 20 000. Just to give a few examples of the need for investment in infrastructure. That is why we in the Committee on Transport have tabled proposals to increase the Connecting Europe Facility, greater funding for the Aviation Safety Agency, greater funding for the European Maritime Safety Agency and the financing of a pilot project to increase transparency in public procurement. And I hope that this will also be enforced in the negotiations.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. Madam President, the EU budget for 2021 needs to be adjusted to fully take account of the COVID-19 pandemic. Our REGI Committee recalls the central role that cohesion policy will play in 2021 in mitigating the economic and social impacts of COVID, as well as in the recovery from the pandemic. We also recall the very essential contribution of cohesion policy in the emergency responses that have already benefited the regions of Europe, through the CRII and CRII Plus regulations that we have adopted here, in plenary, for the use of ESI funds in response to the pandemic. We also note that the implementation of these measures will lead to an increased need for payment appropriations, which will have to be taken into account in the budget for the 2021 fiscal year if we are to, Commissioner Hahn, that all projects committed are paid for. We also welcome the creation of the REACT-EU programme, which will make additional funds available to the ERDF, as well as the ESF and FEADER. We are almost at the end of the current trilogue on REACT-EU. We will have a final agreement trilogue next week, deadlines are being met and REACT-EU funds will be able to deploy on time. Finally, we consider that the European Union's stimulus package is an important step towards a fair and sustainable recovery. However, we fear, given the freedoms granted to The Member States, that cohesion objectives, including the reduction of territorial divides, will be lost along the way.

name: Martin HLAVÁČEK
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries. – Madam President, as the representative of the Fisheries Committee, I’m observing the developments of the proposed budget with great concerns. The 2021 budget is of particular importance for the entire fisheries and aquaculture sector, and it comes at a time of severe economic instability. The new European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF) should help the sector to meet the new objectives of the EU, in particular, to deliver on the Green Deal, and that comes with significant costs. This alone would have well justified an  increase in the budget for 2021 but, not only is the budget in decline, but the sector is in difficulty and facing unprecedented crisis. The sector is suffering from the consequences of the massive drop in demand for fisheries and aquaculture product throughout Europe. We don’t even know yet how many waves of lockdowns will hit Europe, we don’t know how long and often restaurants and hotels will remain closed in the majority of Member States, with substantially reducing demand for fisheries and aquaculture products and business opportunities for our fishermen. The amounts proposed by the Commission are well below what is needed: a drop by 13.5% in comparison to 2020. The Council position is even worse. This is simply irregular, irresponsible and unacceptable for us in the Fisheries Committee. This is why the text proposed by our committee for the plenary raises direct management for the EMFF. It would bring it in line with Parliament’s original position on the multiannual financial framework (MFF) and also it would help the sector and those in need to act fast and get help very fast. This is why we in the European Parliament must vote in defence of our fisheries sector and in favour of the amendments presented by the Fisheries Committee. Only this could help equip the EMFF with the real strike for 2021.

name: Romeo FRANZ
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I welcome the breakthrough in the MFF negotiations and, in particular, that there should be a little more funding for forward-looking programmes for the next seven years, and therefore also for the 2021 budget. But the increase in funding falls far short of Parliament's demands to triple the budget for Erasmus+ and to double that for Creative Europe. Both programmes are of great importance for both social cohesion and the economic development of the Union as a strategic investment in the future. Educational opportunities, youth exchanges and cultural cooperation are important building blocks for promoting open, tolerant and inclusive societies, and very effective means of strengthening our democracy, combating racism, nationalism and inequality.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are experiencing an unprecedented crisis. The responses that the European Union gives to its citizens are decisive for our future, for families and for businesses and, today more than yesterday, I am convinced that we must build a bridge between institutions and citizens, because Europe works for them and for us. This has been highlighted in the report in which the Committee on Constitutional Affairs sets out some clear priorities. Firstly, the increase in funds devoted to promoting the involvement and participation of citizens in the democratic life of the Union. Secondly, the inclusion of a chapter of expenditure devoted to the conference on the future of Europe. If there is no funding, it is not possible to hold the conference, and the Commission has done well to significantly increase investment in communications services, but we need a further effort to combat disinformation. I believe that we must also increase the fund available to the Commission representations and Parliament's liaison offices in the Member States. The agreement reached yesterday between the Council and Parliament reaffirms the centrality of this House as a body that has control over the budgetary procedure, and the Committee on Constitutional Affairs therefore considers it essential to ensure the transparency of our budgets. We therefore call not only for Parliament to make an analysis of the various stages of the implementation of the budget, but also for a regular publication of how the funds are spent and what results are achieved.

name: Robert BIEDROŃ
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality. – Madam President, we in the Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM) Committee are glad that Parliament’s position reflects so well the important issues of gender budgeting and that so many of FEMM’s recommendations have been taken into account.  There is no doubt that gender-responsive budgeting must be mainstreamed in the 2021 general budget as well as in future budgets to better align policies promoting the equal participation of women in the labour market. This is particularly important in times of the COVID-19 crisis, which poses a serious risk of rolling back decades of gains achieved in gender equality in labour market participation. Thus, we welcome the reinforcement of employment and social innovation strands to support programmes and training targeted at advancing women’s participation and tackling their precarity on the labour market. It is also extremely important to secure the Daphne strand to fight violence against girls and women, which has escalated over the last few months.  However, the greatest challenge is still, unfortunately, ahead of us. No real progress can be achieved without a real – I underline real – Council commitment to prioritising gender equality as well, and respect of human rights must also be a part of all Member States’ governments’ policy.

name: Angelika WINZIG
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has had on the work of the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work The EU budget for 2021 is overshadowed by the Corona pandemic, the EU long-term budget and the new development plan, and is therefore different from the previous ones.  However, one thing always remains the same, namely our duty as MEPs to use our citizens' taxpayers' money sparingly and efficiently. The financial resources are not there to make up for past failures in the Member States, but they must be channelled into our defined objectives. Investments in research, innovation, education, digitisation, the competitiveness of our European businesses, the security of supply by our farmers, but also in general security guarantee a high quality of life for our citizens and keep us on an equal footing with the other world powers. The rule of law as a guarantor of democracy must be the DNA of the European Union, and therefore a causal link between the allocation of funds on the one hand and respect for our values is imperative. Our strong European community of values is not invulnerable, as we unfortunately saw last week in Vienna as a result of this terrorist attack. My sincere condolences are therefore due to the families and friends of the victims. Protecting the European way of life, the mandate of the European Commission, therefore also requires a common European action against right-wing and left-wing extremism as well as against political Islam. Now, more than ever, it is important to defend our European values, our system. President Sassoli, I would like to make one more request: please also give us the opportunity to take part in the debate in the region. It makes little sense for all Members to make a pilgrimage to the capitals now.

name: Nils UŠAKOVS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the EU budget 2021 will be the first one of the new MFF. It will also become the first sign and symbol of European ambitions for the next seven years.  I will start with key programmes. Enhancing Horizon Europe is highly important to boost the digital transformation. This is pretty straightforward. The COVID crisis has shown us all how much we depend on technologies – technologies which are both not perfect and not equally available to every EU country and every European.  Investment in research and innovation must both bring new advanced solutions and narrow the gap between Member States, regions and social groups. Fighting digital inequality will in future be as crucial as fighting social or any other inequalities we are dealing with right now.  As part of the overall MMF deal, the flagship programme Horizon Europe will receive an additional EUR 4 billion for research and innovation – which is great news for European scientists – and that means we have to stand for a corresponding increase in annual allocation for 2021 already.  The COVID crisis has proved once again that medical workers and healthcare systems are probably as important as military personnel and armies. Our enemy right now is invisible and we need medicine and vaccines, rather than guns and bombs, to defeat it. EU4Health is the answer to major cross-border health threats and one of the much-needed steps to create a European Health Union.  An additional EUR 3.4 billion as part of the MFF triples the budget of the programme. We all understand that in order to meet current challenges and to prepare for future ones, we need to increase financing for 2021 significantly. This budget is crucial in order to increase the quality of healthcare systems around Europe and their affordability and of course in order to deal with inequalities between Member States and regions.  Another of the enhanced 15 flagship programmes to mention is Erasmus+. It is our strategic investment – investment in our youth, in social cohesion, in European integration. It is investment in our values, identity and heritage that we wish to pass on to future generations. The investment means EUR 2.2 billion of additional money for the next 7 years, and at least EUR 165 million next year. At the same time I would like to outline that Europe can afford much more for its values. The 2021 budget is a good tool in helping us in both enhancing and rethinking the way European institutions work during the COVID crisis and after it, when the ‘new normal’ will arrive. Starting with the European Parliament itself, all the institutions are fighting with the challenges of teleworking in 24 different languages, with different quality of internet and technical advancement around the continent. Nevertheless, they all work hard, bringing Europeans and their ideas together, like for instance the Committee of the Regions or the European Economic and Social Committee.  Our experience from previous economic crises tell us, ‘cut down the estimates for institutions’. That is not the case this time. The estimates for the other institutions and agencies take into account both the tasks to be performed next year and the level of possible transformation that each institution may go through, finding the best suitable way to work in future.  I wish us all good luck in the forthcoming negotiations with the Council.

name: Valérie HAYER
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the mother of all battles is coming to an end and already a new budgetary joust is starting, the first of this new framework, reinforced by us as recently as yesterday. Much has already been said today, I will not go into detail about the additional reinforcements hoped for in this text. I will just point out that the Commission, Commissioner, as you have pointed out, will rectify its proposal on the basis of the agreement reached yesterday. And, undoubtedly, there will have to be adjustments. Beyond the numbers, the important thing is the political message we will send: what priorities for the Union in 2021? The Union which will still suffer from the effects of the pandemic. Personally, I think we need a budget that focuses on recovery, a smart, green, digital and solidarity recovery.  It is this recovery that will bring prosperity back to us and protect the most vulnerable among us. So, yes, to put the package on health and research and innovation. Our economies will be better off and our jobs can be multiplied. But where to find the money? Less VAT, our customs duties have decreased because of the slowdown in our trade and, it must be said, because of the 5.5 billion that we leave to the Member States to do the job, to fill out paperwork, to control goods, a job that is far too expensive, without a doubt. But it takes what it takes to buy the consent to Europe of certain heads of state and government. As a result, by 2021, we will still have to go to the states to adjust our finances. Fortunately, dear friends, all this will soon be ancient history. Our collective fight for the creation of new recipes was decisive. They will be created, tomorrow we will have a carbon adjustment mechanism at the borders, a tax on the digital giants, a tax on financial transactions. Pierre is no longer here but I invite him to work together to make this tax happen. These own resources, once created, will enable the Union to take responsibility. This is the vision that I carry, that we carry and that we will carry to the end. Thank you Pierre, thank you Olivier for this long-term work.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner Hahn, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to make a personal comment first, as Mrs Winzig said at the very end of her speech: I think that these rules, that you can only talk in one or two places in your country, are very, very hindering. And I wish we could find a different solution here soon and return to the plenary session as we are used to. This is really a de facto exclusion of one of the parliamentarians from Parliament, and how is the work to be done? I see a major problem here, and I really cannot judge it any other way than to quote from my group: 'The distance participation is unfortunately appropriate and not an appropriate substitute for actual hearings and debates'. We cannot bear this in the long run. I therefore ask that we really take this point to heart.  In addition to this disempowerment of Parliament, on the one hand, there is a certain degree of self-empowerment by Parliament when it comes to the budget now. Why do I call it that? Now, even the President-in-Office of the Council, Mr Michel, said recently, three weeks ago, that please stop asking us to keep asking for money. In the end, we cannot do that.  Today we have received these sixteen billion, but basically the task of a Parliament as guardian of the budget is being turned completely on its head. Normally, as the Committee on Budgets, we should also ensure that money is used sparingly and economically. The exact opposite is being done here: one uses the existing crises – which are unfortunately there of God – and, to a certain extent, in the shadow of these crises, one hangs on to it and demands more and more money and really inflates this budget until it is almost unsustainable and bursts. And that's a big problem.  And another problem that is not addressed is the question: where do you take the money from? Unfortunately, the revenue will not flow next year, but the 46 billion that Mrs Marques, or who ever spoke of, will only arrive in five years' time. Next year, we will have only one of the six new own resources, namely this plastic levy for packaging. Do you really believe that with this money all the programmes that you now want to re-run can be supported with it? That is completely impossible.  We need to get back to sound, normal financial management. We must do what a budgetary legislator has to do again: he must control the Commission, cut the Council – even in its claims – and make sure that the money remains in his pocket, otherwise the return carriage will come. Next year at the latest – a super election year in Germany – the electorate will choose to say that if I feel the hole in my house, in my pocket, I will no longer trust this current Parliament.

name: David CORMAND
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all thank you to the rapporteurs, Mr Larrouturou and Mr Chastel, on this draft budget for 2021. That has been said, it is the first one that is part of a multi-year budget cycle that we discussed earlier in the afternoon. The message I want to send is that there is an urgent need to stop waiting for ecological transition. We know we have 10 years to act and make a difference, so it is time to accelerate. In this budget, there are some very positive advances from this point of view, with the 30% climate, 10% biodiversity, with the idea, of course, not to use the remaining percentages of the budget to destroy what is being implemented with the climate criteria and biodiversity criteria. This is one of the issues on which we will continue to debate. To also say that, in this report, there is this 60% percentage, which is consistent with the 60% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030, to remember that it is 65% that would be needed, that is the spirit of the amendment I have tabled. Also increase the budget of Parliament's Environment Directorate General to push and work on the ecological transition. And then, in the logic of transparency, we talked about the budget that is going to be needed for the COVID vaccine. An amendment has also been proposed to make these mega-contracts transparent, which is very important. In conclusion, we are therefore part of this urgent will to act. Today's "later" will be the "too late" tomorrow if we do not act now. President Biden's administration, which has just been elected, has a $2 trillion green transition plan. We are a long way off, so we have to target our spending.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We are talking today about the 2021 budget: indeed, a very important issue. This budget is linked to the Multiannual Financial Framework and to the reconstruction tool.  We are certainly all aware that Europe is going through an economic crisis, a pandemic crisis, but also the safety of the people of the Union in general. On the other hand, however, we have 15 very active flagship programmes, as referred to in the resolution of 23 July this year. These included health programmes, the Connecting Europe Facility, Horizon Europe, InvestEU, the Just Transition Fund, the European Neighbourhood Instrument. All these flagship programmes are extremely important for Europe's development. And I want to make it very clear m.in. that is why the ECR will vote in favour of the compromise on budgetary amendments.  However, there is a problem with the resolution. And here I will say right away that we will abstain because we believe that the 60% climate targets by 2030 are unworkable and will cost the European Union a great deal. The implementation of the rule of law mechanism also undermines European solidarity. The resolution also calls for more budgetary resources to support sexual and reproductive rights, and we do not like that too, which is why we will abstain.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, the pandemic, with its fierce second wave, sends a strong message of danger but also a signal to the European Union. We need a more and better Europe in order to be able to achieve public health support, a sustainable and strong recovery of the economy in 2021 and to achieve the objectives set. That is why the European Parliament is demanding a budget for 2021 that is stronger, more ambitious, more socially oriented than the Commission's proposal and much more so than the cuts made by the Council in the Commission's proposal. That is why we support the Larrouturou and Chastel report as a political group; I hope that the adoption of the Larrouturou and Chastel report by a large majority will also give a boost to the tripartite dialogue, so that the Commission and the Council can take steps towards the views of the European Parliament in order to support cohesion policies, farmers and gender equality, together with the necessary effort for climate objectives and the digitisation of the economy. To support employment and to work effectively — in practice and not in words — to combat growing inequalities.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Mr. Chairman, when we talk about the 2021 budget, we are talking about the first of seven years that come to us in a seven-year financial sheath. When we talk about the 2021 budget, we are talking about the reimbursement that we have paid into Europe, in the European budget. It's not a good budget. I'd like to list, say, the Horizon 2030 program, which was supposed to have up to 140 billion euros in seven years. You cut him to just $85 billion, ironically, yesterday on World Day of Science for Peace and Development.  But let's also mention the way money is spent, that is, how its consumption is controlled. I had the personal honor of a few weeks to be in Bulgaria and their capital Sofia where I had the opportunity to speak. I have had the privilege of speaking in front of tens of thousands of protesters who have been protesting against the Bulgarian government for four months. Citizens were outraged that the European Union, now 13 years after Bulgaria's entry into the European Union, was funding the Bulgarian establishment. At the same time Bulgaria is, unfortunately, among the poorest countries in Europe.  My Croatia is also right alongside Bulgaria among the poorest countries in Europe, and in Croatia citizens are outraged at how money from European funds is spent. There is no effective control of European funds in Croatia de facto. When an irregularity is detected, it is reported to OLAF. OLAF puts this down to a national body, AFCOS, which is part of the Ministry of Finance and according to their own claims, they do not have the mechanisms to control how this money is spent. They send an inquiry to the Croatian State Attorney's Office, which is traditionally ineffective, on the one hand, and on the other hand, to the very body that tenders, to control itself. So he wonders the thief if he's a thief. He replies that he is not a thief and it is concluded that there is nothing wrong with this money. Instead of wasting money in this way, it would have been better if we had opened a universal basic income scheme and distributed that money to citizens.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: – Mr President, Dear Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, we cannot fail. 2021 must be the year of the recovery of the economy, the restoration of confidence, promotion, territorial, economic and social cohesion and, at the same time, convergence, strengthening our competitiveness and productivity, creating jobs, creating wealth and being able to have an even stronger social state. We do not lack financial resources and we need to be well used and complementarity and synergies. We will have the next Multiannual Financial Framework in place in 2021, the Recovery Fund and also what has not yet been fully used from the current Multiannual Financial Framework. For example, in my country we will have about 11 billion euros from Portugal 2020, we will have about 33 billion euros from Portugal 2030, from the next Multiannual Financial Framework, plus EUR 15.4 billion from the Recovery Fund. All these resources have to be managed in order to achieve goals. They have to be managed in such a way that they have synergies. One must look at its complementarity. It is essential that this work be done.  The Budget of the European Union, which is an important instrument, I hope that the Council will not see it as an expense, but that it sees it as an investment, because the normal, the usual, is the Council looking at a budget that is small but has enormous added value, but does not recognise an important instrument for the European Union.

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: – Mr President, 2021 is not a year like any other. It is not only the first year of a multiannual financial year, it is the first year in the history of European multiannual budgets in which we must not only look to the future, but also repair the unprecedented damage created by the biggest health crisis in the last century. Not only that, but it's also the year that needs to put us on the path of the new environmental pact. That is why, as shadow rapporteur on AGRI's view of the 2021 budget, I have condemned the 7.4% decrease in the budget in the first pillar of the common agricultural policy.  But most importantly, we have called for the money from the Next Generation EU, which goes to hard-pressed European farmers, to be made available to them as early as the beginning of next year. It is not a privilege, but our obligation to ensure that the hundreds of millions of Europeans will have healthy and affordable food at every moment, no matter what happens. And to ensure that, our farmers need to recover very quickly from the pandemic crisis, especially since from 2021 we are already asking them, through green deal, to produce to ever-higher standards.  And it is also our duty to speed up the process of innovation and digitisation so that the agri-food sector can rise to the required standards without suffering further losses. But at the same time, the Member States must also do their best to ensure that the short chain that Farm to Fork is talking about comes to life and be respected, and that the goods of our producers go where they belong, in the markets and on the shelves of retailers, without inflated and well camouflaged taxes.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: We are now continuing our debate on the report by Pierre Larrouturou and Olivier Chastel on the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2021 (A9-0206/2020).

name: Maxette PIRBAKAS
text: Mr President, as an Overseas Member of Parliament, I wanted to speak today about the situation of the five territories of the French DOMs through the general budget of the European Union. I note that the European Parliament continues to spend millions of euros every year on the construction of new buildings, funding states that call for a boycott of our French products, such as Turkey or Jordan, which penalises our French farmers. I remind you that some of my fellow ultramarine countries are still in great difficulty in accessing drinking water in 2020, to date, within the European Union! On the programme of options specific to remoteness and insularity, that is poseI, I call on the European Commission and the Council not to reduce this programme, which now amounts to EUR 280 million annually for France. I draw your attention to the fact that POSEI maintains the balance between distance, insularity and the additional costs of an island. It allows us to finance major local and national agricultural policy projects, in order to guarantee food sovereignty for our islands and regions. With regard to the European Fund for Maritime Affairs and Fisheries, the FEAMP, the proposal to introduce a 50% cap on the extra cost compensation plan, to which France is also opposed, must be rejected, because otherwise it would be direct aid to ultramarine fishermen. We must also remember that the Union's cohesion policy has a aim: to reduce regional and social inequalities within the European Union. So it is time to take concrete action for our French islands and regions, to move towards more administrative simplification, flexibility, accessibility for every European aid for our territories. Today, the ecological shift that some are trying to give to the European Union budget must stem from major policies to relocate and protect sectors, such as agricultural, fishing or handicrafts. This budget must move towards the defence of traditional fishing, family farming, more protected geographical identification but also more intelligent protectionism and fewer free trade treaties, which penalize our farmers. We now know that Europe is already a very ecological continent, very clean, with many innovative sectors. So why do we continue to put sticks in the wheels of our farmers, our fishermen and all those who participate in our economy and feed us? Together, let us go to a Europe at the service of the nations, the territories that make up it, starting with the outermost regions, those distant territories that make Europe shine... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: – Mr President. For years, the European Court of Auditors has criticised the inefficiencies of a number of European programmes that are output-oriented and not results-oriented for citizens. However, these warnings are often not accepted by the Commission. Evaluations of the impact of Commission proposals on society are often insufficient and do not use appropriate indicators measuring actual results for citizens. It is this plenary to which the Commission is accountable that it is supposed to keep an eye on european taxpayers' money. What we need most now is to allocate more efficiently. We should therefore call for more precise impact clauses and a higher quality of result indicators to help us make sensible decisions.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, as we are witnessing the worsening economic and social situation and the consequences of COVID-19, an unprecedented response was required. The measures adopted so far by the European Union are far from responding to the scale of the problems and this budget is no exception. Instead of the necessary increase and strengthening of its redistributive function, cuts in cohesion and agriculture persist and the absence of effective convergence in economic and social progress between Member States, opting for increases in militarism, eu-Fortaleza consolidation and external interventionism.  Measures are imposed, free from conditionalities and constraints of EU policies, to contribute to supporting states' development strategies, promoting public investment, supporting strategic productive sectors, public services, creating jobs with rights, combating poverty and social exclusion and combating inequalities and asymmetries in the full use of each region's potential.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. In 2010, the Hungarians, of their own free will, rejected the corrupt left, brought the country to the brink of bankruptcy and trampled on the fundamental rights of the people, and decided to give fidesz and the KDNP a two-thirds parliamentary majority. Even in this left-wing political plamflet, all the lies and sleaval that have been constantly being voiced since then, from the bloodshed of anti-Semitism, corruption, the stamp of populism, the alleged death of freedom of the press, to the lies about attacks on the institutions of the rule of law. In 2014, even amid the attacks of the left, Hungarians again supported Fidesz by a two-thirds majority of their own free will.  The Hungarian and European left already saw the Hungarians' decision as a direct provocation and even more vehemently insulted Hungary. Especially after 2015, when the pro-immigration majority of the EP came together against a Hungary that rejected immigration. These undignified attacks have also been summarised in the European Parliament. The Sargentini report was re-used as a vote and the procedure under Article 7 was initiated against Hungary. In 2018, the left was already in disregriben, but hungarians again supported Fidesz by a two-thirds majority. And the left has come to the conclusion that hungarians do not understand the threats made so far, so the period of systematic and harsh punishment has come. Well, this punitive measure is called the rule of law mechanism with historical absurdity on the left.

name: Mónica Silvana GONZÁLEZ
text: – Mr President, we are safer today, following the congratulations to Parliament's negotiators, especially Eider Gardiazabal and Margarida Marques, for reaching an agreement in which Parliament has managed for the first time to increase the figures proposed by the Council and which also allows new own resources to finance the programmes emblematic in the budget. Indeed, from development cooperation, from humanitarian aid, as shadow rapporteur to the DEVE Commission's opinion, we are pleased that this has been achieved, but we cannot stop here. We also need a commitment for the 2021 budget. We therefore wish rapporteur Pierre Larrouturou good luck in the conciliation period in order to reach good agreement with the Council as well. We were already played once in the Council in July, when we lost the EUR 5 billion for humanitarian aid. In the face of the tremendous crises ahead, increasingly numerous crises, increasingly intense crises, we need to strengthen development cooperation, strengthen humanitarian aid. Funds must therefore respond proportionately to the global crises we have, and we must demand that, if the European Union wants to be a global player, it wants to ensure security in Europe, it must strengthen its external action and humanitarian aid. This is a clear message to deal with the negotiation with the Council of the 2021 budget.

name: Roman HAIDER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Europe is being hit by the worst economic crisis in the EU's existence. Europe is haunted by Islamist terror. Europe is losing more and more competitiveness against China right now. One should think that a budget also takes account of these enormous challenges. Unfortunately, this is not the case in the EU.  If you study this report on the 2021 budget, you will immediately notice some absolute absurdities. It calls, for example, for the establishment of a search and rescue fund to support search and rescue missions in the Mediterranean. Obviously, the lucrative smuggling business is not entirely left to the criminals. It is easy to imagine who benefits from such a fund. All these pro-migration NGOs, which are obviously to be sponsored quite properly once again, probably so that the transfer of Islamists to Europe is not quite so arduous. It's incredible! And especially after the attacks in France and Austria, this is quite simply insane.  Of course, the demand for a gender mainstreaming approach must not be missing from this budget either. Gender mainstreaming is particularly important for the many unemployed and the companies that are currently facing bankruptcy. It's really unbelievable. It is incomprehensible what is in this budget.  And what, of course, runs like a thread through this whole budget, is this fetish of the Green Deal. It is obvious that we are deliberately destroying the most environmentally friendly industry in the world, the European one. The main thing is that it is destroyed in accordance with the Green Deal. And it will certainly please the millions of unemployed we have in Europe if they are also allowed to spend their last euro on products from China and India. That's the result of your fetish green deal. And finally, a point that strikes me particularly sour. The EU wants to exploit these current crises, the Corona crisis and the rampant Islamism-terrorism crisis, to exploit its agenda in all directions in order to spread. This starts with the introduction of Eurobonds, the debt union, through the demand for a health and social union, to the total surveillance of innocent citizens. This is unworthy of a liberal democracy and is contrary to the European values that you, in particular, keep highlighting so much.

name: Pernille WEISS
text: Mr President! It's going to be all right! That's probably the phrase we've worn the most in 2020. Because while we know that this is life all in all, the corona crisis has settled like a dense fog around our already many challenges with Brexit, climate, migratory pressures and trade wars. But we Europeans can overcome most of it – especially when we stand together on what none of us can do alone. Everyone knows the Danish position in relation to budgets, which we believe should concentrate on the core tasks and is organized in respect of the fact that the taxpayers' coffers are not cut out of money trees. But most of us Danes also know our pragmatic optimism. Let me therefore stress that the budget provides greater clout in the face of cross-border challenges, where climate change in particular, the pressure on external borders and our ability to match the United States and China in the field of research do not withstand austerity. After all, the European Union is no stronger than the weakest link. And covid has painfully revealed that there are weak links in the EU's stability, readiness for change and resilience. Now we have a strong budget, we have the prospect of a more EU-friendly Us President and on the vaccine front there are also optimistic signals. So tonight I dare say it's going to be all right! Especially if President Sassoli also realises that he should not silence our parliament. Otherwise, no one hears our optimism, sees our toil in reaching each other and feels the hope that we need to share with each other more than ever.

name: Eero HEINÄLUOMA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the 2021 budget under discussion is not a routine budget. It is an exceptionally important budget for all of us for two reasons. Firstly, this budget must trigger a real transition towards a CO2-free Europe, implement the green transition to which we are all committed. Secondly, this budget must also be an instrument by which we lift Europe from the coronavirus crisis to new growth. And these two things still have to support each other. I am delighted that the budget proposal before us is a good one and supports these two major issues. More money for research and university research and innovation is a necessary condition for Europe's success. Another important principle is that 30% of the budget is spent on combating climate change. They're big steps forward. However, I would also like to raise one more point that I consider important, which could be more on the agenda in this budget. It is the fight against money laundering and the resources involved. Billions continue to move in money laundering outside other activities of society, paying a tax burden on those who have to pay taxes. It is therefore important that next year we make progress in the fight against money laundering. In this context, it is particularly important that our police officer Europol's money is in the right place. I hope that improvements will be made to this issue during this parliamentary term.  I am also pleased that the 2021 budget is the first budget conditional on the rule of law. It is an important decision and will impose obligations equally on all Member States. In doing so, we will maintain the Union's ability to act and also its credibility, both in the eyes of its citizens and in relation to the outside world. I can support this draft budget.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is an extremely important debate: the 2021 budget. One of the few powers that the European Parliament has is precisely the time of the budget. So we must, on the one hand, find the courage to dare and, on the other hand, find the courage not to continue to make mistakes, because the next budget that is being carried out for some is worth +15 billion, that is, 15 billion more is being demanded of taxpayers. So you have to figure out where you want to find the courage to find this 15 billion. And I say, let's ask the Chinese government! We call on those who have created a global epidemic to compensate our families, our businesses and our economy. Europe has this great opportunity: we expect the Chinese Government to enter the European budget in compensation. We cannot think once again of finding this money in the pockets of Italian citizens and in the pockets of European citizens. It is also important to take stock of how we can help our businesses, to help our bars, our traders, our craft activities and our production activities, which are in serious crisis; the same jobs, in Italy but also in Europe, are in serious crisis. So, on the one hand, we find the resources and ask the Chinese Government, which created the tragedy of this epidemic, but on the other hand we also cut waste, we cut the Strasbourg office: we have seen that it is not necessary, we can intervene from Milan with an efficiency that I would say unique, without having to move and have a seat in Strasbourg with the associated costs. We also cut agencies, agencies in seychelles or agencies like that, the last one I read, on gender equality, parent one and parent two... Soon we will also do the agency on water or the agency on seven and a half or the agency on butterflies... I don't know what we can waste money on. I say no, of course, to a budget like this, which still includes money for Libya, money for Turkey, money for roma integration, money for reception.  I say that this budget should also find the courage to wipe out the share of VAT that comes into the pockets of the European Union. Italian citizens pay 2 billion VAT to the European Union every year. Then the European Union, with this budget, is giving up EUR 2 billion and leaving the EUR 2 billion in the pockets of the Italian citizens, who really need it.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you very much to Parliament for this dedicated and detailed debate. There have been a wealth of suggestions which will certainly be the subject of intensive discussions in the coming weeks. I am not sure that all the suggestions can be implemented, because a deal with China on the repayment of damages or damages is likely to be unenforceable by the beginning of January. But we will still try to provide the money – the money for the citizens who really need it now, also to keep their businesses afloat, so to speak, the money to ensure that jobs remain secure.  We have the SURE instrument. Yesterday we had another very successful auction in order to provide the funds so that funds could be made available, especially in the short-time working phase, especially in those countries that do not know this instrument to date. We will have REACT-EU, a tool that, as the name suggests, will make it possible to claim costs arising from the COVID crisis in the middle of February this year. So there are a lot of possibilities.  However, I would also like to take this opportunity to draw the attention of the honourable Parliament, to ask that the sectoral negotiations be taken forward together with the Council. Because one budget is one thing, the use of the possibilities is the other. And at European level, this is essentially done on the basis of sectoral legislation that is the basis on how this money can be spent. Even then, we still need appropriate programming, which must also be carried out in order to make the funds arrive where it is necessary, namely the citizens, the entrepreneurs, the researchers, the creativepeople of this country.  In other words, yesterday we made a big impact with the multiannual budget. But now it is a matter of putting things into practice – that is the crucial point – and there is no time to lose and therefore full attention to the 2021 budget. Negotiations will begin next week and must be completed in three weeks' time.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 12 November 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. – After lengthy negotiations, the European Parliament and the Council reached a preliminary agreement on the EU budget for 2021-2027. The European institutions have shown responsibility and care for today and tomorrow's generations, developing new programmes such as the Next Generation EU, designed to boost economic recovery after the Covid-19 pandemic. Romania, through the negotiations held in the Council, is the fourth country in the fourth most budgetary allocation after Poland, Spain and Italy, with a significant increase compared to the allocations from the previous budget.
