Reducing economic, social and territorial disparities will be made possible by money dedicated to cohesion policy, while Romanian agriculture and rural areas will benefit from increased budgets under the common agricultural policy. The new budget also comes with significant increases for the whole of the EU through: the European Health Programme, Erasmus, research and external border security. Even if some states want to veto the multiannual budget of the European Union, the success of making the granting of EU funds conditional on respect for the rule of law is a real victory for democracy and the values of the European Union. It is time for the Member States to show vision and to draw up future projects to attract European money into sustainable investment projects.

name: Josianne CUTAJAR
text: in writing. – As I look forward, I want to be positive. The year 2021 can be the first year of the post-Covid recovery. If we want to recover, we need a strong EU budget that allows us to recover. For this reason, the Budget 2021 has my support. The Parliament is sending a strong message to EU citizens and businesses that says - we are ready to support you, we will stand by you! I would like to highlight the positive provisions in terms of social cohesion, support to SMEs, gender equality and sustainable tourism. The hardly hit tourism sector needs robust assistance to recover sustainably. Islands will also be given specific attention through the Connecting Europe Facility. EU funds must be dedicated to recovery. The leitmotif of the recovery must be resilience. We must build a resilient economy that defends citizens, families and businesses. An economy ready to sustain future shocks, ensuring for Europe the place it deserves in the global arena.

name: Pierre KARLESKIND
text: In writing. Ladies and gentlemen, the 2021 budget is of particular importance to the fisheries sector as it comes at a time of serious economic instability. The new EMFF should help the sector to be part of the EU's new objectives, in particular the Green Deal. This should have justified an increase in the budget for 2021. Not only is the latter on the decline, but the fishing sector must also overcome an unprecedented crisis: the Covid-19 crisis. The sector is still suffering from the consequences of the massive decline in demand for seafood across Europe. The EMFF must be sufficiently sufficient to support the sector and must face possible new demand shocks related to the health crisis. We do not know how many waves will hit Europe next year. We do not know how long the restaurants will remain closed, substantially reducing the demand for seafood and the opportunities for our fishermen. That is why we, the European Parliament, must defend the fisheries sector and in particular the allocations of the FEAMP in order to give it a real strike force for 2021, which promises to be particularly complicated. Thank you

name: Andżelika Anna MOŻDŻANOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa 2021 is an exceptional and crucial year for Member States and all those receiving support. The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic is also a particular challenge. We must therefore ensure that the budget is adequate. In 2021, we must expect payment cumulation. This budget starts the new programming period 2021-2027 and must also cover commitments from the previous Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020. In particular, this applies to cohesion policy and the Rural Development Programme (RDRs), which are very important investment instruments in the EU. As rapporteur for the opinion on cohesion policy in the Committee on Regional Development, I have repeatedly drawn attention to this. Despite increasing the budget by more than EUR 15 billion in 2021, I have doubts about the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 60% by 2030, or the introduction of a rule of law mechanism as a condition for the EP's approval of the annual budgetary procedure. It is essential that we reach agreement on this issue as soon as possible in order to be able to finalise the work on next year's budget and to put in place the necessary resources for the Member States, including the much-needed REACT EU instrument aimed at combating the economic and social consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic.
